Title: Added delay test to measure comm delays with a led scope
Body: This adds a simple test to measure rates and delay end-to-end for wireless comms (offboard control) with a scope.

Title: BlinkM driver
Body: This is working well enough that I think other folks might want to play with it.

Title: support external apps in build for APM
Body: This makes it possible to have apps in an external tree  allowing APM to build its sketches on PX4 without having a modified Firmware tree

Title: Enables the PX4IO ADC from px4io adc integration branch
Body: This branch contains px4io-adc-integration  but also refactors the readout of the battery status (new battery_status uORB topic  changes in commander app to read this message).  It should be safe to merge once it has been verified that FMU and IO both report valid voltages via MAVLink.

Title: Sdlog buffering
Body: This changes the SD logger to an implementation with two threads  thread sync via pthread condition and locking.  The high-prio thread fills the ringbuffer  the low-prio thread empties it to microSD. This is to avoid loosing sensor messages or alternatively delaying controllers by SD I/O.

Title: Suppress warnings from ARM s DSP_Lib code that are spamming developers t
Body: ...o no benefit.  fixes #149

Title: Use the compiler to generate app dependencies
Body: The NuttX dependency generator has a number of issues (doesn't handle sources in subdirectories  for example).  In most cases  we can ask the compiler to do it for us  so let's do that instead.

Title: Sensor hil fixedwing
Body: This is a merge of sensor_hil_incr with fixedwing.

Title: Move APM startup scripts to APM git repo
Body: This adds support for EXTERNAL_SCRIPTS in PX4 build  allowing the APM build to install a rc.APM script from its git tree

Title: Implemented airspeed measurement
Body: First stab at airspeed measurement. Not yet tested in flight.

Title: Nuttx merge 5591
Body: This is running fine on bench tests. Fixed a couple of smaller compile errors due to a change in the low-level NuttX print function. Good to merge to master after a few in-vehicle tests.

Title: Better attitude filter not sensitive to sudden accelerations
Body: This fixes some issues we had with aggressive multirotor flight. Tested in lab setup  not flown outdoors with RC. Please test and report back.

Title: GPS driver rewrite
Body: This is based on Julian's work  with some additional minor cleanup. Does not reflect the most recent state on Julians branch as not stable.  Before merging this needs more cleanup and work  but its a good time to start the review and actively test it.

Title: Added additional debug uORB example
Body: This example helps with debugging controllers / estimators or other things that need a quick & dirty way to real-time graph stuff.

Title: Maxbotix I2C Sonar Support
Body: Sensor support for the i2c version of the maxbotix range finders.

Title: Pwm multirate
Body: This makes the PWM output rates configurable. Some documentation of the usage is required here:  https://pixhawk.ethz.ch/px4/users/apps/pwm  And in the startup scripts for the affected platforms.

Title: archlinux compatibility
Body: needs to be tested on ubuntu

Title: Refactoring of HoTT telemetry transmitter daemon
Body: Refactoring of HoTT telemetry transmitter daemon - Use more appropriate types - Better ways of getting compile-time constants (than using magic numbers) - Use signals for communicating with daemon process instead of shared memory (globals) - Improve logging code (less repetition  more appropriate syscalls)

Title: Quad wide arm mixer
Body: Added a mixer for quads that have wider spread rear arms than a typical V form quad.

Title: Quad wide arm mixer
Body: Added a mixer for quads that have wider spread rear arms than a typical V form quad  such as the SteadiDrone QU4D.

Title: Add support for quads with offset arms such as the TBS Discovery
Body: Adds a new mixer (generated with multi_tables) that supports quads with offset arms such as the TBS Discovery  SteadiDrone QU4D  etc by specifying "4v" in the mixer file.  Note: Do not merge yet. I will flight test this tonight and verify.

Title: Added startup scripts useful when running USB consoles made MAVLink awa
Body: ...re that /dev/console is a hint for running on USB (magic strings  magic strings)

Title: MD25 Motor Controller Driver
Body: I recently wrote a driver for the MD25 motor controller board here: http://www.robot-electronics.co.uk/htm/md25tech.htm. I am using it to control a segway-like robot with two wheels.  This isn't ready to merge yet as I haven't started live testing  but I would appreciate some feedback in the meantime.  The MD25 also has the ability to read the encoder information/ battery voltage/ motor current   which could be used to assist with indoor navigation etc. So it might make sense to add a new uORB topic for at least the encoder data/ possibly the motor voltage/current.

Title: Implement Spektrum DSM pairing in V2
Body: - Bind control for V2 - Relays and accessory power not supported on V2 hardware

Title: Mixer files for hex and octo
Body: Several fixes and hacks to make the hex fly!

Title: Unit tests for mixer
Body: This patch set contributes two things: - It fixes the pwm limit library call  whose state machine was inconsistent  resulting in memory (garbage) values being used for the first 0.5 seconds during arming. The state machine needs to be reviewed again now  but it should do what the design originally intended now. - Added a tight unit test for the ramp and the pass-through mixer  ensuring the ramp behaves as intended  Missing: A unit test checking arming / disarming cycles and the same thing tested in real-life. Please review the changes  I will add the test in the meantime.

Title: PPM in parsing for IO
Body: This changes the pin config for IO pins to match the scheme FMU (successfully) uses. Needs further cross-checking.

Title: Mixer testing and fixed corner cases
Body: This patch set adds a host-computer based OR NuttX based test suite for mixers for convenient and full-coverage testing. It identified a number of unaddressed corner cases and all known failure cases have been resolved  plus all found new corner cases have been considered  too. Please bench-test first  since this fixed issues seen in practice it should be merged rather soon.

Title: RSSI and concurrent S Bus output handling
Body: This patch set (WIP!) adds concurrent support for RSSI in and S.Bus out. Needs testing and fine - tuning  but the right building blocks are there.

Title: Improvements to parameter documentation script
Body: - px_process_params.py is now a fully featured program that takes command line arguments to determine what to output to - Integrates the DokuWiki XMLRPC functionality into the python script to automatically update some wiki pages. Set XMLRPCUSER and XMLRPCPASS environment variables and call px_update_wiki.sh - Improved DokuWiki formatting

Title: Added automatic declination lookup
Body: This allows to get the declination based on current lat / lon estimate and frees the user from the need to manually enter it for each location.

Title: ACRO mode
Body: ACRO mode (direct attitude rates control with RC) implemented for multirotors. Main state ACRO added and corresponding switch (ACRO is submode of MANUAL). Arming in ACRO not allowed for safety reasons. For fixed wing: vehicle_control_mode flags set but need support in fw controller.  Tested in HIL and in real flight.

Title: Kconfig cleanup
Body: This cleans up our Kconfig dependencies. Requires a parallel update of the PX4/NuttX repo.

Title: Mikrokopter BLCtrl driver mkblctrl
Body: Driver for Mikrokopter I2C ESCs. BLCtrl < 2.0 are full supported. BLCtrl 2.0 are currently with 8 Bit resolution (like the Versions < 2.0) supported.

Title: Replace single if lines with brackets in astyle
Body: This prevents us running into single if line errors. In particular with various contributors this is relevant.

Title: Fixed PPM DSM and S Bus co existence tested S Bus
Body: This patch introduces co-existence of the different input methods with respect of the joint channel data structure. If multiple input sources are present  S.Bus has highest priority  then DSM  then PPM. The availability of different sources is correctly accounted in any case  just the channel values and timestamps are stored according to this order.  This has been successfully tested with S.Bus input and FMU / QGroundControl.

Title: Parameter documentation enhancements
Body: Added a lot of parameter documentations and adapted the px4param scripts to Python 3. Includes #669.  Do not merge yet  but please test if the Python 3 fixes still work in Python 2.x. Especially the `open(filename  'wb')` call in XMLOutput which is needed for the new Unicode handling might fail in Python 2.

Title: 61 px4io spektrum decoder
Body: This is a substantial rewrite of the DSM satellite protocol decoder based on testing with actual hardware  and it should address #61. So far  tested with DSMX satellites and the DX8 only.  It should correctly detect 10- and 11-bit protocol streams with 6  7  8  10 or 18 channels  as generated by the current range of Spektrum transmitters. In theory it should decode the serial stream from DSM2 receivers  but this hasn't been tested yet.  Update: the S.bus decoder work from #83 has been merged with this  as there was quite a bit of overlap.

Title: Add Gumstix AeroCore device
Body: Based on the work of Andrew Smith [1]  add board configuration and device drivers to support the Gumstix AeroCore (previously Aerodroid) board [2]. The AeroCore is an autopilot board based on a STM32F427 similar to the FMUv2.  [1] https://github.com/smithandrewc/Firmware [2] https://store.gumstix.com/index.php/products/585/  Signed-off-by: Ash Charles ashcharles@gmail.com  Conflicts:     src/drivers/px4fmu/fmu.cpp     src/modules/commander/commander_helper.cpp

Title: SPI4 support
Body: This adds support for the (external) SPI4 bus.

Title: fix code style script enforce max line width of 120 chars
Body: This was briefly discussed by some of the devs on skype and I put it here to open the discussion to everybody. Currently some part of our code contains very long lines which makes it unreadable side by side even on a large monitor. In my opinion it makes sense to enforce a line width limit at least for new code to get this under control.  I selected 120 because we have tabwidth 8 and most (but not all) code fits 120. Also it's a moderate limit compared to 80 and leaves enough room also for people who like to write longer lines.  I don't want to kick off a religious discussion about linewidths and editors. If the general agreement is that we need a standard for this then lets merge it  otherwise I am happy to close this PR.

Title: NuttX integration merge
Body: This patch set removes all NuttX parts from the PX4 Firmware tree. It has undergone extensive bench testing for weeks (using real sensors and HIL) and should be ready for prime-time.  It would still be good to have some cross testing  but I have already based all my feature branches off this. In particular this branch helps with: - Having latest NuttX with all fixes that have been implemented in the meantime (printf()  NaN in printf()  USB AND ttyS0  to name a few prominent examples) - SPI DMA supported (though not enabled yet  there is a branch here with it enabled: https://github.com/PX4/nuttx/network)  There are some differences to current master in what files need to be checked out and the default target has been renamed to avoid confusion about which build system (old or new) we're using.  To convert an existing repo  perform these steps:  cd Firmware rm -rf nuttx git clone git@github.com:PX4/NuttX.git make archives make make upload px4fmu-v1_default

Title: Mavlink as git submodule
Body: Following the discussions in https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/1070 and https://github.com/mavlink/mavlink/pull/212 this PR adds mavlink as a submodule. The repo is https://github.com/mavlink/c_library which contains just the autogenerated header files.  By using the git submodule we can keep the Firmware and QGC in sync by using the same commit of the c_library.  **This can not be merged as long as the windows toolchain is not updated to fetch git submodules**

Title: Eagle Tree Systems Airspeed V3 Driver
Body: A driver that adds support for the digital Eagle Tree Airspeed I2C sensor. The differential pressure topic used by both the I2C and ADC airspeed sensors has been split into differential pressure and airspeed topics. I have not been able to test the (straightforward) refactoring of the ADC air pressure sensor in sensors.cpp yet.  The parameter SENS_VAIR_OFF previously contained a voltage offset for the ADC sensor and has now been replaced with SENS_DPRES_OFF and should operate on the resulting (or reported) differential pressure and not ADC voltage.

Title: Added px4fmu_sim branch for software in the loop SITL development
Body: I have created a new config under nuttx/config/px4fmu_sim. This builds the nsh console for px4 using the standard linux gcc toolchain. It then creates a virtual romfs and runs the px4 startup script. I wanted to get some feedback from the other developers before going any further. So please let me know what you guys think.  My main question is where should the SITL drivers go. I see that recently all of the code was moved out of nuttx/configs/px4fmu/src to apps/drivers/stm32. Should I create a folder in apps/drivers/sitl? It seems like the nuttx way would be to keep it under configs/px4fmu_sim/src but I can see how that is cumbersome.  Also  if anyone else has interest in helping to develop the SITL drivers  help would be appreciated. Luckily the default nuttx sim arch has a lot of the work done already.

Title: Nuttx bringup fix headers
Body: This is the clean up that made sense for the Firmware:  But I ran into issues with the px4fmu-v1 build for: src/drivers/boards/px4fmu-v1/px4fmu_spi.c   ``` void stm32_spi2select(FAR struct spi_dev_s *dev  enum spi_dev_e devid  bool selected); uint8_t stm32_spi2status(FAR struct spi_dev_s *dev  enum spi_dev_e devid); ```  are missing as prototypes. I have to trace what is going on because they are defined in nuttx'sarch/arm/src/stm32/stm32_spi.h (which should be pulled in from the stm32.h)  when the CONFIG_STM32_SPIn (n = 2-6)  are set but I just could  not get the build to run if I did not kluge it by adding the prototypes :  ``` void stm32_spi2select(FAR struct spi_dev_s *dev  enum spi_dev_e devid  bool selected); uint8_t stm32_spi2status(FAR struct spi_dev_s *dev  enum spi_dev_e devid);** ```  directly into src/drivers/boards/px4fmu-v1/px4fmu_spi.c

Title: Global performance improvements
Body: DO NOT MERGE  This is still WIP. Changes: - Debug/Nuttx.py:   - Now it works on GDB 7.6 with Python 2.7 ([from Terry Guo et al](https://launchpad.net/gcc-arm-embedded)).   - Output format of `show mybt` changed to match GDB's bt default format.   - `show mybt` still can't unwind the call stack correctly though - it was broken and it remains this way. - Added a simple sampling profiler Debug/poor-mans-profiler.sh. - Stack overflow checks via `__cyg_profile_func*()` are disabled by default  per @LorenzMeier's suggestion. They can be enabled back by setting `ENABLE_STACK_CHECKS=1`  e.g. `make ENABLE_STACK_CHECKS=1`. - Enabled extended debug information generation: `-g` replaced with `-g3`. This is not necessary  but it helped me with profiling and it doesn't affect the final binary  so it should be safe to keep. - Changes to the uavcan module (see https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/1417 for details):   - More perfcounters   - Stack overflow checks are always disabled  regardless of `ENABLE_STACK_CHECKS`   - `-O3` instead of `-Os`  One thing left to fix: the current head of this branch crashes occasionally (50/50) shortly _after_ boot:  ``` uavcan: subscribe to actuator_controls_0 navigator: Initializing.. mavlink_if0: DISABLING HARDWARE FLOW CONTROL [i] Addons script: /fs/microsd/etc/extras.txt   NuttShell (NSH) nsh> navigator: Could not clear geofence navigator: offboard mission updated: dataman_id=0  count=0  current_seq=0 Assertion failed at file:armv7-m/up_hardfault.c line: 184 task: uavcan sp:     20009264 IRQ stack:   base: 200092d0   size: 00000ffc 20009260: 200139ac 20009264 20013af0 200092d0 08078931 000000b8 080a9fd8 200139ac 20009280: 08078b61 08086645 08078a01 00000010 08078c05 08078be9 08089751 200065e4 200092a0: 00000003 200139ac 08086671 00000000 20015930 20011a10 00000008 20011a10 200092c0: 20011938 00000001 08078b61 200139ac 00000000 10000010 00000001 00000000 sp:     20013a80 User stack:   base: 20013af0   size: 00001384 20013a80: 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000 08059b6d 20015930 00000000 08059a17 20013aa0: 080599f5 2000da60 00000004 20011570 20011a08 0805b433 2000da60 0001209c 20013ac0: 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000 0805b58b 20013ae0: 0805b581 0807150d 00000000 00000000 ffffffff 198aed12 00000040 80001390 R0: 00000000 20011a10 00000000 63696d2f 20015930 20011a10 00000008 20011a10 R8: 20011938 00000001 200127b0 20011874 00000000 20013a80 08059861 08059c5e xPSR: 61000000 BASEPRI: 00000000 CONTROL: 00000000 EXC_RETURN: ffffffe9 ```  LR: modules/systemlib/mixer/mixer.cpp:73   PC: modules/systemlib/mixer/mixer_multirotor.cpp:217  Bisecting through the history  I found that the breaking commits are aa36686e765b11da040a536326aa8977ffd87d81 and 530988dfd1997f09c2deb61890859aa8d4399114 (the former introduced another bug that was fixed in the latter)  so the change that broke the module was adding `-fno-instrument-functions` to the uavcan module.  I'm currently half asleep and am likely missing something obvious here - I'll continue tomorrow. Meanwhile  any pointers or comments would be appreciated.

Title: ROS SITL
Body: Bringing up support for compiling modules for NuttX and Linux/ROS from the same code. The intent is to lower the barriers for the huge pool of ROS developers for creating px4 software. For people developing robotics software this allows them to easily test the behavior first on their PC in a SITL setup with ROS/Gazebo.  **This branch is not ready for merge yet. The goal is to gather feedback and make the branch available for first testers.** - Main change is wrapper around the uORB and the parameter interface. On ROS  instead of uORB the standard ROS subscriber and publishers are used. The parameters map to the ROS parameter server.   - It should be relatively straightforward to adapt this wrapper to a future uorb2 - Similar to the ROS nodehandle there is a nodehandle for px4 which handles all subscriptions and publications of a module. - Example usage in the [publisher](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/ros/src/examples/publisher/publisher_example.cpp) and [subscriber](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/ros/src/examples/subscriber/subscriber_example.cpp) example - Note that you _don't_ have to use these wrappers as long as your module should only run on a FMU/NuttX as until now. You also _don't_ need to install ROS for normal PX4 development. The only major change in this case is the uorb header generation as described below. - Messages are now defined in the ROS msg format and then converted to uorb header files or ROS header files on compilation   - Ported messages are here: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/tree/ros/msg (I only ported those which are needed by one of the ROS enabled apps)   - Regressions:     - no support for multi-dimensional arrays. As we only used them for rotation matrices in the uorb messages this is not a big problem. Rotation matrices are now stored as a float[9] array and there is this macro for element access: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/ros/src/platforms/px4_defines.h#L208     -  for topic groups (multiple topics of same type that are defined in same header file) I created a new message file for each topic. To make sure that the 'base' type can be used there are some manual typedefs needed: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/ros/src/modules/uORB/uORB.h#L294     - enums are not supported: I defined the values as constants: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/ros/msg/vehicle_status.msg#L2   - _TODO_: The message generation scripts (genmsg and gencpp from the ROS project) are included as submodules. We have to make sure they run on Mac and Windows as well. - Currently only the mc_att_control app is ported. The ported version can be found in [mc_att_control_multiplatform](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/ros/src/modules/mc_att_control_multiplatform/mc_att_control.cpp) (built only with the new px4fmu-v2_multiplatform make target) for now. So this PR _should_ have 0 effect on regular MC flying. - There are some dummy ROS nodes which translate from standard ROS topics to px4 ROS topics [here](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/tree/ros/src/platforms/ros/nodes) - **Setup Instructions**: https://pixhawk.org/dev/ros/sitl  Credits also to @tumbili (all the mathlib porting  initial simulation setup  ...) and @LorenzMeier   The PR includes #1040 by @jgoppert without the changes to mc_att_control  Links to 'hacks' which should be sorted out somehow: - https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/ros/src/modules/uORB/uORB.h#L291 - https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/ros/src/platforms/px4_defines.h#L181 ### TODO Documentation update on merge - Toolchain setup: install python-empy

Title: Nuttx Update to 7 x
Body: Thanks to the efforts of David Sidrane  a first candidate is available for wider testing. The NuttX update per se only provides bugfixes to existing functionality  but will allow to build: - USB mass storage: Faster / convenient access to logs when connected to a computer - Smaller time slices: Optimization to scheduling to allow more accurate prioritisation for critical control tasks - Support for new devices like the CC3000 wifi module (which might be of interest) - We are using a commit from upstream + some minor patches  so we're back to mainline.  Main validation areas: - Check that none of the fixed I2C issues resurfaces. Current NuttX employs all of the fixes developed for PX4 in the past  but not using the very same code  so soak testing is required.  Changes before merge:  This PR will be rebased  so for review only. We will squash a lot of the commits and get rid of merge commits.

Title: Mavstation addition
Body: This is all of the additions to get the Mavstation board running based off of this branch.  The board boots  starts a NSH terminal over USART1 (GPS port)  then automatically starts the mavstation code which switches the Radio from USART2 to the Raspberry Pi Header. The select button can be used to switch the Radio port back. The blue LED indicates the state of the switch  on=RasPi  off=Mavstation.

Title: SITL integration tests
Body: **WIP  supersedes #1803** - Updated integration tests based on MAVROS integration. - Modified commander to arm automatically when offboard setpoints arrive - Also contains a helper class that is able to verify if the copter stays on a predefined flight path with specifiable radius and visual indicator in Gazebo.  Issues that should get fixed before demo tests can be completed: - PX4/euroc_simulator/issues/11 - PX4/euroc_simulator/issues/9 (not necessarily)  Wiki pages that go along with this PR  also WIP: - https://pixhawk.org/dev/ros/sitl_testing - https://pixhawk.org/dev/ros/sitl_ci_setup  TODO: - resolve arming issue  then cleanup tests (2 things: controller creating in euroc and cmd support in mavlink) - move mavros nodes to root  Nice to have: - gtest demo test - attitude/velocity setpoint demo test

Title: ROS SITL offboard setpoints
Body: # What's new - mavlink dummy node which forwards a small subset of messages via udp to a mavros node - Support for local position and attittude offboard setpoints (XXX_target mavlink messages) in ROS SITL - Small demo node for offboard position control - launch files which launch the demo node and setup mavros: `roslaunch px4 gazebo_ardrone_empty_world_offboard_demo.launch`  Here is a small overview:  ``` (Gazebo <--> ) [demo_positon_setpoint_generator node] <--> [mavros] <--> UDP <--> [mavlink node] <--> [controller nodes] <--> Gazebo ```  If you use your own (pizza delivery  obstacle avoidance) ros node instead of `[demo_positon_setpoint_generator node]` this will allow you to test the functionality in gazebo before replacing the part right of `UDP` with the real system (which is then connected to mavros through a serial port instead of UDP). # Testing status - offboard position control is operational and tested with the demo node - offboard attitude control is operational and tested with the demo node  Includes #1786   Fixes #1745

Title: SITL integration test demo
Body: @thomasgubler @LorenzMeier  **Not to merge.** Opening this PR for discussing next steps/issues. The demo simulates joystick input to arm and uses a hack to force it into offboard  which will all be obsolete once offboard is in for real.  It contains 2 simple Python unittests and ROS launch files that can be executed either with `rostest` or `catkin_make test`. See here: http://youtu.be/Qedhq5O0mYM :)  **Launch files:** I had to pull up all the iris_empty_world stuff into our top-level launch file to expose the Gazebo arguments (for headless testing). This works of course  but if you like to leave these part in euroc_simulator  the launch files there need to be modified instead. What's best?  **Automated testing:** I also have a setup ready for a build server with Docker support :) But for that we should take the Docker files out of the PX4 repository. The Docker hub builds the image on every push which makes no sense. I suggest to add a new repository for "container" related stuff (Docker  Vagrant  etc). Something like this: https://github.com/UAVenture/containers For running the integration tests I added a new container that is based off the existing px4-ros-full: https://github.com/UAVenture/containers/tree/master/docker/ros-indigo/sitl-testing . There we can add other things  like pre-built source dependencies to speed-up the test. I'm thinking of everything except Firmware. But how is it with euroc_simulator and mav_comm? Since they are private  I'm not just going to include them then in a public build ;)  This is how it's supposed to work: ![sitl integration test setup](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5750020/6221085/dd8d5d8e-b63e-11e4-9963-79ef8b4b2caa.png)  Cheers ada

Title: add make check_format to enforce astyle
Body: The idea is to fix formatting once and for all so we don't have to waste time discussing it. Once the formatting is fixed (make format) and committed  'make check_format' can be added to travis to catch formatting errors as they're created.  make format runs ./Tools/fix_code_style.sh on all sources files and headers in src.  make check_format runs astyle  but displays a diff of the change and doesn't modify the original.  This is what running 'make format' will do. It looks like we may want to tweak the case indenting. https://github.com/dagar/Firmware/compare/format_fix?expand=1

Title: Qurt test
Body: Makefile multi-target support  ``` NuttX is still the default target and all NuttX configs can still be built with:  make  Individual NuttX  POSIX  and QuRT configs can now be built more easily by specifying the target and configs:  make posix posix_default make qurt qurt_hello make nuttx aerocore_default  Running make with just the target will make all the configs for that target:  make nuttx make qurt make posix  The help is also target specific: make nuttx help make qurt help make posix help  "make help" will still assume you want help for the NuttX target  Added a new QuRT config called qurt_hello as a sample config to test building in different commands for separate configs. ```  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: Sensors added missing px4_close and removed _exit call

Title: Fix double build when using new make target syntax
Body: When make is invoked as "make posix posix_default" it will build the posix_default target twice. The Makefile was fixed to correct this.  If "make posix" is run  the Makefile still calls "make PX4_TARGET_OS=posix".  If "make posix posix_default" is run  the posix target just exports PX4_TARGET_OS=posix and then make evaluates the next goal (posix_default).  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: pwm_input modifications
Body: *\* Reset feature added for pwm_input driver. ** GPIO_GPIO5_OUTPUT (AUX 6 signal pin) is currently used as reset pin. Reset is happening if pwm_input don't get any data for some time  to prevent reset-spamming while lidar is not connected ROMFS should toogle pwm_input driver on parameter. (not implemented in this fork)  *\* Publication to range_finder topic added ** range_finder topic is used by several sensors (pwm_input  i2c lidar interface and range_finder currently) and ROMFS should have cases to enable ony one of them.

The PR also contains: #2222  Feel free to review  comment and test  thanks.  **Things tested:** - `pwm_input start` - `pwm_input test` - `ll40ls start pwm` - `ll40ls test pwm` - DISTANCE_SENSOR message in QGroundControl  ``` nsh> pwm_input start nsh> ll40ls start pwm nsh> ll40ls test pwm ll40ls: single read ll40ls: measurement: 1.81 m ll40ls: time:        0 ll40ls: periodic read 0 ll40ls: measurement: 1.842 m ll40ls: time:        0 ll40ls: periodic read 1 ll40ls: measurement: 1.842 m ll40ls: time:        0 ll40ls: periodic read 2 ll40ls: measurement: 1.818 m ll40ls: time:        0 ll40ls: periodic read 3 ll40ls: measurement: 1.807 m ll40ls: time:        0 ll40ls: periodic read 4 ll40ls: measurement: 1.836 m ll40ls: time:        0 ll40ls: PASS nsh> ll40ls info pwm state @ 20014c40 ll40ls_pwm_read: 218 events  0 overruns  12104us elapsed  55us avg  min 34us max 2471us 165.817us rms ll40ls_pwm_read_errors: 1 events ll40ls_pwm_buffer_overflows: 208 events ll40ls_pwm_zero_resets: 1 events ll40ls: poll interval:  50 ticks ll40ls: distance: 1.839m  ```  Also  the reset on Aux pin 6 seems to be working:  ``` nsh> Idle Task: Lidar is down  reseting ```

Title: git_version not removed on clean
Body: The Build/git_version.\* files need to be removed on make clean.  If the files are not removed  they create problems for header dependencies that may not exist. Specifically  trying make posix after having previously built for NuttX failed because it could not find stdint.h in the nuttx-exports subdir tree and the dependency existed in git_version.c.d  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: Integration of the multithreaded version of the uavcan module that saves on memory
Body: UDATED: Ready to merge  @LorenzMeier Hold off on this until @pavel-kirienko and I work out any remaining issues. - DONE  This commit saves on memory by the virtue of changes in uavcan lib and by adding a separate object that runs in a lower priority thread which runs the functions that support bootloading with Dynamic Node ID allocation and FW file serving.  The separate thread is part of the uavcan task and started with a subsequent  `uavcan start fw`  command. The separate thread is independently stopped with  `uavcan stop fw`  Or it stops with the main uavcan task  `uavcan stop` (if it is already started)

Title: Cmake weak
Body: This fixes driver problems with unlinked weak functions in the current build by removing the weak attribute.

Title: Removed weak attributes
Body: This fixes driver problems with unlinked weak functions in the current build by removing the weak attribute.  This is based upon #2855

Title: Improvements to make support added debug target
Body: - Defaulted to j4 parallel make bulid - Enabled autostart script  since boot is now working. - Added debug target that creates a gdbinit script and calls gdb on the firmware for you. Note that you will need to set the follwing in your root .gdbiint:   ~/.gdbinit:   set auto-load safe-path / - Added check_weak target that prints all weak symbols in the firmware  the current list is:   This removes the weak attribute from some functions that caused the symbols to get thrown away when linking as static libraries to the executable in the new build.

Title: Work on px4io firmware building
Body: I just renamed the branch on PR #2842 for my own sanity.  I also rebased this on cmake-2 so it is a simple patch.  This is the compile flag diff we need to analyze to fix the linking.  ``` cmake --- ms5611_build_cmake  2015-09-12 14:40:34.753689277 -0400 +++ ../Firmware/ms5611_build_orig   2015-09-12 14:40:39.901689126 -0400 @@ -1 48 +1 43 @@  arm-none-eabi-g++ +   -MD     -c     -fno-exceptions     -fno-rtti     -std=gnu++0x     -fno-threadsafe-statics     -D__CUSTOM_FILE_IO__     -Os +   -g3     -fno-strict-aliasing     -fno-strength-reduce     -fomit-frame-pointer     -funsafe-math-optimizations     -fno-builtin-printf     -ffunction-sections     -fdata-sections     -mcpu=cortex-m4     -mthumb     -march=armv7e-m     -mfpu=fpv4-sp-d16     -mfloat-abi=hard     -DCONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_PX4FMU_V2     -D__PX4_NUTTX     -DCONFIG_WCHAR_BUILTIN     -Isrc/ -   -Ibuild_px4fmu-v2_default -   -Ibuild_px4fmu-v2_default/src     -Isrc/modules/     -Isrc/include/     -Isrc/lib/     -Isrc/platforms/ +   -IBuild/versioning/     -Isrc/drivers/boards/px4fmu-v2 -   -Isrc/modules/px4_messages -   -Imavlink/include/mavlink     -Isrc/lib/eigen/     -Inuttx-export/include     -Inuttx-export/include/cxx     -Inuttx-export/arch/chip     -Inuttx-export/arch/common     -DPX4_MAIN=ms5611_app_main     -fvisibility=hidden     -include src/include/visibility.h -   -nodefaultlibs -   -nostdlib     src/drivers/ms5611/ms5611_nuttx.cpp     -o     ms5611_nuttx.cpp.o ```

Title: CMake Mac OS SITL support

Title: Cmake Added px4io bin to ROMFS

Title: Cmake io upload fix
Body: Fixes io uploading by correcting alignment in linker script.

Title: Added PX4 ESC skeleton functionality to nuttx_next
Body: @pavel-kirienko @LorenzMeier The pr is the integration branch for the ESC  https://github.com/Zubax/px4esc_foc/issues/7#event-359044277  I think it will need a binfs and start up script. For now all functions are available from the command line   I have hooked the PX4 param system and added support for saving the params in the reserved sectors of the STM32. See https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/commit/09e2c8f0b91dba042d5ee731f27074bfd7fc1b01#diff-0650f9344eb2be13429c5573ff67400bR983 for the lowvlevel interface.   The normal PX4 param commands work and persists the data in the Soc's Flash  ``` help usage:  help [-v] [<cmd>]    [           date        help        mkfifo      rm          uname   ?           dd          hexdump     mh          rmdir       unset   break       echo        kill        mv          set         usleep   cat         exec        losetup     mw          sh          xd   cd          exit        ls          ps          sleep   cp          false       mb          pwd         test   cmp         free        mkdir       reboot      true  Builtin Apps:   sercon   serdis   adc   cfg   rpm   config   param   stat   ver   uavcanesc   nshterm   selftest   dc   top   reboot nsh> param show Symbols: x = used  + = saved  * = unsaved     SYS_PARAM_VER [-1 0] : 1     SYS_COMPANION [-1 1] : 0     SYS_RESTART_TYPE [-1 2] : 2     SYS_USE_IO [-1 3] : 1     SYS_AUTOCONFIG [-1 4] : 0     SYS_AUTOSTART [-1 5] : 0     CBRK_GPSFAIL [-1 6] : 240024     CBRK_ENGINEFAIL [-1 7] : 284953     CBRK_FLIGHTTERM [-1 8] : 121212     CBRK_AIRSPD_CHK [-1 9] : 0     CBRK_IO_SAFETY [-1 10] : 0     CBRK_RATE_CTRL [-1 11] : 0     CBRK_SUPPLY_CHK [-1 12] : 0     UAVCAN_BITRATE [-1 13] : 1000000     UAVCAN_NODE_ID [-1 14] : 120   + UAVCAN_ENABLE [-1 15] : 0   16 parameters total  0 used. ```

Title: qurt Must use latest version of Eigen
Body: The latest version of Eigen is required to build with the Hexagon 7.4 toolchain. Only certain C++11 features are supported and the latest version if Eigen provides these tests. A patch is required to add support for the Hexagon compiler.  These changes force the sync and then update of eigen and allow it to be patched for qurt.  The eigen-3.2 submodule was removed as it is no longer needed by the qurt build with the updated toolchain.  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: CMake Windows Fixes
Body: @LorenzMeier @jgoppert There are several problems with cmake on windows. So far I've identified the following  but I don't have proper fixes yet. - [x] remove rsync again - delete and copy NuttX each time - [x] change cmake generator to `MSYS Makefiles` (I think)  We need some way to detect windows for the toplevel makefile. One hacky way is to check for the SystemRoot env variable that should only be present on windows. - [x] set PYTHONPATH properly on windows https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/72dfc6b0b6c3a561f5b338677dce112b41bdce83/cmake/common/px4_base.cmake#L333 - [x] libuavcan problems with windows include paths not being passed properly - [x] topic_listener path split - [x] romfs bin_to_obj.py

Title: cmake improve submodule handling and nuttx copy
Body: Unfortunately because of the way git submodules work I think we'll have to update them every single make. There's no easy way for cmake to detect that a submodule needs to be updated.

Title: Code style enforcement with formatting fixes
Body: PR #2744 + formatting fixes to see if it breaks anything.

Title: reduce make verbosity
Body: This PR silences `%  MODULE_*`  and `make: Entering directory` `make: Leaving directory` messages by default (enable with make V=1).  Overall it reduces the console output significantly to the point where it can be properly displayed on travis-ci.

Title: Remove policy that broke posix and fix gcc warning
Body: A Clang only flag was set for all builds. The policy change to upstream was reverted.  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: cmake Fixes for qurt build
Body: Added build stubs. Fixed NuttX build for missing px4_parameters Fixed missing module (platforms/common) which was causing missing generated message errors.  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: Qurt rebase updates 3
Body: Added dspal as a PX4 submodule. Removed the re-definitions of the usage method in the posix/main.cpp file. Added qurt_external_hook interface to call externally linked module. Fixed code format to comply with PX4 style. Added usage information to main app and handled cases for unknown arguments. Fixed the orb_priority interface to use int32_t instead of int. Fixes to get hil working with led changes. Added the config_eagle_adsp.mk file and update the make files to to use new include/lib paths

Title: Fixes for qurt HIL build
Body: Workaround required Eigen downgrade to 3.2. Hexagon toolchain does not support C++11 features of newest version of Eigen.  Running   ``` make qurt_fixup  ```  will downgrade and patch Eigen for qurt. Running   ``` make restore  ```  will revert the patch and do a git submodule update to restore the expected Eigen version.  Fixed type used in orb_priority to be consistent with the code (int\* was used in declaration but int32_t\* used in code)  Removed unused class member variable in sensors.cpp  Added cmake fix for unit tests. The location of px4_log.c changed.  Fixed the qurt drv_hrt.c implementation to use us instead of ms for time resolution  Added px4_led.c to nuttx platform layer Use the posix version of px4_led.c for nuttx so we don't end up with duplicate files. It was moved out of common because it is not used by qurt.  Changed PX4_DEBUG to PX4_WARN when checking for the error condition for store_poll_waiter in vdev.cpp  Updated the px4_log.h file to make calls to the qurt_log functions. The qurt_log function is defined in the platforms/qurt layer.  Added an option to control starting the commander module in HIL mode.  Moved the flight specific drivers to the configuration file instead of adding them to the common tool chain file because HIL mode does not need them.  Added the uorb Subscriber and Publisher classes  Call PX4_ISFINITE macro instead of isfinite().  Added px4_led.c to nuttx platform layer Use the posix version of px4_led.c for nuttx so we don't end up with duplicate files. It was moved out of common because it is not used by qurt.  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: Fixed check for uavcan submodule version
Body: Script was checking for uavcan vs src/lib/uavcan  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: Changes for qurt SITL and other minor qurt fixes
Body: Qurt build configuration fixes  Moved LED functions from simulator to src/drivers/boards/sitl so it can also be used from QuRT when not running simulator. This is needed for HIL.  Fixed parameter type in uorb_priority  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com  Reverted rate limiting deletion  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: Removed qurt patch for Eigen and updated eigen commit
Body: The patches for Hexagon support are in the eigen repo so the patch can now be removed.  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: qurt Change to Hexagon 7 2 10 compiler
Body: Switched to 7.2.10 since the Linux version of this is available.  Added -DHAS_C9X flag to fix isses with undefined math functions when using hexagon-clang++.  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: Driver for the SRF02 ultrasound range finder adapted from Maxbotix driver
Body: I created this driver for the SRF02 ultrasound range finder  I took the Maxbotix driver (mb12xx) and modified the I2C commands to make it compatible with the SRF02. I tried it with one sensor and it works.  Note:  I also noticed that the original driver has a problem with the "test" command  since it always return 0.0 meters when you connect just one sensor. I corrected it on my driver  it should be corrected even in the mb12xx driver but I can't  because then I don't have a mb12xx sensor to test it

Title: Hexagon vagrant
Body: Fixes to support cmake 2.8 (used by vagrant image) and provide the environment variable in the vagrant provisioning for the HexagonTools.  This will allow the HexagonTools to be installed in the vagrant image using the installer defaults.  The default file sharing mechanism breaks when mmap is used for files in the shared folder. Using NFS for shared folders resolves this issue and works out of the box for MacOS.  On Ubuntu: sudo apt-get install nfs-kernel-server

Title: Local Position Estimator
Body: This is a repost of https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/2096 since we moved the repo to dronecrew. This has been recently flight tested. I'm just about to fly it again on an Iris after pulling from master. @TSC21  @BMP-TECH  @LorenzMeier  @mhkabir  @tumbili   It adds a replacement for position_estimator_inav  local_position_estimator  with a standard kalman filter implementation and fault detection. The kalman filter gains have been automatically tuned using real log data. There are at least several hundred hours of flight testing behind this estimator. Primarily with GPS + lidar or GPS + baro configurations. PX4Flow indoors was also tested. It also support motion capture and vision based position data  but this hasn't been heavily tested.  This has been rebased on the latest cmake changes and the lpe firmware can be built using:  ``` bash make px4fmu-v2_lpe make px4fmu-v2_lpe upload etc... ```

Title: Moved sitl targets to cmake to easily support more board configs

It also includes a robust way to estimate airspeed from local velocities and wind states  instead of using direct sensor input..  TODO till tonight: - interface att_control modules to take the filtered rates - interface fixed-wing module to take the airspeed - add to logging  @tumbili   I will have time again in the evening to complete this  hopefully in-time for you to test them tomorrow ;)

Body: VTOL code now also runs on posix.

Title: Separate matrix lib into own repo added testing and coverage
Body: This adds a submodule for: https://github.com/dronecrew/matrix that provides eigen like functionality. This library is BSD 3 part licensed  and I'm flexible to changing it  moving the project to PX4. I've flown this in SITL with no problems.

Title: Adds valgrind support started to correct some bugs in SITL
Body: So far valgrind has helped find a lot of "branch depends on unitialized value" issues. Mostly in our polling for SITL. There are a ton of other unfixed memory errors   you can run this using:  ``` bash make posix_sitl_default jmavsim___valgrind ```

Body: @LorenzMeier Not really to merge yet  but you can start to try it. I've integrated DriverFramework into ADCSIM and GYROSIM.

Title: Driver framework 2
Body: New branch for the co-ordinated development for driver_framework integration. It is rebased on master. This is not yet complete and should not yet be merged but the PR allows the changes to be visible.

Title: Set flags for building the proper DriverFramework target
Body: The DF_TARGET cmake variable needs to be set to (linux  darwin  qurt  nuttx) The define __DF_LINUX or __DF_QURT needs to be set. The __DF_DARWIN target is untested  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: Takeoff landing
Body: This branch is rebased on master which was a bit of a pain. I'm using the matrix lib of James Goppert in the terrain estimator because of the eigen issue in the standard mathlib. This should be test flown in SITL (not necessarily takeoff and landing but general fw operation ). After that we can merge it and I will do a real test flight with the new trainer model we have.

Title: Tailsitter gazebo
Body: This together with the PR for sitl_gazebo allows simulation of a tailsitter model in gazebo.  To try type: make posix_sitl_default gazebo_tailsitter  Connect with QGC over the default UDP port. If you haven't done so calibrate your Joystick AND the Radio. Set your mode switches  don't forget to map AUX1 because this is the transition switch.  I would also advise to set VT_PERM_STAB param to 1 so that the the plane is always stabilized in fw mode.

Title: Added changes to sensors cpp for DriverFramework
Body: This only works for DF based builds (not NuttX). NuttX is not yet ported to DF.  Signed-off-by: Mark Charlebois charlebm@gmail.com

Title: SITL fixes
Body: @mcharleb This works around the broken orb_limit calls and makes the HRT 0 interval warnings go away except for on init and on buzzer calls  which both make sense. I have a bad memory access still happening  but its likely unrelated. Currently chasing that one with all of Vagrant's might.

Title: Driver framework memory fixes and verbosity cleanups

Title: Vtol work

Title: BST Black Sheep Telemetry protocol support
Body: Driver for BST devices connected to I2C port. Tested with [TBS Crossfire RX](http://www.team-blacksheep.com/products/prod:crossfire_8chrx).  Driver sends the following messages: - Attitude (not yet supported by Crossfire TX) - Battery - GPS  TBS Crossfire TX converts these messages to mavlink and sends via Bluetooth to groundstation.  I had to change `rc.scripts` to avoid starting ms5611 driver on I2C port  it detects Crossfire RX as ms5611 chip because of the same device ID. Maybe it's possible to return it back if make chip detection more smart.  Tested in flight  battery and GPS work fine. Need more testing and adding more BST messages.

Title: Remove CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD ifdef dependencies from mtd
Body: Since mtd already checks whether CONFIG_MTD_RAMTRON is set in defconfig use this define to check whether to call ramtron_attach() or at24xxx_attach() in the main function  instead of checking CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_PX4FMU-V1.  Also instead of using #ifdef CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_AEROCORE to determine whether to start mtd on spi 2 or 4  rather use a new board define PX4_SPI_BUS_RAMTRON in the board_config.h file.  This is related to suggestion for improvement #2574 - improving the portability of the  firmware to new boards.

Title: add rotation for stryker vtol

Unless there's a significant performance impact for doing a 3x3 matrix multiply versus rotate_3f in the sensor drivers?

We still need to write tests for the new functions and also for the data management class. I think it would be great if you could try this and see if you can get into a good work-flow with the submodules (it took me quite some time).  Note: If e.g. your ecl folder stays empty try something like git submodule update --init --recursive --force

Title: MC Takeoff and land support
Body: Merry Christmas PX4 :) Adding with permission  takeoff and landing improvements.  This PR adds: - Auto takeoff - Auto land - ACK for commands - Possibility to switch to POSCTL/ALTCTL on the ground (to really make use of this #3385 needs to be implemented) - Make RTL use the same landing method  Disarming after landing is not active by default  we'd need to check default values for that carefully. How good it works depends on the tuning of the airframe  all the involved parameters have to be in "sync".  Landing and takeoff is currently supported via command  in missions and RTL. #3385 could be the next step.  Fixes #3365

Title: Add Input Capture capabilities to FMU For Camera time stamping
Body: @LorenzMeier  and @tridge   This PR add the (ioctl) hooks and test for Input Capture capabilities to FMU.  The original  pwm_servo driver and a new input_capture driver are layered on top of a new io_timer driver.  The io_timer driver manages the timer's channel resources in a sharing friendly way. It demuxes interrupts and provides layered callbacks.  Currently the fmu diver has been expanded to support the additional modes of:  | Mode | Aux | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 | 6 | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | mode_pwm2 |  | P | P | G | G | G | G | | mode_pwm3 |  | P | P | P | G | G | G | | mode_pwm2cap2 |  | P | P | C | C | G | G | | mode_pwm3cap1 |  | P | P | P | C | G | G |  The test command will also display input statistics and capture data.  Some limitations:  Since a Capture input channel and a PWM output channel share the same timer time base. The maximum that a capture channel can be blocked by disabled ISR and not overflow is == the 1/ PWM output rate. Since the pwm runs at. 2.5 and 20 Ms. - This should not be a problem.  For this very reason  when using the PWM Input driver AUX 5 and 6 should be used. It will have a maximum capture range of 62.5MS  **NB** the pwm input driver should be started **AFTER** the FMU driver is started in a mode that leaves AUX 5 and 6 as G(pio)

Title: Yaw timeout for VTOL forwards transition
Body: This adds a yaw timeout on accepting the waypoint for the VTOL forwards transition because a VTOL might not reach yaw in wind. Fixes #3728  MIS_YAW_TMT - default: -1 - > 0: timeout active on waypoints which force heading  ignore heading for acceptance on normal waypoints  MIS_YAW_TMT set to 10 seconds for default VTOL configurations

Title: Added LSM9DS1 GYRO ACCEL LSM9DS1 MAG and BMI160 GYRO ACCEL Fi
Body: We tried to make the PX4 compatible with the sensors LSM9DS1 and BMI160 sensors.  As the LSM9DS1 has two different CS pins for MAG and ACCEL+GYRO  we decided to keep them into separate files and treat them as two different devices.  The LSM9DS1 MAG driver seems to be working properly. The LSM9DS1 ACCEL+GYRO driver works well when compiled with the LSM9DS1 MAG and MPU9250. The BMI160 driver works well when compiled with the LSM9DS1 MAG's and MPU9250.  When we try to implement BMI160 and LSM9DS1 ACCEL+GYRO at the same time  it gives: "offboard mission init: ERROR" and "Not ready to fly: Sensors need inspection".  PS - The drivers' comments might not be correct  as this is a raw version of the final drivers.

Title: PWM init
Body: This patch changes the way the system boots and forces all GPIO pins to low on boot. This might interfere with triggers / GPIO payloads  but since the level shifter is auto-direction sending not doing this means the pins are in a random state on the output. This way we force a known state.

On top of that  the branch contains several merge conflict fixes  as well as build fixes and ifdefs in order not to break existing functionality.  Currently  the following build: - [x] `make px4fmu-v2_default` - [x] `make posix gazebo` - [x] `make posix jmavsim` - [x] `make posix_rpi2_default` - [ ] `make posix_rpi2_release` - [x] `make posix_eagle_default` - [x] `make qurt_eagle_default`  The following are flight tested: - [x] `make px4fmu-v2_default` (**TODO before merging**) - [x] `make posix gazebo` - [x] `make posix jmavsim` - [ ] `make posix_rpi2_default` (still needs sensor integration  won't fly just yet) - [ ] `make posix_rpi2_release` (still needs sensor integration  won't fly just yet) - [ ] `make posix_eagle_default` (WIP) - [ ] `make qurt_eagle_default` (WIP)  @mcharleb and @LorenzMeier please review and check for merge mistakes (especially removed/added files) and check for things that could potentially flying with NuttX.  @tumbili (or anyone else) please do a regression flight test on hardware running NuttX.  ~~Also  before merging this  we should try to include @jywilson's fixes as well.~~ Done  This pull request replaces #3723.

Title: git submodules sanity and minor Makefile cleanup
Body: More fun with our favorite subject git submodules. This PR fixes a bunch of little problems I've encountered as I frequently jump between master  stable  and even older. In particular submodules within submodules appearing and disappearing between checkouts is especially fun.  Summary - `make submodulesclean`  - the nuclear option for forcing them to reset and cleanup. - `make distclean` - restore everything to the state of a fresh clone - restored default eclipse project files - it's not clear why these were causing problems. If it's still a problem can you please provide details so I could fix it? - run unit tests with `make tests` and ignore generated files - moved travis-ci vectorcontrol build commands into `make uavcan_firmware` - added `make check` which builds all nuttx configs  runs the tests (which builds posix_sitl_default)  and checks formatting. I'd eventually like to turn this into the thing you can run locally to replicate exactly what travis-ci does. - added `make package_firmware` to zip all the .px4 binaries into Firmware.zip

Title: improved position based flow correction for lpe
Body: The main difference is that this treats flow as a position estimate in order to reduce long-term drift. It also has a high pass on the flow gyro which effectively removes gyro bias from the flow sensor without having to estimate it directly.  Flight test video  pretty good  mild wind  5-10 mph  very cold :-/: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0PqPsRMFyhw  Flight Logs: http://logs.uaventure.com/view/xWtaFRQioDTwiE8j6VDjsG http://logs.uaventure.com/view/ZPHp2jaXUUbLXZCmzzxGmK

Title: mavlink_log refactor take 3
Body: Since we can't use the ioctl call on Snapdragon  let's move the mavlink_log calls from ioctls to the uORB interface.  This is a third PR and replaces #4018. Title: added snapdragon rc pwm driver
Body: This branch can be used to fly snapdragon with Pixfalcon / Pixracer or Pixhawk as companion for rc input and pwm output. You can flash this branch onto the Snapdragon AND the Pixfalcon. You will have to configure e.g. the Pixfalcon such that it suits the vehicle you are flying. This is because the mixing is happening on the Pixfalcon and not on the Snapdragon. This step allowed much easier integration of the two systems. Also make sure to calibrate the rc on both the Pixfalcon and the Snapdragon. The vehicle can be armed as usual with the safety switch and the rc control.  Comment: The actuator commands are sent form Snapdragon to Pixfalcon using UART at 115200 bit/s. It appears that this link is too slow to run at 250 Hz  therefore there is a usleep(5000) in uart_esc.cpp at line 474. We need so see if we can run the UART at a higher rate. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/rc_pwm/src/drivers/uart_esc/uart_esc.cpp#L474  The UART on the Pixfalcon which is used to communicate with Snapdragon is specified here https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/rc_pwm/ROMFS/px4fmu_common/init.d/rcS#L817 Make sure that this replicates the port you are using. This is tested with the Pixfalcon!  You will have to create a serial cable with connects the ~~ESC connector J12~~ J13 to the serial output of the Pixfalcon (telem output).  This branch was tested on a quad in the lab  see video below.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=spBVfxyKi3Q&feature=youtu.be  Summary: 1) Flash this branch to Pixfalcon using make px4fmu_v2_default upload 2) Flash this branch onto the Snapdragon using the commands in the devguide 3) Push the startup scripts onto the Snapdragon (they have been modified)  4) Do the complete setup of the Pixfalcon via QGC as if you wanted it to fly the quad you are using. This is important because otherwise Pixfalcon will not arm and so no pwm is output. 5) Do the rc calibration on the Snapdragon after you have connected the system together.  6) Start mainapp on the snapdragon 7) Switch safety off on the Pixfalcon and try to arm the system via rc.

Title: WIP VTOL roll trim
Body: This adds a roll trim param to combat roll produced by the inertia of the pusher prop. Also  the scaling was removed for roll and pitch during transition in order to correctly apply these values.  With this param  and the already existing pitch trim the climbing and rolling during transition can be corrected. The roll trim will have to be set depending on the rotation direction of the pusher / puller. In SITL the following values produce a stable result; VT_FW_PITCH_TRIM: -0.25 VT_FW_ROLL_TRIM: 0.25  The MC  during transition blending does not have enough authority to correct roll and pitch and the FW is not yet in control to apply these corrections.  Setting the above values fixes https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/4079 Airframes should independently be analyzed for correct values. Roll should be set positive CCW pusher prop and negative with a CW pusher prop Pitch (in all the logs i have seen) always seems to angle up and therefor needs a negative value  I'm not sure if this is a permanent solution or if we should revisit the control authority of MC/FW during transitions.  @AndreasAntener @tumbili @LorenzMeier

Title: Sdlog2 on Snapdragon
Body: This adds sdlog2 to Snapdragon startup. It has been tested in-flight.  One current caveat is that the Snapdragon doesn't have a valid time on boot-up  and setting the time using GPS is not implemented yet. Therefore you end up with folders named sessXXX.

Title: Nuttx Update to 7 10 With Hard Fault Logging and lots more
Body: Hard Fault Logging  The PR uses a non volatile file system added to Nuttx  that is backed by the STM32's Battery backed up ram in the BKP (same as RTC) domain to store the data from a hard fault or an assertion failure and reboots the system.   On boot up  if there is valid hard fault data  it will be written to the micro SD card. Then the system will be re-armed to capture any new hard faults.   Fault logs capture the context of the CPU at the time of the failure.  They contain different information depending on the cause of the failure. Assertion or hardfault. The common elements of the fault log include the time and date of the fault  the type of the fault  and information about the build such as the git hash and build time and date.  For an assertion failure  the log will contain the file and line the assertion failed on and a dump of the users stack. For a hard fault failure the log will contain a copy of the users stack  the interrupt stack  and the processors registers.  Since we want to capture the initial cause of the failure  once a hard fault has been committed to BBSRAM it can will not be overwritten by a subsequent hard faults until it is rearmed.   The Normal path is Fault--Save to BBSRAM ---Reboot---Save to SD card -- Rearm--- boot --- run  ``` [boot] 4 Battery Backed Up File(s) [hardfault_log] Fault Log info File No 3 Length 3257 flags:0x00 state:0 [hardfault_log] Fault Logged on 2011-02-20-14:20:11 - Valid [hardfault_log] Saving Fault Log file /fs/microsd/fault_2011_02_20_14_20_11.log [hardfault_log] Fault Log is Armed [hardfault_log] Done saving Fault Log file ```  In the case that the system cannot save the fault data to permanent storage due to A) Infinite reboot loop or B) SDIO not mountable. The system will behave as follows: Reboots with a valid hard fault record in the non volatile file system are counted (also in a non volatile file). Once this count is greater than 2  it means we have rebooted before the Normal path above has completed and committed the fault log to the SD card. This implies that flight cannot be continued or resumed. Therefore on each boot  where there is a valid fault log in BBSRAM  with the count greater than 2 the fault log will be dumped to the debug console and the system will prompt with the menu shown below.  To retrieve the log  connect the debug terminal and re boot (If the count is less than  2: reboot with the space bar held down.)   The log will be output to the terminal. You will be presented with a menu:  ``` Enter B - Continue booting Enter C - Clear the fault log Enter D - Dump fault log ```  To recapture the log use D then C to rearm the system.  Debugging:  Debugging an unstable system that resets it's self can be a real pain!  GDB/JTag:  If you use a Jtag place a break point on up_assert to catch the hard fault or assertion before it is logged and the system rebooted in the call out to the `void board_crashdump(uint32_t currentsp  void *tcb  uint8_t *filename  int lineno)` located in px4fmu2_init.c Hint:If you set the pc = the lr you may be able to walk back up the stack to the code that caused the fault.  You may also place a break point on for `(int c ='>'; !dbgContinue; c= getchar())`  in px4fmu2_init.c and set dbgContinue = 1  to continue debugging.  Printf Debugging  On a debug console hold the space bar down at boot to see the debug output and stop a infinite reboot cycle.  How to use a fault log:  Assertion failure:  The line and file that the assertion failed at will be listed   ``` up_assert: Assertion failed at file:ystemcmds/hardfault_log/hardfault_log.c line: 118 task: hardfault_log up_dumpstate: sp:     20025e84 up_dumpstate: IRQ stack: up_dumpstate:   base: 20009d90 up_dumpstate:   size: 00000800 up_dumpstate:   used: 0000015c ```  Hard fault failure:  Use the comand arm-none-eabi-nm -n <path to from git hash listed in dump>/firmware.elf > fw.map  Use the value of the pc lr or values from the stacks to find the closest address in fw.map file.  ``` Type:Hard Fault in file:armv7-m/up_hardfault.c at line: 183 running task: hardfault_log  FW git-hash: db15eaa4a6a33fe02d336a75024d68d9de2ca19b  Build datetime: Mar  3 2015 16:23:42  Processor registers: from 0x20025dac  r0:0x00000000 r1:0x00000001  r2:0x00000000  r3:0xe000ed14  r4:0x00000000  r5:0x20005e48 r6:0x20025ef4 r7:0x00000003  r8:0x00000000 r9:0x00000000 r10:0x00000000 r11:0x00000000 r12:0x00000000  sp:0x20025e80 lr:0x0807e82b pc:0x08073c38  xpsr:0x41000000 basepri:0x000000f0 control:0x00000004  exe return:0xffffffe9  IRQ stack:   top:    0x20009d90   sp:     0x20009d34   bottom: 0x20009590   size:   0x00000800  User stack:   top:    0x20025ef0   sp:     0x20025e80   bottom: 0x20025b1c   size:   0x000003d4 ```  It is expected that there will be a tool that will automate the above-mentioned process.  This PR supersedes  https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/1758

The system will behave as follows: Reboots with a valid hard fault record in the non volatile file system are counted (also in a non volatile file). Once this count is greater than 2  it means we have rebooted before the Normal path above has completed and committed the fault log to the SD card. Title: New logger generate padding fields
Body: I propose an alternative to the serialization: add auto-generated padding fields to the struct where necessary (ie. for nested types).  Advantages: - only one memcpy necessary when logging a message - no code bloat with many auto-generated functions - automatic handling of (newly added) nested types in the message template  Padding is added at the end of each struct as well  which is needed for nested types. ATM this is logged as well  so that the readout still works. If we use this  we can cut these  so that there is only a small overhead in size for nested structs. This then requires the log reader to ignore padding bytes at the end of a struct format definition (if it is not used in a nested struct).  @dagar @kd0aij what do you think?  Tested on SITL & Pixracer.

Title: Eagle build cleanup
Body: While working on the RPi2 port  I found the Snapdragon build system to be quite confusing  so I decided to do some cleanup.  This PR removes the `Toolchain-arm-linux-gnueabihf.cmake` from `cmake/toolchains` and sets the build system to use it from `cmake_hexagon` (https://github.com/ATLFlight/cmake_hexagon/pull/1)  as proposed by @mcharleb in https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/4203  While not strictly required  this makes things a lot easier to understand  since "arm-linux-gnueabihf" encompasses _any_ ARM build like Odroid / RPi / Eagle.  Another alternative  if you don't want this would be to rename the current one to "Toolchain-arm-linux-gnueabihf-linaro" and add separate ones like "Toolchain-arm-linux-gnueabihf-raspbian".

Title: Adding LSM9DS1 BMI160 and LIS2HH12 sensors
Body: I tried to make LSM9DS1  BMI160 and LIS2HH12 compatible with PX4 project.  LSM9DS1/BMI160 driver is only prepared for the connection by SPI and LIS2HH12 only by I2C...  Now I'm facing 2 problems: 1) The BMI drivers is not working properly because it is slowing the PX4 performance and when I try to run LSM9DS1 at the same time  the autopilot crash. I'm guessing that it may be some configurations not well done but I'm working on it...  2) My purpose of adding this sensors is to use an IMU board with: - LSM9DS1 (MAG+GYRO+ACCEL); - BMI160     (GYRO+ACCEL); - MPU9250 (GYRO+ACCEL); - LIS2HH12 (ACCEL); - MS5611 (BARO).  Regarding this  I want to use 4 accelerometers at a time  but PX4 is only prepared for accepting 3. I've already tried to see some files that need to be changed  but no success.   I'd appreciate if you can hep me with this :)  Thanks

Title: cmake add fcheck new to cxx_compile_flags
Body: GCC assumes that operator new never returns null  but throws an exception instead. This is defined by the C++ standard  and thus ok. But we disable exceptions with -fno-exceptions  so we break this assumption. GCC then goes ahead and removes some of our nullptr checks. This flag removes the assumption.  This adds ~1.4kB to the binary size of the px4fmu-v4 target.  Fixes #4493

Title: WIP position control belnding during MC to FW transition for standard VTOL
Body: The current state of the transition is that we have a constant attitude setpoint (0 pitch/roll  fixed target heading as yaw) which comes naturally from a non-active MC position controller (disabled during the transition). The symptoms we see are the setpoint is not held properly (error too small) and it drifts off path. There are many ideas around on how this should be solved  so far I missed to provide the code for my own  so here it is ;)  I argue against "trims" on the actuator output level because they are impossible to set right and do not account for the changing dynamics during the transition.  How I would do it: - [x] Position on horizontal plane: use the FW position controller and start using rudder right from the beginning. - [ ] Altitude: have a mode in TECS where it is able to output a pitch setpoint with airspeed below the minimum  Notes on the implementation here: - yaw support in SITL doesn't yet work as it should - instead of adding yaw separately it should be added through the coordinated turn logic but maybe that is overdoing it - the use of rudder on the back transition needs to be validated

Title: Better granularity for flight failsafe modes
Body: @kd0aij Testing this with props off would be great. Main documentation:  ``` C++ /**  * Set data link loss failsafe mode  *  * The data link loss failsafe will only be entered after a timeout   * set by COM_RC_LOSS_T in seconds.  *  * @value 0 Disabled  * @value 1 Loiter  * @value 2 Return to Land  * @value 3 Land at current position  * @value 4 Outback Challenge (OBC) rules  *  * @group Mission  */ PARAM_DEFINE_INT32(NAV_DLL_ACT  0);  /**  * Set RC loss failsafe mode  *  * The RC loss failsafe will only be entered after a timeout   * set by COM_RC_LOSS_T in seconds. If the timeout value is smaller than  * zero it will never be entered. If RC input checks have been disabled  * by setting the COM_RC_IN_MODE param it will also not be triggered.  *  * @value 0 Disabled  * @value 1 Loiter  * @value 2 Return to Land  * @value 3 Land at current position  * @value 4 Outback Challenge (OBC) rules  *  * @group Mission  */ PARAM_DEFINE_INT32(NAV_RCL_ACT  0); ```  @DonLakeFlyer The comments above should also be enough to re-do the safety screen. I've broken the param system with this change  I need to think how we address that.

Title: FW generalize auto takeoff
Body: This PR refactors RunwayTakeoff to be used for all FW auto takeoff  which then simplifies the handling within the FW position controller.  This is based on the observation that hand launching larger aircraft require roughly the same phases as runway takeoff.  **ACCELERATE** (formerly CLAMPED_TO_RUNWAY for RunwayTakeoff) - no roll or pitch until min airspeed \* scaling is reached - fixed heading  **TAKEOFF** - no roll  small pitch until we have enough ground clearance - fixed heading  **CLIMBOUT** - roll constrained to MAX_ROLL while navigating to takeoff point  **FLY** - proceed to takeoff waypoint normally  All runway specific functionality should be encapsulated within the FixedwingTakeoff class  with the defaults being appropriate for hand launch.  There should be no change to runway takeoff other than renamed params. Existing auto takeoff for small aircraft should be roughly the same as they quickly hit min airspeed after a throw. They'll now have heading hold (while under climbout diff)  but that can be disabled. Hand launching larger heavier aircraft that require time to accelerate before climbout should be much more reliable with this change.  TODO - [x] match existing launch detection throttle behaviour - [x] test runway takeoff - [x] test hand launch - [ ] test hand launch with launchdetection - [ ] @AndreasAntener getYaw() takeoff in current heading direction idea - [x] modify navigator takeoff waypoint acceptance (see #3922) - [x] update airspeed setpoint to calculate_target_airspeed(mission_airspeed) after climbout  -closes issue #3812

Title: Motor ramp test app
Body: **WARNING: do not use this command unless you know exactly what you are doing  it will spin up all connected motors!**  This adds a new system command to do motor ramp tests. Based on bad experience with low KV quad setups we felt it is necessary to analyze this more closely. The issue with low KV setups is that you can easily over tune them and get props to stall. This app should accomplish 2 things: - clarify and quantify the problem - measure the limits of a specific system so we can tune it accordingly  If we understand the problem well enough we could then add protective measures  for example a PWM output slew rate limit.  TODO: - [x] safety: what kind of protective measures should still be built in here to prevent this from accidentally going off? (at least I'll take the same protection over from the esc_calib routine) - [x] sinus ramp: @tumbili

Title: Move __STDC_FORMAT_MACROS to build system
Body: __STDC_FORMAT_MACROS changes the behavior of inttypes.h to allow defining format macros for printf-like functions. It needs to be defined before any include is done  otherwise due to include chains and header guards it may not take effect.  Instead of having to define it everywhere it is used  move the define to the build system. Also update ecl and DriverFramework submodules to deal with the changed definitions.

Title: towards systemwide replay
Body: The following proposes a way to replay any part of the system  based on uORB topics. Replaying consists of 3 components: - a replay module - uORB publisher rules - time handling ## replay module  This is a separate module that loads an ULog file  applies the parameters from it (and optionally applies user-supplied parameters from another file) and then publishes all topics it finds in 'real-time'. It also adds a constant offset to the timestamp of each message to match the current system time. The log file name is supplied via an environment variable. ## uORB publisher rules  With a set of rules loaded from a file  the user can specify which part of the system should be replayed. In particular  the rules are fully integrated into orb and specify which module is allowed to publish which topics. This process is completely transparent for each publisher  so a publisher doesn't know (and doesn't need to know) that his messages are simply ignored. Here's an example:  ``` restrict_topics: sensor_combined  vehicle_gps_position  vehicle_land_detected module: replay ignore_others:true ```  It means the rules should be applied for the given topics and the `replay` module. Only the `replay` module is allowed to publish these topics. The `ignore_others:true` means that all other topics from the `replay` module should be ignored. This allows precisely which part of the system should be replayed. The rules are deliberately generic (they could be applied to another module as well)  but I didn't find another use-case yet. ## time handling  This point is still open. We want to be able to replay faster-than-real-time. For that we need to manipulate system time (`hrt_absolute_time()` and friends). I see two options: - replay as fast as possible - use a constant (maybe automatically set) speed-up factor  The first one is tricky  because we need to make sure no messages are lost. We could make orb synchronous  but this introduces lots of other problems such as deadlocks. So I tend towards the second. And then maybe report to the user  when the system starts to lose messages (i.e. replay is too fast). A solution to this is basically independent from replay and highly overlaps with gazebo time simulation  so we should find a solution that works for both. We need to identify which part of the system need the time  and in which way (like `hrt_absolute_time()`  clock  usleep  timeouts (like poll) etc). For some cases we don't want to speedup  for example status output every second or hardware access  like disk timeouts  and probably other cases. ## Workflow  A user wanting to replay has to: - record the necessary topics - setup orb publisher rules - optionally setup parameter overrides - optionally copy dataman mission file  if missions should be replayed - `export replay=<abs_file_to_ulg>` - build and run the target  The replay module has a `replay trystart` command  which checks if we want to replay (via env variable). If not in replay mode  it does nothing  so we can add it to the normal SITL startup script. We could even use the same cmake target  but we should at least use a separate build directory for two reasons: - the parameters from the replay file are stored in the SITL parameter's file. This can (and will) mess up normal SITL simulations. - uorb rules should only be applied in replay mode.  The method demands one restriction to replayed topics: all additional timestamps except for the auto-generated field must be relative (because the replay module only knows about one timestamp). This is doable but requires a bit of refactoring (quite a few topics have additional timestamps). At the same time this allows to save some space  because relative timestamps don't need to be stored with 64bits.  Then  multi-topics are handled properly  but it is currently required that all or no instance is replayed. Should this restriction become a problem  we can still change it in the future.  We should also think about whether we can simply apply all parameters from the log file. Certain values for some parameters might not make sense for a simulated system. ## test results  I tested to replay ekf2. However the topics contain additional timestamps. I just set them to the same time as the published topic. This is wrong of course and has an effect to the result  but the following shows that it basically works: Pixracer log: ![screenshot_ekf](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/281593/16042831/0069a080-323d-11e6-80ac-8f92bde72bae.png) Replayed log: ![screenshot_ekf_replayed](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/281593/16042830/00675ffa-323d-11e6-8ee1-b4e9b41b7f78.png) The replayed sensor values match exactly  and the estimated attitude at least look similar. We will have to see how it looks with proper timestamps.  If you want to test  you need to: - add `#define ORB_USE_PUBLISHER_RULES` to `src/modules/uORB/uORBManager.hpp` - setup publisher rules in `build_posix_sitl_default/src/firmware/posix/rootfs/orb_publisher.rules` file - make sure the replayed topics contain no other timestamps  or fix them. - `export replay=<abs_file_to_ulg>` - run sitl - `replay start`  Feedback  improvements & comments are welcome!

Title: more testing cleanup
Body: @LorenzMeier the overall goal is to have a single tests command that runs everywhere. I wanted to use a nice testing framework like gtest  doctest  check  etc  but they're actually quite difficult to get working on Nuttx. After wasting more time than I'd care to admit I decided PX4 unit_test and all of its boilerplate is good enough. - run `tests all` in posix_sitl on travis-ci - start moving unittests/ -> systemcmds/tests/ (we could probably entirely kill unittests/) - `tests all` now runs commander_tests  mavlink_tests  controllib_test  uorb_test - added `make quick_check` for developers to build common targets (pixhawk  pixracer  test  format) - start using unit_test for some tests - TODO: mavlink tests is broken everywhere

Title: RPi add clang clang check support
Body: This adds support for clang & clang-check. clang emits more friendly warnings. clang-check does static checking of compiled codes. The checker requires cmake to generate compile command database (compile_commands.json). Some of the warnings generated are not harmful  but things like buffer overflow and memory leak might be worth a look. And it seems to me that some are actually bugs.  To use clang with this PR  you need to set a environment variable RPI_USE_CLANG=1 and make a symbolic link of clang and clang++ into where your cross gcc is. You also need a symbolic link to clang-check for the check.
