Title: Crazyflie 2 Base Configuration Drivers
Body: Most of the drivers needed for running PX4 on the Crazyflie 2.0  Extension of the original work by Tim Dyer (see https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/px4users/vkyjs6nEzYY). - Complimentary boot loader : https://github.com/dennisss/Bootloader/tree/crazyflie2  The biggest update was integrating the upstream changes to the MPU9250 driver  so I'd like to see that part of this pull request go through to lock down the driver needed for the Crazyflie  Flashing strategy same as from original post: - Compile bootloader - Hold down power button while plugging in usb and hold for 5 seconds for DFU mode - Flash bootloader: `sudo dfu-util -d 0483:df11 -a 0 -s 0x08000000 -D crazyflie_bl.bin` - Flash firmware via bootloader as usual `make crazyflie_default upload` - Connect via USB to QGC  manually set SYS_AUTOSTART to 4900  What is working: - MTD parameter saving - MPU9250 I2C Mode   - Based heavily on the MPU6000 driver. The 9250 driver can now operate in both I2C and SPI mode   - When in I2C mode  MPU external I2C port bypassed to processor to allow other sensors to be easily connected (particularly the LPS25H) - Motor driver - LPS25H mostly functional  but needs some more work  What was tested: - MPU9250 on Crazyflie 2.0 and PixRacer   - Note: the PixRacer FMU driver is broken so won't work without integrating the upstream 8b66a764322d950d460d8c3257dc578c11bb90ee   - Crazyflie 2.0 tested with nshterm - Motor driver testable via command `crazyflie test`  What's left to be done: - Crazyflie not ready to fly yet - Integration with wireless NRF51 module on the Crazyflie  I'm looking forward to completing the wireless integration in the coming days. Any feedback is appreciated.

Title: Proposal to check code style a bit earlier
Body: I've separated the list of included modules to check code style so everyone can include it in their git pre-commit hook and run it for changed files only before the commit. This should get rid of these unnecessary "code style" commits at the end of a pull request.  Had to remove `-print0` from find  which should be fine as long as we don't have spaces in the paths.. Maybe a linux guru can suggest a way to keep `-print0` (and test this :)).  Once this is good I can followup with a quick doc in the devguide.  How-to  in your repositories:  ``` mv .git/hooks/pre-commit.sample .git/hooks/pre-commit chmod 755 .git/hooks/pre-commit ```  Then edit `.git/hooks/pre-commit` and replace the white-space check (yes  it also does that  ) at the end to:  ``` # If there are whitespace errors  print the offending file names and fail. git diff-index --check --cached $against -- if [ $? -ne 0 ] then         exit 1 fi  # Check for code style  only in changed files for i in `git diff --cached --name-only --diff-filter=ACM` do         ./Tools/files_to_check_code_style.sh $i | xargs -n 1 -P 8 -I % ./Tools/check_code_style.sh %         if [ $? -ne 0 ]         then                 exit 1         fi done ```  (see my complete pre-commit file: https://gist.github.com/AndreasAntener/0f9cc67cd4d4eb321f935297d9c268bd)

Title: add option for full attitude control and attitude sequencing in ACRO mode
Body: initial capability working in SITL. Roll and pitch flips are working  and there are no limitations on desired orientation. Currently  rate/duration commands are necessary to specify inverted orientations  **What's going on with code style?** I'm seeing many whitespace changes in commander.cpp  and all I'm doing is "Tools/fix_code_style".  The sequencer executes a series of rate  attitude and delay commands. Rate commands are the same as ACRO mode rate controls  and attitude commands specify a target orientation using Euler angles. All orientations are legal.   This is a 360 degree roll: ![roll_flip](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2300221/18399357/b6fd7e36-768d-11e6-8fdf-362dd22f7a4c.png)  and this is a "2 point" roll  with a pause at inverted: ![two_point_roll](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2300221/18399372/cb6a7cf2-768d-11e6-99d8-84a92832fe4e.png)

Title: Fix the multi target targets 5489
Body: On second thought  using % just isn't correct. When a make target looks like:  foo% bar%:     ...  Then that implies that it will build BOTH foo% and bar% whenever that rule is triggered (by either) for any value of the pattern %.  Clearly that is not what we want / intend.  So  this commit goes back to using config targets without a % in it by generating a full list of them.  It also turns sitl_deprecation into a Hidden Target.  Finally  now that we have those target lists anyway  I added a 'help' and 'list_config_targets' targets that print the available targets.

Title: Fix some pthread related linker stuff px4_os_add_flags
Body: The px4_os_add_flags defined in cmake/posix/px4_impl_posix.cmake did add (threading) libraries to added_exe_linker_flags  which subsequently end up in CMAKE_EXE_LINKER_FLAGS and then have no effect because those flags are passed to the linker before any of the object files and static libraries.  Those libraries are already added correctly in the corresponding src/firmware/*/CMakeLists.txt files (for qurt  nuttx AND posix).  I left in the non-library linker flag '-pthread' for the bebop board  although it seems very weird to me that this is needed (is it?). If that is needed then it seems weird to link manually (that is  src/firmware/*/CMakeLists.txt) with -lpthread.  For linux/g++ -pthread is added to the CXXFLAGS as it should be: this causes the compiler to define _REENTRANT which is needed for (the interface of) certain libraries to become thread-safe. Offically one also can just pass -pthread to the linker  which then causes the right libraries to be linked  but just linking with -lpthread -lm -lrt works too.  I ran into this while adding support for libcwd  which explicitly complains that _REENTRANT isn't defined when trying to link with the thread-safe version of libcwd (-lcwd_r) and then tells you to use -pthread.

Title: WIP XCode 8 Compatibility
Body: XCode 8 improves the POSIX compatibility of Mac OS and we take advantage of it and rip out some hackery we had been doing to make it compatible.

Title: add support for out of tree modules
Body: Add the possibility to build out-of-tree src modules via EXTERNAL_MODULES_LOCATION variable. Usage: - EXTERNAL_MODULES_LOCATION points to a directory with the same structure as Firmware (and thus contains a directory `src`) - copy an existing module (eg. examples/px4_simple_app) to the external directory - rename the module (including MODULE in CMakeLists.txt) or remove it from the existing Firmware cmake config. - add `$EXTERNAL_MODULES_LOCATION/CMakeLists.txt` with content:  ``` set(config_module_list_external     modules/<new_module>     PARENT_SCOPE     ) ``` - add a line `EXTERNAL` to the `modules/<new_module>/CMakeLists.txt` within `px4_add_module` - `make posix EXTERNAL_MODULES_LOCATION=<path>` (or just set the cmake variable in the build folder if a build already exists)

Title: Only optimize for size on NuttX
Body: With this change only builds for NuttX which are very much flash size constraint are optimized for size. All other builds (e.g. SITL  Snapdragon  etc.) are left at the default for debugging or -O2 for the usual use.  This addresses #4759. ## Build times ### POSIX:  -Os: `make posix 164.70s user 11.82s system 334% cpu 52.833 total`  -O2: `make posix 187.23s user 12.61s system 351% cpu 56.923 total`  (default no -O2  not in this PR): `make posix 115.52s user 11.32s system 337% cpu 37.601 total` ### QURT:  with -Os `make qurt_eagle_default  257.10s user 6.22s system 208% cpu 2:06.03 total`  -O2 `make qurt_eagle_default  245.09s user 5.87s system 221% cpu 1:53.15 total`  (default no -O2  not in this PR): `make qurt_eagle_default  98.16s user 5.94s system 341% cpu 30.496 total` ## size comparison: ### px4fmu-v2_default  before (-Os): `1018992 build_px4fmu-v2_default/src/firmware/nuttx/firmware_nuttx.bin`  after (-Os): `1018992 build_px4fmu-v2_default/src/firmware/nuttx/firmware_nuttx.bin`  Unfortunately  the changes here include the latest ecl submodule  so this can't be merged before the rest of ecl has been merged.

Title: Add wrapper for DF driver AK8963
Body: Add the DF wrapper for the AK8963 driver used on the Parrot Bebop. It also includes some adaptations to use the sensor calibration and the attitude estimation on the Bebop.  However  during testing there have been some problems with the precision of the compass calibration  resulting in a drifting yaw estimation. This needs some further improvements.

Title: Random things across the tree
Body: This includes fixes  performance improvement & cleanups. Most important: - save some CPU on posix by avoiding sending a thread signal all the time. - fix accelsim & lower it's update rate to 250Hz - fix preflight checks on linux (disable only on RPI as it was intended) - mavlink logging: always log the critical & emergency messages to the ulog file - fix symlink generation problem on RPI & Snapdragon - get rid of the many `oddly  ERROR is not defined for c++...` copies.

Title: add pci Bitcraze to px4_base cmake

Title: LPE switch to velocity based optical flow
Body: This switches LPE from treating optical flow as a position measurement and keeping the integrated state to just treating it as a velocity measurement.  This makes it work more easily with external vision measurements. I just flew this in position hold at 100 ft with only sonar  so it is very robust. I also manually increased the px4flow autoexposure maximum to get this kind of performance  for some reason the default is set very low.  I've also been flying this branch in gazebo simulations with external vision measurements and it works well.  @mhkabir probably will be useful to you

Title: Add pitch angle to AK8963 for Bebop
Body: On the Parrot Bebop  the magnetometer is mounted with a slight angle compared to the IMU  which caused an inaccurate sensor calibration. This PR rotates the sensor measurements accordingly and fixes #5571.  See #5236 for more details.

Title: MC pos control realize when we are on the trajectory but passed the target waypoint
Body: In the following mission https://gist.github.com/AndreasAntener/42eb7d7e777cff4baf0c0c01c3a5de4f the multicopter manages to fly 180 degrees into the wrong direction. This waypoint combination most likely never occurs for multicopters (discovered while analyzing #5270). However what happens is that the MC controller sees a previous and current setpoint where the previous setpoint is on the further end of the trajectory (viewed from the current position). The outcome is a target position setpoint on the trajectory into the direction from previous to current and therefore into the wrong direction. Should be investigated further having a second pair of eyes to look this over would be appreciated.

Title: Master dataman ram
Body: @LorenzMeier   This PR added the RAM based storage directly in dataman.   Ram usage is way too high!   ``` sercon: Registering CDC/ACM serial driver sercon: Successfully registered the CDC/ACM serial driver nsh: mount: mount failed: No such device nsh: mkfatfs: mkfatfs failed: No such device ERROR [mtd] MTD not enabled  skipping. WARN  [param] selected parameter default file /fs/microsd/params INFO  [dataman] Unkown restart  data manager RAM size is 103090 bytes WARN  [ms5611] no device on bus 1 ERROR [ms5611] driver start failed WARN  [hmc5883] no device on bus 2 WARN  [mpu6000] no device on bus 1 ERROR [sensors] no barometer found on /dev/baro0 (2) WARN  [sensors] FATAL: no accelerometer found: /dev/accel0 (2) WARN  [sensors] FATAL: no gyro found: /dev/gyro0 (2) WARN  [sensors] FATAL: no magnetometer found: /dev/mag0 (2) WARN  [sensors] FATAL: No barometer found: /dev/baro0 (2) ERROR [sensors] sensor initialization failed ERROR [sensors] no barometer found on /dev/baro0 (2) ERROR [sensors] no barometer found on /dev/baro0 (2) INFO  [init] Multicopter nsh: mixer: command not found ERROR [init] Error loading mixer: /etc/mixers/hexa_x.main.mix WARN  [ekf2] alloc failed ```  Please have a look at dataman.h    ``` /** The maximum number of instances for each item type */ enum {     DM_KEY_SAFE_POINTS_MAX = 8  #ifdef __cplusplus     DM_KEY_FENCE_POINTS_MAX = fence_s::GEOFENCE_MAX_VERTICES  #else     DM_KEY_FENCE_POINTS_MAX = GEOFENCE_MAX_VERTICES  #endif     DM_KEY_WAYPOINTS_OFFBOARD_0_MAX = NUM_MISSIONS_SUPPORTED      DM_KEY_WAYPOINTS_OFFBOARD_1_MAX = NUM_MISSIONS_SUPPORTED      DM_KEY_WAYPOINTS_ONBOARD_MAX = NUM_MISSIONS_SUPPORTED      DM_KEY_MISSION_STATE_MAX = 1 } ```  and suggest or commit the values that make sense and I can re-test.

The main reason why we do this is because the new logger app #4282 will log entire topics and so we don't want to burn the logging bandwidth on redundant data.  This needs review  testing in SITL and testing outdoors. At several locations code has been commented out. If we agree on the content of the attitude message then this code can be removed.

Title: Reduce the firmware binary size for Bebop
Body: The firmware binary is to large to fit into the onboard memory of the Parrot Bebop. It could be uploaded to the emmc  but for ease of use it would be nice to have it in /usr/bin.   The script `./Tools/adb_upload_to_bebop.sh` is called when `make posix_bebop_default upload` is executed. So  no additional manual actions are needed while the build still results in an unaltered executable  which could be uploaded by hand.   This corresponds to the solution proposed in #5675.

Title: WIP Mount and ROI implementation
Body: This is the second PR for the implementation of ROI and a new gimbal driver (see #4584) and depends on #4585.  It removes the old gimbal driver  and implements a new mount driver which is able to do the following: - control a gimbal via mavlink (based on the current ROI or aux channel input if enabled) - control a gimbal via rc (based on the current ROI or aux channel input if enabled) - control (and stabilize) a onboard mount (via `MAV_CMD_DO_MOUNT_CONTROL` or aux channel input if in `MAV_MOUNT_MODE_RC_TARGETING`)  ## Details about the components: #### MAVLINK mode  The MAVLINK mode is intended to talk to a mavlink capable mount (gimbal). In this mode  the mount driver simply takes the current ROI and sends out  `MAV_CMD_DO_MOUNT_CONTROL` and `MAV_CMD_DO_MOUNT_CONFIGURE` messages with the calculated angles to a gimbal controller that understands MavLink (like the Storm32 BGC). If the `MNT_MAN_CONTROL` parameter is set to 1 and there's no current ROI  the gimbal can also be controlled by the AUX channels (also set via parameters). ### RC mode  The RC mode is also intended for mounts (gimbals) that self stabilize on their own but don't communicate via MavLink  but take RC inputs (like the SimpleBGC  AlexMos  etc). In this mode  the mount driver also takes the current ROI (or as above  if none ROI and enabled  can be controlled via the AUX channels) and publishes its yaw  pitch and roll values on the `actuator_controls_3` topic to be used by a mixer. ### ONBOARD mode  The ONBOARD mode is intended for generic mounts (servo gimbals  antenna trackers  etc...)  that can optionally be stabilized by the driver itself using the autopilots sensors. Instead of listening to the current ROI  this mode listens on the vehicle_mount topic - and such will react to `MAV_CMD_DO_MOUNT_CONTROL` and `MAV_CMD_DO_MOUNT_CONFIGURE` COMMAND_LONG messages  which have the same sysid and compid as the PX4 itself. ## Progress: - [x] Implementation of the vehicle_mount topic and parsing of `MAV_CMD_DO_MOUNT_CONTROL` and `MAV_CMD_DO_MOUNT_CONFIGURE` - [x] Implementation of a gimbal mavlink driver - [x] Implementation of a gimbal rc driver - [x] Implementation of a generic mount driver - [x] Math for the pitch angle based on the vehicle_global location - [x] Verify pitch  roll and yaw are in the correct format (degrees) - [x] Implement manual control by AUX channels - [x] Mount override - [x] Parse CMD_DO_MOUNT_\* in mount.cpp instead of commander.cpp - [x] Updating parameters at runtime - [ ] Increase deamon priority? - [ ] Global retracts passthrough (via AUX) - even in idle? - [ ] Global mode override (via AUX) maybe? - [ ] Test Onboard   . [ ] Test Mavlink - [ ] Test RC - [ ] Test ROI performance  accuracy and correctness of calculations in the field - [ ] Create proper documentation

Title: Clean up of app h
Body: app.h  generated from app.h_in  has unnecessary code duplication and isn't a header file (it defines globals  static functions and doesn't have a header guard  moreover  it has a 'using namespace std;'). Because of this  a real headerfile that declares the stuff defined in apps.h was missing leading to even more code duplication: scattered forward declarations in .cpp files and an often repeated type of std::map<std::string  px4_main_t>.  This patch moves cmake/qurt/apps.h_in to src/platforms/apps.cpp.in (with some changes) and removes cmake/posix/apps.h_in. Then src/platforms/apps.cpp.in is split into src/platforms/apps.cpp.in and src/platforms/apps.h.in  splitting declarations from definitions.  A typedef is defined for the map (apps_map_type).  The main difference between cmake/posix/apps.h_in and cmake/qurt/apps.h_in was that the first defined a global 'apps'  while qurt stores the apps in QShell. I opted to get rid of the global variable (which are in general evil for various reasons) and used the API of cmake/qurt/apps.h_in where a provided 'apps' map is initialized with a call to init_app_map. Thus removing the existing code duplication.

Title: Graph based Return To Land
Body: The Return-To-Land mode now makes the vehicle return along the previously flown path. This way  crashes due to tall buildings can be avoided. The new RTL is based on a flight path tracker  which records the flight path as a graph.  The implementation was tested in unit tests (on PX4-FMUv4) and SITL  but no flight tests have been made yet. Some test paths in src/modules/navigator/navigator_tests are quite verbose  maybe I should remove them?  Memory and CPU usage depends heavily on the flight pattern. A 2-4kB bound should be sufficient for most cases. During tests  the most critical algorithm blocked the navigator for 300ms. This should not be an issue if the system behaves as designed  but we still may want to run this on a separate low-priority task instead.  The new RTL mode is now called RTLA while the old mode was renamed to RTLB and is used as a fallback for some failure modes. Also  a new RCRecover mode enables the vehicle to just return a few meters to regain a good signal. Someone with more experience with the system could integrate this such that it is invoked when needed. Changes to QGroundControl may be required to understand the new flight modes.

Title: Master can init
Body: Closes https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/5594#issuecomment-251978543 by allowing NuttX CAN eaxample. This however does not add __EXPORT as it is not required.   ```  The Nuttx CAN driver is not used with UAVCAN. However to facilitate compilation to allow the Nuttx CAN Example to be compiled and linked  the missing proto type was needed.  Futhermore to include the NuttX CAN eaxample the following changes are needed:  1 ) In cmake/configs/<target>.cmake Add can to config_extra_builtin_cmds as:  set(config_extra_builtin_cmds         serdis         sercon         can         )  Add: add_custom_target(can) set_target_properties(can PROPERTIES        PRIORITY "SCHED_PRIORITY_DEFAULT"        MAIN "can" STACK_MAIN "2048"        COMPILE_FLAGS "-Os")  2) Update the nuttx-configs/<target>/nsh/defconfig  Run make oldconfig and make menuconfig and set the follwoing: CONFIG_CAN=y CONFIG_STM32_CAN1=y or CONFIG_STM32_CAN2=y CONFIG_CAN_EXTID=y CONFIG_CAN1_BAUD=250000 CONFIG_CAN_FIFOSIZE=8 CONFIG_CAN_NPENDINGRTR=4 CONFIG_EXAMPLES_CAN=y ```

Title: Do not include headers inside __BEGIN_DECLS __END_DECLS blocks
Body: We don't have C++ unsafe headers (anymore).  I added a test to fix_headers.sh that checks if certain "unsafe" headers are ONLY included inside a __BEGIN_DECLS ... __END_DECLS (because after all  they are unsafe)  as well as checking that no other header files are included inside such a block. The rationale of the latter is that if a file is a C header and it declares function prototypes (otherwise it doesn't matter) and is sometimes included outside a __BEGIN_DECLS ... __END_DECLS block (from a C++ source file) then it has to be C++ safe and doesn't ever need to be included from inside such a block; while if a file is a C++ header then obviously it should never be included from such a block.  fix_headers.sh subsequently found several safe headers to be included from inside such a block  and those that were (apparently in the past) unsafe were included only sometimes inside such a block and often outside it. I had a look at those files and saw that at least an attempt has been made to make them C++ safe  but especially because they already are included OFTEN outside a __BEGIN_DECLS ... __END_DECLS (from C++ source files) the best decision seems to treat them as safe.  This is not risky: .c files that define such functions still generate C-linkage for their functions. If a C++ unsafe C header is included outside a __BEGIN_DECLS ... __END_DECLS block then the only possible result would be an undefined reference to a function with C++-linkage that will not exist. Aka  when something links after this commit  then the commit was correct. I did build all targets and they all linked.  PS I added v2.0/common/mavlink.h to "unsafe headers" in fix_headers.sh so that the script will leave the include at the bottom of src/modules/mavlink/mavlink_bridge_header.h alone (which must be included after the function prototypes above it). It isn't really unsafe either though ;)

Title: HIL SITL multirotor actuator range fixes
Body: Instead of sending actuator controls from -1..1 for SITL  we should send 0..1 like we already do for HIL. This will enable negative thrust in the future  e.g. for pusher props that spin backwards  or for vehicles with variable pitch propellers.  This resolves #5305.  This depends on https://github.com/PX4/jMAVSim/pull/45 and https://github.com/PX4/sitl_gazebo/pull/57  Please review @LorenzMeier.

Title: MindPX update
Body: We make some important improvement for MindPX hardware. Major changes include:                                       1. add RC input/SBUS/Spektrum/FrSky telemetry receiver IO hardware circuit                                      2. expand to 8 pwm outputs.  This PR is an adaptation to the new hardware.

Title: WIP Improved Navio PWM out use external mixer
Body: As stated in #5695  the output support on the RPi2/Navio2 is still very basic.    In order tackle this a little  I propose to use external mixers instead of the default multicopter mixer  such that Navio can also be used on other plattforms.  As I'm new to IO related things on PX4  I would be glad if I could already get some feedback on the changes.    Improvements/Changes:  - [x] uses default px4 mixer files  - [x] all actuator groups may be used in mixer file  - [x] baseline config for fw platforms  - [x] make command line option for mixer file    What still needs to be done  - [ ] use more of the existing params  - [ ] probably some more error handling

Title: Fix data loss in ekf2 and ekf2 replay and enable smaller buffers to reduce RAM
Body: Fixes a time stamping bug in the ekf2_replay app that could result in repeated mag and baro data being used.    Allows high rate magnetometer and baro data to be used without data loss by downsampling data using a running average if the data rate is too high. This will allow a smaller observation buffer size to be used on the ekf2 to save RAM by setting the delay parameters for all sensors not required to zero and tuning the remaining delay parameters using replay logs.    This has been tested on replay and flight (copter only) in combination with https://github.com/PX4/ecl/pull/213

Title: Fix incorrect MPU9250 device ID
Body: We propagate the bus parameters from the bus (SPI) interface to the sensor devices. Thus  the device ID of the sensor driver is set to the correct bus id and address. Otherwise it would be zero  which is an issue if several MPU9250s are running at the same time.    This fixes #6002. Due to the incorrect ID the calibration of the first sensor was also applied to the second sensor  which in turn caused the inconsistency for the acceleration and gyro sensors.    **Caution**: This will alter the MPU9250 device ID on all boards and lead to errors. The previous device is not found anymore and the calibration is not retrieved.    Please test on Pixhawk 2.1 to make sure that it works now  but also on other boards that use the MPU9250.

Title: Implement the way to run posix simulator directly from IDE without the need to reconfigure command lines but use runner created via CMake
Body: What these changes do:  In addition to the existing cmake targets that run `sitl_run.sh` with parameters for px4 to load correct model it creates a `launcher` targets named `px4_<mode>` that is a `thin wrapper` around original sitl px4 app. This `thin wrapper` simply embeds app arguments like current working directories and path to the model file.    How to use it:   * Run gazebo (or any other sim) server and client viewers via the terminal: `make posix_sitl_default gazebo_none_ide`   * In your IDE select `px4_<mode>` target you want to debug (e.g. `px4_iris`)   * Start debug session directly from IDE    This approach significantly reduces the debug cycle time because simulator (e.g. gazebo) is always running in background and you only re-run px4 process which is very light.

It also retains the PWM pulsewidth-space definition of trim  and sets the default to 1500  but that should perhaps change to the normalized [-1 1] range.

Title: Config prune

Title: cmake fix update of git hashes
Body: Since the git hashes were being generate by cmake it would only be  generated if the header file was not present. Simple test:        $ make aerofc-v1_default      $ touch a      $ git add a      $ git commit -m tmp      $ make aerofc-v1_default    The file build_aerofc-v1_default/build_git_version.h should have the new  hashes and the correspondent .c/c.pp files should be rebuilt  but they  aren't.  The end result is that checking the version with "ver git" in  the nsh console will point to the wrong commit.    This moves the generation of the header to a separate tool and enforces  the command to be executed every time.

Title: Simulation fixes for fleet mostly VTOL
Body: @AndreasAntener @tumbili @sanderux @dagar The models in SITL seemed mostly unusable. I've fixed a number of issues with them and the flight performance improved significantly (from unusable to reasonably realistic). Cross-testing  in particular under joystick control  would be most appreciated.    And Merry Christmas! I guess this is my gift for the PX4 VTOL developers.    Note that the control gains and stall speeds became more realistic with these fixes. That's a good hint towards things going into the right direction.

Title: Simulation Fixes for SITL SOLO VTOL and CI
Body: Assorted fixes from a complete validation pass through SITL and CI. We need to make sure performance issues like this one get raised earlier. @dagar @tumbili @sanderux Please make sure to be vocal if the development environment deteriorates. SITL *MUST BE RELIABLE* and if its not then its broken and has to be fixed immediately.    The assumption that its not a complete replacement for a flight simulator is very wrong  except for corner cases of fixed wing control. But for the level of sophistication of our current controllers its more than enough and if its not working for you it has to be fixed. Moving to HITL is a really bad replacement  except for testing of the HW itself.

Title: Nuttx v3 nuttx_next_cmake merged latest master
Body: This PR is a merge of the latest master (see below) via merges and cherry-picking in preparation for replacing master.    Current as of: 29550a4cee5618e3508f0d8dfa97bcbedece30da      This PR will superceed https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/tree/nuttx_next_cmake     **N.B. RAN OUT OF CODE SPACE**   commits:    1.c7db20e removes LPE    esc35-v1 bootloader has been added. (the app - esc35-v1_default) is not tested - Do not use it!    The following are turned off on px4fmu-v2  new logger  drivers/lis3mdl  drivers/blinkm    # Testing nuttx_next    ## Checking out the source    The upstream Nuttx GIT structure  and hence nuttx_v3  is different from Firmware/master 's Nuttx structure.     When switching from master to nuttx_v3 use the following commands:  ```  git submodule sync --recursive && git submodule update --init --recursive  make clean  ```    When switching from nuttx_v3 to master use the following commands:  ```  rm -fr NuttX  git submodule sync --recursive && git submodule update --init --recursive  make clean  ```    ## Building    ### Compiler    ```  arm-none-eabi-gcc (GNU Tools for ARM Embedded Processors) 5.4.1 20160609 (release) [ARM/embedded-5-branch revision 237715]  Copyright (C) 2015 Free Software Foundation  Inc.  This is free software; see the source for copying conditions.  There is NO  warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  ```    ``` make px4fmu-v2_default upload```    ## Building with upload    ``` make px4fmu-v2_default upload```    ## Building other targets    use ``` make list_config_targets```    to list the additional targets. N.B .Omit ```[nuttx_]``` from the build command.

Title: mc_att_control conversion to control lib
Body: This is a simple  concise replacement for mc_att_control  tested in sitl full auto as well as manual flight so far. It uses controllib and matrix and accomplishes the same task in 1/3 of the code. The math model behind it is also more standard and easy to write down. Whatever was going on with the quaternion error formulation and mixing between two different rotation mechanisms seemed like it was overthinking it to me. This just uses euler angles and flies better in my opinion.

Title: Param find macro
Body: This pull request adds a macro for looking up parameter handles instead of doing a string lookup. The main advantage of this is that parameters that there is now the ability to have a compile time check for if a parameter exists in the build. This is now possible since the parameter order is known at compile time as of #6254.    The number of `param_find()` function calls will now go down to items requested externally by string (i.e. over mavlink)  strings generated in loops (like when using scanf)  and when needing to handle the possibility of a parameter not existing. Additionally  there should also be a boot time speed up  as much less `param_find()` functions are called.    List of changes:  * Generate the parameter handles at compile time  * Add a `PARAM_FIND` macro for getting the handle directly  * Changed most `param_find()` function calls to `PARAM_FIND()` macro calls  * Moved ATT_VIBE_THRESH and SDLOG_UTC_OFFSET parameters to more appropriate modules  * msg_gen now depends on param_gen as a result of systemlib/param/param.h now including the generated px4_parameters.h    Keeping track of which parameters are used will now only work with string lookups. Does this still make sense to keep that? Could a script accomplish something similar?    I've only built the px4fmu_v4-default  px4fmu_v2-default  and the SITL builds so far. More tweaks will probably be required with the other builds.

Title: FMUv5 Fixed hardfault log

Title: Optical flow preparation for Parrot Bebop 2
Body: This PR adds the camera interface for an optical flow computation on Parrot Bebop 2. The module wraps the MT9V117 image sensor (see PX4/DriverFramework#175) and adds a V4L2 interface.     The driver can be tested with: `bebop_flow trigger -n 10`. The command saves the next 10 frames as pgm files in `/home/root/images`. The camera runs at 90 fps and has a frame size of 320x240.

Title: WIP Driver Bebop 2 ultrasonic rangefinder
Body: This adds the wrapper to the driver in DF and belongs to  PX4/DriverFramework#167. The driver is basically finished but requires some integration and further testing.    The main issue is caused by the integration with EKF2. The sensor has a block distance by design and when the quadcopter is on the ground  the sensor cannot measure something reasonable. Yet  if the EKF2 does not receive valid measurements  it will not fully initialize which in turn prevents us from taking off. The driver currently publishes a distance of -1.0 when it is within the block distance.    Moreover  the estimation jumps when transitioning between block distance and valid measurement distance.

Body: @LorenzMeier     This fixes 2 nastys!     This prevents the meta value of 0 => not used from being passed to px4_arch_configgpio. As this would map to PORTA|PIN0 and mess up other inits like using UART4 for a console.

Title: Add compensation for IMU and Barometer thermal drift
Body: Draft implementation for comment and review.    See https://docs.google.com/document/d/1GHzjsPTfSUAxYGPNlXSL7FYkxFcq76jTfsaquc57Rww for previous discussion.    A separate PR's will be submitted for the on-board logging and calibration function.    TODO:    Assignment of unique ID's to baro sensors to enable multiple Baros to be used with calibration.  Better method of assigning unique ID's to gyro and accel sensors.

Title: simulator Do not kill every process with string px4 in the name
Body: This is a follow-up PR from https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/6319

Body: This pulls out board specifics from the MTD driver and puts it into the board config (where it belongs).

Body: @ChristophTobler Please continue here. @eyeam3 FYI.

Title: AeroFC stuck in Hard fault that were not committed to disk
Body: I know that I should not change defconfig by hand but there is too many changes doing so that I will do it in another PR after validate that AeroFC is correctly working after Nuttx update.

Title: MC rate ctrl sync
Body: @priseborough I continued your PR here.

Title: Expunge hardware HW CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_xxx ifdefs
Body: @LorenzMeier     This is ready to go. It expunges the majority of the hardware HW CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_xxx ifdefs.    Note:    1.  Other than the Search path c6b96e1 I did not affect the px4io HW dependencies as these seem just.   2.  I did not affect the px4iofirmware HW dependencies as these seem also proper.   3. Would likes some guidence on the LED usage [here](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/commander/commander.cpp#L3200)  4. Posix derived builds now have a consistent presence  in src/drivers/boards/ [see] https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/6384/commits/406c3a363a4b2c5fe11e20f28dc56752f33e861f  5. @julianoes  @mcharleb Would you please run the non Nuttx Builds?  I found some oddities in the non Nuttx builds wrt CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_xxxx     The following build time defines for RPI for example   ```  -DCONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_RPI   -DMODULE_NAME=\"ver\"   -DPX4_MAIN=ver_app_main   -D__DF_LINUX   -D__PX4_LINUX   -D__PX4_POSIX   -D__PX4_POSIX_RPI   -D__STDC_FORMAT_MACROS   ```  defines __PX4_LINUX that then defines CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_SITL [here](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/platforms/px4_config.h#L55) in addtion to CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_RPI     This would then have consequences on the use pattern of #ifdef and #elif would have priority  ```  #ifdef CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_SITL   yada  #endif    #ifdef CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_RPI   yada  #elif CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_SITIL  #endif  ```

Title: Onboard Temperature Calibration WIP
Body: Temperature Calibration Scheme for calibrating sensors. The module will be running onboard and processing data realtime.    #### TODOs:  Parameters for post and pre calibration stage not yet saved  add mechanism to store them.  Currently only gyro  include accel and baro.  Integrate with Events interface    #### Current Results:  Gyro Temperature Cal Temperature vs Gyro Bias plots (Temperature is on reference offset scale):  ![gyro0_x](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5697288/22174650/b99b6852-e009-11e6-92a5-2f25ddebaee9.jpg)  ![gyro0_y](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5697288/22174651/bdab91d8-e009-11e6-9d3c-1061ec26796e.jpg)  ![gyro0_z](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5697288/22174653/c111f448-e009-11e6-9ab9-ecfe34c9a63f.jpg)      `tempcal start` inside nsh will kick off temperature cal.

Title: Master hal version
Body: @LorenzMeier     This one moves the mcu_version to the common board API

Title: cmake nuttx binary naming fix
Body: @LorenzMeier - With this PR the nuttx binaries (.px4) are now named in the same form QGC expects for S3. For example px4fmu-v2_default is now named `px4fmu-v2_default.px4` instead of `nuttx-px4fmu-v2-default.px4` which was then erroneously renamed to `px4fmu-v2-default.px4`.    The naming of the binaries uploaded to S3 for QGC has been wrong for about 2 weeks now. Dashes instead of underscores.

Title: Astyle update to v2 06
Body: Updated docker image with v2.06 likely won't be available for another hour or so.

Title: WIP Send more data frsky telemetry
Body: I've been working on this the last couple of days and managed to implement the sending of all kinds of data that might be useful to be displayed on a sPort and openTX 2.2 compatible radio either by itself  or via scripts (like my https://github.com/thedevleon/PixPilot  which is also still heavily WIP)  New data that will be sent: - Acceleration in X Y and Z - Arming State - Attitude Roll  Pitch and Yaw - Mission current & reached sequence as well as it's status - Mavlink Messages - Average Cells Voltage - GPS Time and Date  This includes a couple of fixes as well I made as I got more familiar with how opentx handles telemetry. - all data values should now be sent correctly (like acceleration  gps date and time  and more) - corrected frequencies for sending data - instead of offsetting the nav_state by 128  I offset all the sensor id's for PX4 by 128. That way 0-128 can be used by ardupilot and we use 128-255  and we have the full range of the uint32_t because there is no further offsets.  This is still WIP - I'm looking for feedback if there is anything else that should be sent.  The DIY values all require OpenTX 2.2 of course. For reference on how to use these  please take a look at these links: - https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/4349 - https://github.com/opentx/opentx/pull/3326 - https://github.com/opentx/opentx/pull/3426 #### Progress: - [x] add and verify id's for wanted data - [x] functions for wanted data - [x] verify receiving of wanted data - [x] implement sending of mavlink messages - [ ] verify correct format of values and display in opentx

Title: MPU6000 check against device_type
Body: Fixes the following case: a board that has several bus_options enabled   and wants to start a specific device (eg mpu6000 -T 20608 start). In that  case the given device_type is never actually checked  and since the start  routine iterates over all bus_options  several can match  and thus start  multiple instances of the driver (note that the whoami check is performed  against the value provided with -T and thus the check will pass).    It happens on Pixracer (PX4_SPIDEV_MPU and PX4_SPIDEV_ICM_20608 are both set).    This is a short-term fix  @davids5 plans to refactor the whole board sensor config & initialization.    @davids5 I set `PX4_SPI_BUS_EXTERNAL` to `MPU_DEVICE_TYPE_MPU6000`  which is only used by px4fmu-v5. Please make sure this is correct.    Fixes #6449    Start output is now not duplicated anymore:  ```  HMC5883_SPI on SPI bus 1 at 5 (11000 KHz)  MPU6000 on SPI bus 1 at 6 (1000 KHz)  MPU9250 on SPI bus 1 at 4 (1000 KHz)  ```  As a comparison  this is the output of an older Pixracer I have:  ```  HMC5883_SPI on SPI bus 1 at 5 (11000 KHz)  WARN  [hmc5883] no device on bus 1 (type: 3)  WARN  [mpu6000] no device on bus 3  MPU9250 on SPI bus 1 at 4 (1000 KHz)  ```    The start failure of hmc5883 and ICM-20608 can be explained by the lack of the physical chips (on the right):    ![20170131_093839](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/281593/22457729/5e8c3f62-e799-11e6-9fe2-9d62143cf0a5.jpg)

Title: Use wild card _PX4_ for upload
Body: Compliments the Bootloader change to simplify the ripple effect on the tools  we will be using  /dev/serial/by-id/*_PX4_* to locate PX4 devices. Therefore  moving forward all Bootloaders must contain the prefix "PX4 BL "  in the USBDEVICESTRING

Title: Thermal calibration updates
Body: - fixes problem introduced in https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/6497/commits/24eb72e1ce199909c99c464758bcab178aa1451e  - notifies system after param reset before starting temp calibration  - more refactoring to reduce code duplication    Follow-up to #6497    @priseborough

Title: Commander Switch system off if in undervoltage condition and disarmed
Body: This is necessary to not have systems deep-discharge the battery while sitting idle. While at it we also deny arming in low battery conditions to ensure people who just landed with a low battery do not take off again and fail to get a successful RTL.

Title: Remove the notion of legacy from the api and save some FLASH space too
Body: @LorenzMeier     This remove the notion of legacy from the api. The board level code  will perform the translation to legacy format on the STM32.  New targets will not need to do this as there is no case where the serial number were used by mfg for tracking.    It maintains the legacy incorrect selection of significant digits of the UUID in the PX4 code base.  This is done to avoid the ripple effects changing the IDs used on STM32 base platforms. [See] (https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/commit/f126668dbd41f10667a8759be7937dd822549828#diff-8da0cce1d272772f52e0d92c6f4343a5R83)

Title: Camera trigger updates
Body: - enable & build `camera_trigger` module for SITL for basic testing  - forward camera triggering via MAVLink    Fixes https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/6520

Title: PX4FMU V4PRO support
Body: This pull request brings changes for px4fmu-v4pro :     - correct RAM size for new processor (critical)  - correct GPIO logic for power supply sensing  - new chip select for temperature calibration EEPROM  - changes in the LIS3MDL driver    To be discussed : "artificial" rotations have been removed from the LIS3MDL driver. The aim here is to only use startup script with the "-R" option in order to correct the orientation between sensor's own orientation and autopilot's orientation.

Title: Fix AUAV X2 1 Board Config for 20608
Body: These changes were required to fix support for the ICM-20608 after this commit:   https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/commit/f746141afe3499ae56e75b3db06409381ead2f4b    This has been tested!

Title: Add support for the ICM 20602 to the Pixracer FMUv4
Body: The current ICM-20608 is nearing EOL.  I have tested on both ICM-20608 and ICM-20602 based Pixracers.

Title: Add support for the ICM 20602 to the Pixracer FMUv4
Body: The current ICM-20608 is nearing EOL. The ICM-20602 is pin compatible with the ICM-20608  only a minor software change is required to support either chip in the same physical location.    I have tested on both ICM-20608 and ICM-20602 based Pixracers.

Title: Master
Body: ADD MPU_WHOAMI_9250 MACRON DEFINITION TO SUPPORT REAL MPU9250  ADD __DF_RPI_SINGLE DEFINITION TO SUPPORT RASPBERRY PI alone (without navio or pxfmini )

Title: px_uploader multiple baud rates
Body: This doesn't change the default baud rate yet since it's not clear what baud rate will be set.  However it enables easier migration from one version to another that has a different baud rate set.

Title: Make cmake default config only an alias and cleanup param scope processing
Body: This improves the organization of the cmake configs for posix_sitl and nuttx_px4fmu-v2  so that the default config now is just an alias and all common files are in _common.cmake.    I needed this so when testing me PR I can switch default easily to IEKF from EKF2 so I can test my builds work without modifying the ekf2 config which was hard for me to maintain.

Title: Param add locking
Body: This adds locking to the param module.    We need to protect access to the param_values array. This is dynamically  allocated and resized (utarray_reserve() calls realloc). If some thread  was iterating the array while another was resizing the array  the first one  would iterate on a freed array  thus accessing invalid memory.    On NuttX this could lead to hardfaults in rare conditions.    @davids5 This also adds locking to the flash-based params. Can you please test that I called `param_init` everywhere where needed? I checked where `hrt_init` was called and compared that against the cmake config's that enable the `param` module.    @Stifael can you please test this on Snappy?    I tested on Posix & Pixracer.    This could be implemented more efficiently if we had atomic variables.

Title: WIP LPE Q config for racers with no GPS or compass
Body: This is the 6DOF acro PR https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/5498 rebased onto release 1.5.2  with a new config for SITL and flight performance testing.    SITL results are looking very good with reduced accel weight  but the simulated gyros probably don't exhibit drift or noise  so flight testing (and perhaps simulator enhancement) is still required.

Title: Stable
Body: In Firmware/src/lib/DriverFramework/drivers/mpu9250/mpu9250.hpp   line 196  add the definition  **`#define MPU_WHOAMI_9250_REAL 0x73`**      In Firmware/src/lib/DriverFramework/drivers/mpu9250/mpu9250.cpp  line 278   change the WHO_AM_I verification . I purchase the MPU9250 sensor in china.  The WHO_AM_I value of the sensor is 0x73.  I think maybe 0x71 is the value for mpu9150.  **`if (!(MPU_WHOAMI_9250==sensor_id || MPU_WHOAMI_9250_REAL==sensor_id )) `**      add new drivers and cmake configs for raspberry pi.  In Firmware/src/drivers/rpi_rc_in.    **Both 8 channel ppm encode and 8 chanel revicer are required**    You can decode the ppm by rpi directly .  The driver has been tested   you can click the following link to see the video of testing  http://player.youku.com/player.php/sid/XMjUxMzczNTEzMg==/v.swf     All of the codes are in the attachment.  Plean click the following link. Thanks    [Firmware.zip](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/files/778952/Firmware.zip)

Title: Add fast EKF2 replay for ulog
Body: This adds the ekf2 replay functionality from sdlog2 to the new logger. There were some tweaks necessary  for instance timestamp manipulations  and the logger cannot use usleep because of the fast replay.  In my tests (with a pixracer) I got reproducible results.    The logging rate drastically increases due to the ekf2_replay topic from ~60kb/s to 115kb/s when setting `EKF2_REC_RPL`. We can reduce this topic to only the timestamps  such that it can be logged by default. I'll probably do that in a follow-up PR so this can already be reviewed  tested and/or merged in the current state.    I also needed to increase the number of file descriptors because we log more topics.    #### Usage  - as usual  set `EKF2_REC_RPL` to 1  use the new logger (and potentially set `SDLOG_MODE` to 1 to start log from boot)  - record a log  - To replay:  ```  export replay_mode=ekf2  export replay=<abs_path_to_log.ulg>  make posix none  ```  You can stop it after there's an output like:  ```  INFO  [replay] Replay done (published 9917 msgs  2.136 s)  ```    As usual  the parameters can be adjusted. The params from the log can be extracted with (install pyulog with `sudo pip install pyulog` first):  ```  ulog_params $replay -d ' ' | grep -e '^EKF2' > build_posix_sitl_default_replay/tmp/rootfs/replay_params.txt  ```    The location of the newly generated log is also printed with something like:  ```  INFO  [logger] Opened log file: rootfs/fs/microsd/log/2017-03-01/13_30_51_replayed.ulg  ```    @tumbili @priseborough please review & test    @mhkabir The first commit fixes the vision topics. Fixes https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/6701

Title: Fix HIL mode
Body: HIL mode is currently broken in several ways:  - mc_att_control listened directly to the gyro topic  but in HIL mode  both mavlink and the sensor driver(s) published this topic on the same instance.  - CPU was always at 100% (which explains the purple blinking LED)  - thermal compensation was applied even in HIL mode    This changes the following:  - let mavlink only publish the raw sensors topics  which is then handled in `sensors`  which in turn publishes `sensor_combined` as usual  - make sure no sensor driver starts in HIL mode to avoid publication interference  - don't apply thermal corrections in HIL mode    With these changes the CPU was still >90%  and the drone flew very unstable. It turns out that jMAVSim uses a default update rate of 500Hz  which means the system would run at 500Hz as well. I tested with a rate of 300 and 250 Hz (see command below)  and in both cases the drone flies stable. We may need to change the default in jMAVSim.    The CPU usage was still very high  but it may not be representative as I had to use a different mavlink port to run the tests (my USB UART connection on the laptop is flaky).    To test:  `  ./Tools/jmavsim_run.sh -q -d /dev/ttyACM0 -b 921600 -r 250  `    @gamoreno can you test this?    @clovett @julianoes  fyi

Title: Hil refinements
Body: - avoid some warnings in HIL mode  increase the sensor timeout  - remove unneeded code in state_machine_helper  - add a HIL config for RPI (did not fly stable because I used it over WiFi)    edit: HIL works fine on the RPi when using a LAN cable

Title: Remove sensors init
Body: The initialization code is redundant and incomplete (only the first sensor  is done). I verified that all drivers already set this on startup.  For the mags  they all set their maximum supported update rate.  For the baro  the call (in sensor init) can silently fail  as for example the MS5611 which  does not support 150Hz update. But it also sets the maximum in  initialization.    Tested on Pixhawk & pixracer.

Title: cmake fmu v3 fix and enable more examples
Body: This enables all the examples in the px4fmu-v3_default and posix_sitl_default configs (#6667).    I've synced posix_sitl_default  px4fmu-v4pro and px4fmu-v5 with px4fmu-v3_default so that we can try and keep the driver and module availability consistent. I've left the more widely deployed configs alone.  For example the sf1xx and iridium drivers weren't included in the new configs. I simply sorted the lists and added what was missing.       - fixes #6667

Title: Only Compile and create dependencies for the Messages specified in ms
Body: g/CMakeLists.txt  this lets a user select what msgs should be compiled for his project Care must be taken though  to compile all orb_topcis that are required by the Rest of the Code. Otherwise many compile errors will occur.  This commits adds by default the ./msg include path to reference to other msgs. if an exisiting msg is used in another msg.

Title: Work in Progress Nxphlite v1
Body: This is a WIP for the NXP flight V1 HW based on the K64. It builds but it very memory constrained and incomplete as it is missing key Nuttx support in the Kinetis architecture.  The drivers/kinetis/\* is just stubbed out. There is no HRT or SPI.  Missing Components - [x]  FPU support in the OS - [ ] DMA - [ ] SPI - stubbed kinetis_spibus_initialize(int bus); - [ ] CAN - [ ] VBAT - for bootloader app commnincation. - [ ] Timers PIT  LPTM  and FTM  PDB - for pwm  capture  tones  and hrt. - [ ] RESET up_systemreset(void) noreturn_function;      Incomplete Drivers: - [ ] PWM supports only 1 chan per timer. - [ ] USB - [ ] UART lacking DMA kinetis_serial_dma_poll(void) - [ ] TERMIOS for serial - [ ] RTC - up_rtc_getdatetime  OS/System dependant SW - [x] Cannot use FPU yet on kinetis - [ ] Termios - [ ] tcgetattr - [ ] tcsetattr - [ ] cfsetspeed  PX4 FMUV2 Modules removed from build due to No External SPI - [ ] drivers/bma180 - [ ] drivers/bmi160      NOT Portable YET - [ ] /Firmware/src/modules/systemlib/mcu_version.c - [ ] drivers/pwm_input - [ ] drivers/test_ppm - [ ] systemcmds/hardfault_log - needs bsram - [ ] modules/uavcan - [ ] uavcan - [ ] uavcan_stm32_driver - need Kinetis CAN driver  PX4 Drivers Needing porting - [ ] drivers/kinetis/* - [ ] drv_hrt.c - [ ] drv_input_capture.c - [ ] drv_io_timer.c - [ ] drv_led_pwm.cpp - [ ] drv_pwm_servo.c - [ ] drivers/kinetis/adc - [ ] drivers/kinetis/tone_alarm

Title: Intel Aero Set correct ESC mode
Body: @ChristophTobler @bkueng I've set the correct ESC mode here and we should test this Monday including some position control tuning. @zehortigoza @lucasdemarchi Here is what I expect a final tune should get close to:    ```  # pitch angle & rate setting  param set MC_PITCHRATE_P 0.142  param set MC_PITCHRATE_I 0.05  param set MC_PITCHRATE_D 0.001  param set MC_PITCHRATE_MAX 360.0  param set MC_PITCH_P 6    # roll angle & rate setting  param set MC_ROLLRATE_P 0.142  param set MC_ROLLRATE_I 0.05  param set MC_ROLLRATE_D 0.001  param set MC_ROLLRATE_MAX 360.0  param set MC_ROLL_P 6    # yaw angle & rate setting close to defaults    # hover thrust  param set MPC_THR_HOVER 0.5    # Position control parameters  param set MPC_XY_VEL_P 0.14  param set MPC_Z_VEL_P 0.39  param set MPC_XY_P 1.2  param set MPC_Z_P 1.5    # Position control velocity  param set MPC_XY_CRUISE 8.0  param set MPC_XY_VEL_MAX 12.0  param set MPC_Z_VEL_MAX_UP 3.0  param set MPC_Z_VEL_MAX 2.0  param set MPC_Z_VEL_MAX_DN 2.0  param set MPC_LAND_SPEED 0.8    # throttle pid attenuation  param set MC_TPA_RATE_P 0.4  param set MC_TPA_RATE_I 0.5  param set MC_TPA_RATE_D 0.2  param set MC_TPA_BREAK_P 0.65  param set MC_TPA_BREAK_I 0.6  param set MC_TPA_BREAK_D 0.65  ```

Title: LPE fault relaxation and sitl fix
Body: Closes #6140.    @Stifael please test.    I was able to reproduce drift when the fuse gps flag was set to off. This occurred since the standard iris config for LPE didn't set the param and if you run the  "make posix_sitl_default gazebo_iris_opt_flow" followed by "make posix_sitl_default gazebo_iris" Then the iris without flow and with gps will have flow enabled and gps disabled. It will still take off due to the land detector correction  but then drift since it doesn't have a valid position measurement anymore.

"pwm rate -g N -r 0" sets channel group N (timer N) to oneshot mode    Flight tested on PixRacer (see #6608) only bench tested on auav-x21 (with PX4IO)  Jitter is worse on IO  probably due to timing of serial comms between FMU and IO.    - [x] flight test oneshot mode on fmu-v4  - [ ] flight test oneshot mode on fmu-v2/v3 or auav-x21  - [ ] regression testing of normal PWM modes

Title: UAVCAN performance audit
Body: I will be logging my efforts to improve the UAVCAN driver  especially in the sense of CPU load  in this pull request. Please do not merge it yet.    Considerable time has been spent on my fruitless attempts to squeeze the driver into the FMUv2 build by switching some optimization flags and removing some not-so-critical components. Unfortunately  during my experiments the system tended to either overflow ROM  fail in a confusing way during boot  or just refuse to perform basic functions such as connecting to QGC. At some point I gave up (with much regret) and replaced FMUv2 with FMUv4.    According to the reports from @LorenzMeier  a system consisting of Zubax GNSS + a Sapog ESC + FMUv1 creates a 12% CPU load in the UAVCAN driver. I am observing a slightly different number of 7.6% with my FMUv4 setup  perhaps the difference can be explained by a higher clock rate of the newer board.    Looking at the CAN bus traffic I noticed that the ESC command messages carry six values  whereas my setup requires only four. It turned out that the default CAN quadrotor mixer is configured to generate 6 outputs rather than 4  the extra 2 serving some obscure purpose I couldn't understand. In order to validate this  I defined a new mixer and made the CAN quadrotor vehicle config refer to it. Expectedly  this change reduced the number of values per command message from 6 to 4  which allowed the UAVCAN stack to send only one frame per message. This change has dropped the CPU usage from **7.6%** to **5.7%**.    @LorenzMeier @AndreasAntener I strongly advice to review your VTOL mixer files and make sure that no unnecessary outputs are being generated  they slow things down.    I also added a check in the UAVCAN ESC output bridge that removes the trailing zero setpoint values from the output. This should help to somewhat improve performance even when buggy mixing is afoot.    My next step is to let the system run for several hours under a sampling profiler in order to find bottlenecks. Has this ever been done before?

Title: Master px4io ppm fix
Body: @LorenzMeier     This was reported by @matanhavi in "Error on px4io-v2/board_config.h ?" #6516    I am surprised this ever worked on the PX4IOs.    Could it be PPM was never tested [since](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/commit/85651218e28968161890ddcae1c670f08774c285#diff-1f9583407523ce00e27e2754f6800af2) ands subsequent mods to the same line?    I stepped the code on the F1 on master and it does **not** initialize the pin returning -EINVAL:    ```   /* Verify that this hardware supports the select GPIO port */      port = (cfgset & GPIO_PORT_MASK) >> GPIO_PORT_SHIFT;    if (port >= STM32_NGPIO_PORTS)      {        return -EINVAL;      }  ```    Therefore I want to have this tested to ensure there was not some side effect.

Title: Call clearenv on NuttX
Body: Result from https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/6924 analysis.    Environment variables are automatically exported when set in an `nsh` script  and copied to all running tasks (without any option to disable the exporting). This requires a considerable amount of RAM of around 6kB. Since we do not use environment variables in any of the modules on NuttX  we can just clear them all before creating a new task.    This is the content of all variables after bootup:  ```  LOG_FILE=/fs/microsd/bootlog.txt  PARAM_FILE=/fs/mtd_params  PWM_DISARMED=p:PWM_DISARMED  FMU_MODE=pwm  AUX_MODE=pwm  USE_IO=yes  VEHICLE_TYPE=mc  MIXER_AUX=pass  IO_PRESENT=yes  BOARD_FMUV3=false  TTYS1_BUSY=no  PX4IO_LIMIT=400  SDCARD_MIXERS_PATH=/fs/microsd/etc/mixers  MIXER_AUX_FILE=/etc/mixers/pass.aux.mix  ```    Additionally we can now increase the log buffer by 4kB to minimize dropouts.

Title: use snapdragon_pwm_out and change connector for RC

Title: Refactor board level RC_IN definitions and useage
Body: @sirPerna This should resolve the RC_INPUT is pulled to VCC issue.     Removed the legacy FMUv4 define that was activating a nonexistent  pull up and on some HW driving the PPM_IN aka RC_IN aka SPEKTRUM_RX  to VDD.    Also detailed the connections of this pins for the board.    The simplest connection is RC_IN to a timer capture pin  and a UART.  In this case the UART_RX pin and just be left as is.  While the pin can be configured as the PPM_IN (Timer capture)  or as SPEKTRUM_RX_AS_GPIO_OUTPUT to use it as and GPIO to  facilitate binding.    Renamed the macros and defines to be more explicit as to what  Is being done and the sense of the parameters

Title: fmuv5 serial dma fixes and sbus
Body: The px4fmuv5 Sbus was broken on several levels.    1. The wrong stty was listed  2. The inversion routine had a cut-n-paste error  3. Nuttx stm32f7 serial driver was broken in 2 ways    Backport stm32f7:Serial fix for dropped data         1) Revert the inherited dma bug from the stm32         see https://bitbucket.org/nuttx/nuttx/commits/df9ae3c13fc2fff2c21ebdb098c520b11f43280d         for details.           2) Most all CR1-CR3 settings can not be configured while UE            is true. Threfore we make all operation atomic and disable            UE and restore it's originalstate on exit.           N.B. This backport omits all upstream breaking changes.

Title: Hui
WIP Mixer configuration View modify mixer parameters then save to a mix With px4io and mavlink support
Body: [New PR here](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/6960)    Rework of previous pull request with additional support for px4io.  https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/4844    **NEW**: [This document describes the system.  It does not describe the px4 implementation:](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LeQC2qtxqdesNuJ3RAWH_MJ_30xjf-PMN3bd5wtUAUo/edit?usp=sharing)    **NEW:** Modified to access all mixer parameters ie. both input and output mixers for SimpleMixer.  New usage instructions to follow below.  **NEW:** Support through mavlink messages with mavproxy mixer module available here:.  https://github.com/crashmatt/MAVProxy/tree/mixer  **NEW:** Stream all mixer data so a GCS can pick it up.    **NEW**:  Get mixer connections data so a GCS knows what each mixer is connected to    User instructions in post below.    **BUILD INSTRUCTION:**  Feature included automatically for targets without the 1MB flash limit.  To include in smaller targets define MIXER_TUNING in the board config    **ACTION**: Check that both fmu and io resources are within limits.    px4io changes are limited to the following changes for mixer config option only:      5 new 16bit i2c registers and additional case statement for them.      The set_parameter function and case statement for each mixer type      px4io support is done by having a copy of the mixers on the fmu.  The fmu and io changes are kept synchronized.  When a request to generate the mixer file is done  it is done from the fmu copy.    No flight testing is done since I have no time or space for it right now.  SITL will not test this.  HITL might test but this needs review  **ACTION**: Find someone to do testing or get HITL running - Thanks Mark W for first tests    px4io is critically short of memory.  Running the parameters access might push it over the limit.  **ACTION:** Run diagnostics and a suitable soak test for stability    **TODO**  Fix travis errors due to virtual name hiding  Tidy up px4io firmware naming  Limit set parameter changes to appropriate operation mode  Prevent reboot due to mixers not being loaded  Fix hacked mixer save confirmation message  Fix failure to clear local mirror mixers when re-uploading to px4io  Fix mixer naming headers  Fix signed-unsigned mismatch through mavlink for error values (sub count and more?)    **PLANNED:**  - Support on qgc  - Automated test support  - Clean up - not so much left  - Converting XML file to headers

Title: Updates to aerofc
Body: Several changes that are still being validated  but we've got better perfomance with this  particularly AltHold  less vibration  better GCS connection  etc.  The changes to baro will affect all boards (hopefully positively).    The UART link to Aero got the baudrate changed to 460800  providing much better connection to GCS.    Now we are using MPU9250 driver that's really an MPU6500 with additional mag in the same package. In future  migrating those 2 to MPU6000 would allow to have a single driver for them.    The last commit is a workaround to a bug introduced in master branch that doesn't allow updating the parameters.

Title: Param add rate limited auto save on LP work queue
Body: This automatically saves parameters after a timeout of 300ms and at most every 2 seconds.    The previous behavior was more complicated: `param set` on the console (or in scripts) would immediately save params; after bootup  commander would save params on param change notification (but only if `COM_AUTOS_PAR` was set).    It greatly improves bootup time after an airframe reset (`SYS_AUTOCONFIG=1`).

Title: Restructure patch ordering and dissolve 90000 wip inflight to upstream patch
Body: Per discussion and suggestion from @lucasdemarchi  order patches to avoid patch order dependent patch failures.    # Why are there nuttx-patches?    ## Upstream submission    1. Upstream may reject a patch for "not applicable" An example of this would be ```00002-fix-shadow-wanings.patch``` PX4 build with stricter warnings than does upstream. The patch applies compiler specific pragmas that have been rejected upstream.      2. PRs that go upstream a can come back very different. a) they can get reformatted and the essence of the PR can be lost in b) multiple further upstream formatting commits or c) committed with other wip in upstream. This is not an issue on the PX4 branches tied to the PX4 NuttX upstream branch. The PX4 NuttX upstream branch tracks upstream NuttX master at a regular uptake rate and I have to keep it building and running. On PX4/Firmware master The PX4 NuttX is lagging behind upstream and we want only our changes.    3. Taken as is. This is not an issue on the PX4 NuttX upstream branch that tracks upstream NuttX master but on PX4/Firmware master that is lagging behind upstream these become backports.    # What it 90000-wip-inflight-to-upstream.patch?    On the PX4 branches tied to the PX4 NuttX upstream branch: This file has the changes to keep the development and build moving along while the work in process is in flight to upstream. Depending on the outcome of the **Upstream submission** - the content can be 1) moved to a non-upstream able permanent patch. In Case 2) or 3) the contest can be removed once the PX4 NuttX upstream branch has been merged with the upstream NuttX master.    On the PX4 Firmware master branch:  This file has the changes to keep the development and build moving along while the work in process is iflight to upstream. Depending on the outcome of the **Upstream submission** - the content can be 1) moved to a non-upstream able permanent patch.   Or in case 2) and 3) Backported against masters NuttX submodules  This usually requires manual intervention to remove disjoint files that got committed upstream with the PX4 contribution or in the subsequent beautification edits.  Therefore the patch file is cleaned up and saved as a 6000 bp series patch file.    Why are you not using Git for this? (If I only could)    Workflow incompatibilities with upstream NuttX.   1. Upstream NuttX master may be used as a development branch from time to time. Lacking a re integration workflow means there will not be a clean commit set.    2. As has happened in the past a the upstream repos may be reorganized as submodule and then brought back into the tree.     Therefore rebasing will not work and even cherry picking can be difficult. With this KISS approach we can see all the changes PX4 requires to NuttX and edit and re-apply them when the upstream files set changes.     I am open to suggestions on a better way - to date I have not found one.      Got Some great suggestions and feedback - Thank you!    Naming has been changed per @lucasdemarchi recommendation to enforce ordering and classification    ```  00001-PENDING-fix-xyz.patch  00002-BACKPORT-fix-abc.patch  00003-REJECTED-remove-shadow-warnings.patch  ```    cmake has been taught to order the patches based on name.

Title: Logger add logrotate reduce CPU load
Body: - Imlement a simple logrotate. If free space on the SD card falls below a threshold  old log directories are deleted. The threshold is conservative: 300MB or 10% of the disk capacity if that's less  to make it usable on all architectures (SITL  embedded Linux  Pixhawk & co).  - Reduces the CPU load of the logger by ~1.5% to 5.3%.  - Add a `logs` symlink to the SITL build root directory for more convenient access to the logs.

Title: Adding STM32F7 Support px4nucleoF767ZI v1
Body: **3/15/2017 Since the HW does not have any FMU peripherals onboard and has a limited pinout. This platform is depreciated and is for reference only. While it will build not all features may work.**    This PR ports PX4 to the STM32F7. Specifically the px4nucleoF767ZI-v1  which is based on the STMicro Nucleo-144 development board family.      The STMicro Nucleo-144 can be thought in terms of OOD/OOP as a "base class" and the specialization are instanced as the Nucleo-144 variants.     ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1945821/19193526/1430aac4-8c46-11e6-98b0-3b8d5e33d657.png)    All the boards are identical  differing only in the installed part and some solder blob option.    The NUCLEO-F767ZI hosts a  STM32F767ZIT6 which is a 216MHz Cortex-M7 with 2048Kb Flash memory and 512Kb SRAM.    This is a WIP development platform based on the FMUv5 specification  and since the NUCLEO-F767ZI is not an auto pilot  it is not flyable without adding  a lot of IO devices. (Anyone want to spin a companion board?)

Title: WIP IEKF with simple dynamic model
Body: The goal here is to see if we should go the dynamic model route. I have px4tools working pretty well to sysid vehicles via log files so it might be feasible to fly with an estimator like lpe and then get the params from the sysid to load into IEKF.

Title: WIP IEKF estimator and minimal ROS port for PX4
Body: @ecmnet @mhkabir @kd0aij @julianoes @bkueng  This is a position and attitude estimator that borrows ideas from LPE. Hopefully I will get it passing the CI mission soon. Your input is appreciated.    Paper describing the IEKF: https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00494342/document    @LorenzMeier This is my current best stab at an estimator API to support easy development and algorithm comparison. I ported ROS minimally for the components I needed to PX4. It is similar to the example directory multiplatform code as you suggested  but instead of adding a common middle layer between px4 and ros  it ports ROS keeping the API the same. The benefit is that it should be an API already well known by researchers and they can compile their code without any middle-layer on ROS.    In order to port ROS  I had to add a string hashing library. This is pretty small and template based. For each Node I build up a hash table of all topics needed  and will do the same for parameters. I have to do this manually right now on the PX4 side  but I could probably automate that with some effort.    ## TODO  * [x] Pass quad auto mission for CI in SITL    * http://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=4ad24a77-3ab7-471a-9df3-aa112f0850ec  * [x]  Pass VTOL auto mission for CI in SITL    * URL: http://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=485af2cc-de4d-412c-944a-626547988f28    * URL: http://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=6e508bc2-fb98-4d2f-b4c1-064334a19c39    * URL: http://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=2a44e876-009e-427c-a8f9-e7f97d37bceb    * URL: http://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=a38e4576-ff39-4b2a-8756-c6773f76bdf8    * URL: http://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=7951ada2-5e12-425f-a45d-42302762c6e9     * URL: http://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=fb746804-cc8f-4017-b667-b39edcede913  * [x]  Lidar correction   * [x]  Optical flow support    * http://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=b0cd0f14-6f3b-44a0-a805-4a3665fdf86c  * Vision/mocap support  * [x]  Landing detection support  * [x] Parameter system  * [ ] Flight testing - In progress (only manual flight mode tested so far  working well)    ## IPython notebooks  * [Simulation](https://github.com/jgoppert/iekf_analysis/blob/master/IEKF%20Simulation.ipynb) (This is pretty useful since github renders ipython notebooks  making it easy to analyze algorithms).  * [IEKF Derivation](https://github.com/jgoppert/iekf_analysis/blob/master/IEKF%20Derivation.ipynb) (Some pretty ugly non-commutative algebra with quaternion products here if you are interested. I was able to re-derive all of the equations from the paper just to make sure I completely understood what was going on.)  * [Measurement Jacobians](https://github.com/jgoppert/iekf_analysis/blob/master/Measurement%20Jacobians.ipynb)    ## Quick Links to Code for Review  * [Header](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/iekf/src/modules/iekf/IEKF.hpp)  * [Source](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/iekf/src/modules/iekf/IEKF.cpp)  * [Ros spin loop](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/iekf/src/modules/iekf/iekf_main.cpp#L146)  * [ROS port](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/tree/iekf/src/lib/ros)  * [Hash table for ROS port](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/iekf/src/modules/iekf/ros/ros.cpp#L50)

It already integrates the latest Eigen version with a small modification on the include paths so it can use `Tensors`.  @LorenzMeier to this to build well  you have to push the latests `default` of Eigen on my repo and update the Git tag.
