[Waiting for this PR into mavlink common](https://github.com/mavlink/mavlink/pull/711)    **TODO**  **Complete mavlink PR**  Update to changes in mavlink parameters    [Description document for mixer parameters](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LeQC2qtxqdesNuJ3RAWH_MJ_30xjf-PMN3bd5wtUAUo/edit#heading=h.3cs7tuenkkib)    [This is a smaller part of a larger change which was implemented in this closed PR](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/6960)    **nsh menu**  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/351261/25250859/a2882fac-2617-11e7-9123-075e7381c3e0.png)    **View parameters - Running sitl**  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/351261/25250906/c8d07ec6-2617-11e7-82e4-eccc6bc4492b.png)    **Setting a parameter and reading back the change**  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/351261/25251004/1bbdf37a-2618-11e7-9d15-68c37b079939.png)    **Showing mixer configuration on screen - A simple quadcopter config**  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/351261/25251672/7161379a-261a-11e7-897a-b32838d4ec14.png)    **Saving mixer configuration to file (posix)**  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/351261/25251886/3fe52194-261b-11e7-9051-7941187aed53.png)    **The output mixer file opened in a text editor**  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/351261/25251934/6b8ea306-261b-11e7-97ee-3f9a5eadff88.png)

Title: Free RAM on IO Take 2
Body: @LorenzMeier    Free memory at "police light check" is 1656 bytes  that is 1056 up from master and up 176 bytes from pr-io-free-ram.    This has been tested on px4fmu-v2 (2 Mib) with Spektrum  and FrSky PPM and FrSky S Bus using QGC to check radio.    Based on your [comment](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7165#issuecomment-298430127) I refactored the first commit:    RC C library: Use same buffer as the protocols do not decode in parallel  There are now *No code changes* from master  other than file name refactoring and using a common struct.  The only downside is that it that rc_common has to include all the other protocols.

Title: px4fmu v4 SPI and init clean up
Body: This is a clean up of the SPI chip select handling. It was very broken.      When the MS5611 baro was moved to SPI2  the majority of the code was not refactored. The MS5611's CS was still being activated on SPI 1 and it was driven to enabled during sensor_reset on SPI1.

Title: Ackermann attitude and position control
Body: This PR builds on top of  #6615   and implements 2 new modules  1) gnd_att_control  2) gnd_pos_control    These two branched off from fixed wing apps and went through big refactoring and  to the best of my abilities  simplification and improvement.  Also  it allows to drive a Traxxas Stampede VXL manually and with mission mode and aims to provide a low level interface for similar vehicles.  I did a lot of tests on the system but  as a precaution  I'll do the final one this weekend and post here the logs for final validation.  This work was developed during my master thesis with @LorenzMeier and it's close to its end so I thought it would be cool to propose a merge with master so to allow others to develop on top of it but also to get feedback from this great community.    I used the new Pixhawk mini and built the system as shown in pictures below    ![panel_top](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11164269/25453856/c501e854-2aca-11e7-99c1-8cf61180c336.png)  ![final_assembly](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11164269/25453855/c4fb02a0-2aca-11e7-8c44-d17cf2ca19ef.jpg)    This is definitely not at the level of other apps and I kept it as simple as possible but perhaps it's still useful or interesting.  Any suggestion/comment/feedback is welcome.    PS: please apologize me for the immense amount of commits  which probably do not follow any good practice  it was a learning curve and I was often using two computers in two different locations  so i moved code through github.

Title: Versioning refactoring and more version information to the log files
Body: in particular  it adds the following information to the logs:  - SW release version (in addition to the git hash)  - OS name & version (tag + git hash if exists)  - mcu version & revision & UUID  - toolchain name & version    Still missing: NuttX version information  see TODO's in version.c. @davids5 can I leave that up to you?    Also I noticed  if you are on a git tag but have local changes  it still shows it as the release version.

Title: Prototype for synchronising MC attitude loops to gyro topic
Body: This has been submitted to get feedback on the proposed approach and to see if someone can spot why it flies OK in SITL  but hangs when run on a px4-v2 and px4-v4 board     It has been forked from https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/6344    It synchronises the mc attitude controller to sensor_gyro instead of control_state uORB topic. This removes the latency associated with the sensor and ekf2 applications from the gyro feedback path. This is a minimum change solution that does not involve splitting the rate and attitude controllers. Splitting the rate and attitude controllers is something that should be considered longer term.    The changes relevant to this review are in the last patch:    https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/6350/commits/482b90900eab07252fcd27832c68ada06bd871d5

Title: ULog Geotagging System and Trigger Refactor
Body: **UPDATED : Now includes transitional support for QGC till we can phase in the proper trigger control API**    This PR :     1. Adds a new camera feedback module  which only relays trigger packets (with geotag information) for now. This will be extended after the release to handle hardware/software feedback from supported cameras. (e.g http://www.seagulluav.com/product/seagull-sync/?v=1ee0bf89c5d1)  2. Added trigger pause/unpause functionality  which is now used to pause triggering during turnarounds  but makes sure than the camera isn't switched off completely.  3. Implements **strict** adherence to MAVLink spec across the board and removes/fixes all hacky/inconsistent uses of the spec.  4. Adding preliminary support for online geotagging (for commercial use-cases with datalink to the ground). No retransmission/SD storage implemented yet. If running a MAVLink 2.0 link to QGC  you will see image locations on the map as they are captured/triggered.  5. Reimplements trigger driver's internal state machine to not be absolutely crappy.    ...And a multitude of other optimizations which I'm forgetting right now.    Companion QGC PR : https://github.com/mavlink/qgroundcontrol/issues/5107    TODO (post-release) :   1. Implement proper timestamp/frame matching in QGroundControl GeoTag implementation. Current implementation will cause garbage tagging even if a single frame is missed.  2. Change `DO_DIGICAM_CONTROL` to `DO_IMAGE_START_CAPTURE`  etc. For now  I have made sure QGC and Firmware **consistently** use `DO_DIGICAM_CONTROL`  as it was all broken before (e.g "Hover and Capture" functionality.)  5. Re-iterate over mavlink.io docs and add deprecation notices for `DO_DIGICAM_CONTROL` after updating Firmware + QGC.  5. Implement navigator control of pausing/unpausing trigger when leaving mission area (mostly trivial thanks to architectural refactoring done in this PR).  6. Move distance counting out of the trigger driver and into navigator  from @dagar.  7. Store online tagging packets (MAVLink `CAMERA_IMAGE_CAPTURED` and PX4 `camera_capture.msg`) on the SD card using dataman. Implement a retransmission interface.  8. Add QGC support (in GeoTagController) to actually use these packets. Currently they are only displayed on the map (if running MAVLink 2.0).  9. Rotate camera orientation with a parameter or automatically using gimbal orientation if available.  10. Make QGC fill XMP tags with the new information (e.g attitude) it now has access to (https://support.pix4d.com/hc/en-us/articles/206434245#gsc.tab=0)  11. Make QGC fill EXIF's GroundDistance tag when rangefinder data is available in the log (already transported).

Title: changes to allow for multi uav support
Body: Modifications to allow simulating multi-UAVs  the following modifications were made: - Mavlink class can now take the mavlink_fcu_url as a ros parameter - ardrone and iris launch files expect this argument to be provided  otherwise they will default to: udp://localhost:14565@localhost:14560 - A new multi_uav.launch file was added to demonstrate this capability

Title: navio_adc add driver for Navio2 ADC
Body: Hello     This is my first attempt to make a Navio2 ADC driver for #7211 . Documentation is available [here](https://docs.emlid.com/navio2/dev/adc/) for Navio2.    Currently I'm having troubles getting sensors to see the adc driver:  ```  [user@mhome px4]$ ./src/firmware/posix/px4 .  commands file: .  18446744073709551267 WARNING: setRealtimeSched failed (not run as root?)    ______  __   __    ___   | ___ \ \ \ / /   /   |  | |_/ /  \ V /   / /| |  |  __/   /   \  / /_| |  | |     / /^\ \ \___  |  \_|     \/   \/     |_/    px4 starting.    pxh> uorb start  pxh> navio_adc start  INFO  [navio_adc] NavioADC::ctor  INFO  [navio_adc] init done  pxh> sensors start  ERROR [sensors] no ADC found: /dev/adc0 (9)  ERROR [sensors] no barometer found on /dev/baro0 (9)  pxh> list_devices  INFO  [drivers__device] PX4 Devices:  INFO  [drivers__device]    /dev/adc0  INFO  [drivers__device] DF Devices:  pxh> list_files  INFO  [drivers__device] Files:  pxh>   ```    I see sensors use DevMgr to get a handle DevHandle. Have I inherited the wrong class (VDev) ?  Any pointers are appreciated  ping @bkueng    This is WIP  I added the driver to SITL only for dry-testing.

Title: WIP Bebop RPi Toolchain Update v2
Body: This is a continuation of https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/6528    You will need to set `PATH` to a include the path to a `arm-linux-gnueabihf-g++` compiler    GCC Testing:  a. get rpi-tools  `git clone https://github.com/raspberrypi/tools`  ```  export PATH=<path>/tools/arm-bcm2708/gcc-linaro-arm-linux-gnueabihf-raspbian-x64/bin/:$PATH  export PX4_SOURCE=<px4-source>  ```    b. get a different compiler  like 5.3.1 from Linaro: https://releases.linaro.org/components/toolchain/binaries/5.3-2016.05/arm-linux-gnueabihf/gcc-linaro-5.3.1-2016.05-x86_64_arm-linux-gnueabihf.tar.xz    ```  export PATH=gcc-path>/bin:$PATH  export PX4_SOURCE=<px4-source>  ```    ```  cmake \  -G"Unix Makefiles" \  -DCONFIG=posix_rpi_cross \  ${PX4_SOURCE}    make  ```    Clang Testing:  You will need a GCC cross-compiler!  a. get prebuild clang  http://releases.llvm.org/download.html  ```  wget http://releases.llvm.org/3.9.0/clang+llvm-3.9.0-x86_64-fedora23.tar.xz  ```  unpack    Create symlinks for clang and clang++ in gcc cross-compiler dir:  ```  ln -s <clang-path>/bin/clang <gcc-path>/bin/clang  ln -s <clang-path>/bin/clang++ <gcc-path>/bin/clang++  export PATH=<gcc-path>/bin:$PATH    export PX4_SOURCE=<px4-source>    cmake \  -G"Unix Makefiles" \  -DCONFIG=posix_rpi_cross \  -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=clang \  -DCMAKE_CXX_COMPILER=clang++ \  ${PX4_SOURCE}    make  ```    @mhkabir @dagar could you please take a look?

Title: Raspberry pi only No navio or pxfmini needed rc in and pwm output without shield

To download ppmdecode program   visit https://github.com/crossa/raspberry-pi-px4firmware.  PPM signal can be decoded by GPIO.7    Pxfmini and navio are not popular autopilot hardware in china   I can handly to purchase it.  So that I use raspberry pi to build autopilot separately.  This dirver help to read the pwm value from shared memory and pushlish it to orb system    To see the video of testing

Title: Mavlink command retransmission
Body: This adds a class to allow for retransmission of outgoing commands.  The sent commands are kept in a timestamped list to check if they are acked as required by the mavlink protocol.  If they are not acked within a timeout  they can be retransmitted.    Only commands to other component IDs are actually sent out and broadcast commands are also ignored.    Before merging  this will need a cleanup of all the debug printfs.

Title: Sensirion SDP31 pressure sensor driver
Body: General specs: Good from 0 m/s (it can register 1 m/s) up to 25 m/s / 60 mph / 100 km/h. Impressive sensitivity virtually no offset. This should not require in-field calibration any more. The graph below shows a log where I walked about 8 meters indoor from one table to another and put the sensor down. You can even see when I approached the desk at the end of the log - just moving close to it triggered some air circulation.

Title: px4fmuv4pro Init GPIO_VDD_3V3_SENSORS_EN off at reset
Body: Insure a 0.0 voltage initial condition on VDD_3V3_SENSORS    By starting the GPIO_VDD_3V3_SENSORS_EN  low and deferring    the GPIO init of the slave selects and drdy signals until    board_app_initialize. We get ~ 180 ms of power off time    with 0.00 voltage applied to the sensors.

Title: Common module base class and module documentation
Body: We currently have these problems:  - module startup & shutdown are susceptible to race conditions and failure cases are generally not handled well  it's easy to make mistakes (#1644)  - modules documentation is missing completely on the dev guide ( @hamishwillee )  - the help function of some modules is not useful  incomplete or missing altogether. I sometimes have to go through the code to see how a command works.    This PR proposes a solution for these. Although the documentation & common base class are independent problems (and my solution)  it makes sense to change them in one go.    ### Module base class  Design goals:  - should work with threads and work queues  - integrate well with current structure to minimize the converting effort  - constructor & destructors should be called from within the new task (so that orb_subscribe etc work)  - thread-safe  - provide only the basic functionality (We already have the Block classes for param handling for example)  - possibility to wait until a task is started  - the `px4_task_spawn_cmd` and `px4_getopt` should be handled in the derived class  to provide customization    I used a template class so that it can have a static instance that is different for each derived module.    Limitations:  - it currently does not work with multi-instance modules such as mavlink  or some drivers (eg. mpu6000)  but it could be extended for that.  - `errx` and `err` do not work  since they can leave the lock in a locked state. Since we wanted to remove these anyway  this is a good opportunity (we can get rid of `warnx` too while at it).    ### Module documentation & usage  My idea is to have something similar to a `man` page that can be used on the console  as an online documentation  and in the source. It should be in the source  so that it's easy to update and in sync with the module. It's a document-once-use-everywhere approach to minimize maintainance efforts.    The module documentation looks like this (to make it readable in the source  I used C++11 raw string literals):  ```   PRINT_MODULE_DESCRIPTION(    R"DESCR_STR(  System logger which logs a (configurable) set of uORB topics and system printf messages  (warnings and errors) to ULog files. These can be used for system and flight performance evaluation   tuning  replay and crash analysis.  [...]  Typical usage to start logging immediately:  $ logger start -e -t  )DESCR_STR");  ```  The intention is that it includes:  - provided functionality of the module  - high-level implementation overview  - examples how to use the CLI interface    These strings can then extracted via script and turned into a html page (we could use markdown in the description and add sections). I haven't done that yet.    There are some limitations  for instance  no images  so it will still make sense to have a separate documentation page for a few of the modules.    On NuttX the module description is removed  to reduce Flash usage.    Similarly the usage help strings: they should be standardized  so that we can:  - easily use them on the console  - extract them and show them online  - maybe do fuzzy testing later on  allowing to test less common code paths in an automated way    This is the usage output for the `pwm` command (probably one of the more complex ones):  ```  Usage: pwm <command> [arguments...]   Commands:       arm           Arm output       disarm        Disarm output       info          Print current configuration of all channels       forcefail     Force Failsafe mode       on|off      Turn on or off       terminatefail Force Termination Failsafe mode       on|off      Turn on or off       rate          Configure PWM rates       -r <val>    PWM Rate in Hz (0 = Oneshot  otherwise 50 to 400Hz)       oneshot       Configure Oneshot125 (rate is set to 0)       failsafe      Set Failsafe PWM value       disarmed      Set Disarmed PWM value       min           Set Minimum PWM value       max           Set Maximum PWM value       test          Set Output to a specific value until 'q' or 'c' or 'ctrl-c' pressed       steps         Run 5 steps from 0 to 100%       The commands 'failsafe'  'disarmed'  'min'  'max' and 'test' require a PWM value:       -p <val>    PWM value (eg. 1100)     The commands 'rate'  'oneshot'  'failsafe'  'disarmed'  'min'  'max'  'test' and 'steps' additionally require to specify the channels with one of the following commands:       [-c <val>]  select channels in the form: 1234 (1 digit per channel  1=first)       [-m <val>]  Select channels via bitmask (eg. 0xF  3)                   default: 0       [-g <val>]  Select channels by group (eg. 0  1  2. use 'pwm info' to show groups)                   default: 0       [-a]        Select all channels     These parameters apply to all commands:       [-d <val>]  Select PWM output device                   values: <file:dev>  default: /dev/pwm_output0       [-v]        Verbose output       [-e]        Exit with 1 instead of 0 on error  ```    I already converted some modules & commands to test that it works (logger  send_events and fmu  which can run as task or on the work queue).  Others should work too  I looked at commander  dataman  navio_sysfs_pwm  mc_pos_controller  navigator  ekf2  LPE  fw_pos_control  fw_att_control  and land_detector.    Any thoughts?

Title: Guard against reboots during param saving
Body: This adds a shutdown locking API: the lock is aquired during param write  so that all shutdowns & reboots (this includes power button  reboots from shell scripts  FW flashing  low battery poweroff  ...) are deferred (with a maximum timeout of 5sec  after that the system forces shutdown). This avoids corrupt param storage.  It is implemented in a way that the lock is always only held for a very short time  so that the negative effects are avoided (priority inversion  blocking a work queue).    The reboot command adds a `lock` and `unlock` command for testing:    ```  reboot lock  reboot &  reboot unlock  ```    It can also be tested with `param save & ; reboot`.    ---    In addition it changes the work queue call from IRQ context for the power button notification (https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7038) to an uORB publication. Work queues cannot be used in IRQ context on NuttX because they use semaphores.

Title: Enable slower than realtime drift setups to achieve full accuracy in SITL
Body: @dagar @priseborough @bresch @Stifael @MaEtUgR @tumbili I wanted to do this forever but only now got around to it: We had already a lockstep interface that would pause the simulation if the simulator paused  however  we did not have the ability to deal with constant drift (simulator running constantly at a slower rate). This fixes the simulation engine to properly deal with this and makes the whole simulation environment a lot easier to use.

Title: px4fmu v2 Use simple HW versioning API to differentiate V2 variants at runtime
Body: There are several boards that share the px4fmu-v2 build as px4fmu-v3 build.       It was initially envisioned  that the build would be binary compatable and     the RC script would probe different sensors and determine at runtime the     HW type. Unfortunately  a failed sensor  can result in mis-detection     of the HW and result in an improper start up and not detect the HW     failure.       All these boards's bootloader report board type as px4fmu-v2.     This precludes and automated selection of the correct fw if it     had been built  by a different build i.e. px4fmu-cube etc.       We need a way to deal with the slight differences in HW that effect     the operations of drivers and board level functions that are different     from the FMUv2 pinout and bus utilization.       1) FMUv3 AKA Cube 2.0 and Cube 2.1 Bothe I2C busses are external.        This effected the mag on GPS2 not reporting Internal and        having the wrong rotation applied.       2) FMUv3 does not performa a SPI buss reset correctly.        FMUv2 provides a SPI1 buss reset. But FMUv3 is on        SPI4. To complicate matters the CS cross bus        boundries.       3) PixhawkMini reused a signal that was associated with SPI4        as a SPI1 ready signal.       Based on hardware differnce in the use of PB4 and PB12 this code     detects: FMUv2   the Cube  and PixhawkMini and provides the     simple common API for retriving the type  version and revision.       On FmuV5 this same API will be used.

Title: Define default BOARD_NUMBER_I2C_BUSES and BOARD_I2C_BUS_CLOCK_INIT
Body: This allows for the default number of I2C bus and clock speeds to be set at compile time for a given board.    This reduces the need for code calling [device::I2C::set_bus_clock](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/4453e4201b7a245cff52beeb38a293161aea4c48/src/drivers/boards/crazyflie/crazyflie_i2c.cpp) to just 2 defines in the board config.

Add yaw 23 to the ronation

Title: WIP NuttX cmake wrapper
Body: This is an experiment for wrapping the NuttX build differently. It significantly decreases NuttX build time and has some side benefits for incremental builds and debugging source confusion.    The idea is to directly wrap the building of each of the handful of NuttX libs PX4 requires and skip the slow nuttx-export.     - NuttX build (cmake wrapper) moved to the top level of NuttX (aka the knot - https://github.com/PX4/PX4NuttX/tree/cmake)   - nuttx-configs are moved into the PX4NuttX repo.    - nuttx-patches are moved into the nuttx and apps forks.    @lucasdemarchi you might be interested in this.

Title: RFC Make NuttX drivers cross platform VDev CDev and MS4525 linux driver
Body: On NuttX we have a large collection of well tested device drivers (I2C/SPI/serial) implemented using CDev (nuttx character devices). On non-nuttx posix platforms we have a nearly identical interface called VDev which uses virtual files/devices/ioctls.    If we combine them and instead treat VDev as the platform independent version of CDev we can fairly easily "port" our existing NuttX to the other platforms.    In this PR I've renamed VDev -> CDev and ported the NuttX ms4525 differential pressure sensor driver. I've successfully tested it on a Navio2 Raspberrypi. Porting consisted of removing unnecessary headers  prepending px4_ to ioctl  open  close  and making sure the ms4525 launcher didn't call exit.    I propose we consider this as a path forward for unified cross platform PX4 drivers. My next step is adding a Linux CDev SPI interface  then porting the bulk of the important drivers. I'd like to continue the Driver rearchitecture discussion  but doing so incrementally from CDev. I have another PR that cleanly combines the Device and CDev classes between NuttX and Linux  then each have separate I2C and SPI interfaces.    @davids5 @mcharleb @bgat @LorenzMeier

Title: aerofc Use baud of 921600 for Aero
Body: This changes the baudrate that communicates with Aero to 921600. In order to get a reliable communication there are some changes on the Linux side that's done here and will be part of a new version in future: https://github.com/intel-aero/meta-intel-aero/pull/272 and https://github.com/intel-aero/meta-intel-aero-base/pull/18    Without upgrading the distro/packages these are the equivalent instructions:    - Add this line to the `/lib/systemd/system/mavlink-router.service` under `[Service]` section:  `ExecStartPre=/bin/bash -c 'echo 4 > /sys/class/tty/ttyS1/rx_trig_bytes'`  - Change baudrate of the uart port for mavlink-router in `/etc/mavlink-router/main.conf`  - Change baudrate of the update script in `/usr/sbin/aerofc-update.sh`

Title: WIP worst case analysis of stack usage
Body: This is an experiment on worst case analysis of stack usage.   The idea would be to compute at compile time the maximum stack usage of apps. The resulting number can be compared to the allocated stack and checked by CI.     I added the gcc compilation flag `-fstack-usage` which creates one file with extension `.su` per object file. The `.su` files contain the stack usage per function. I used a perl script `avstack.pl` (originally developped for avr) to walk the call tree and compute the worst case stack usage for each function.  It does not fully work yet. I added sample output of the script for target `px4fmu-v2_default`.    TODO:  - [ ] Check the error messages in file `wca_stack_usage_errors.txt` (see diff)  - [ ] Compare values of stack usage returned in `wca_stack_usage.txt` to what is returned by `top`    If this is fixable  then there will be additional items:  - [ ] add compiler flags only when using gcc  - [ ] update CI to retrieve allocated stack size for every application and compare it with the output of the script    @dagar have you tried something like that already?

Title: 30 Day notice Deprecation of FMUv1 and PX4IOv1 Merge on Sept 10th
Body: This PR removes the support for FMUv1 and PX4IOv1 HW from PX4.     The ardrone_interface is also removed as it was only used by FMUv1.    See https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/7758     @hamishwillee FYI

Title: drivers add support for TeraRanger Evo
Body: Terabee is about to release a new range finder sensor. This commit adds a driver for it.    Any feedback is welcome and highly appreciated.

Title: Fix conflict in OcPoC Ubuntu configuration
Body: Adds 'lib/micro-CDR' to posix_ocpoc_ubuntu cmake config file; mirrors changes in 39eeebd from PR #7685.

Title: Add LED signal when boot failed
Body: ## Problem  When the boot is halted because of an error in the init scripts  the system is left in a half-started state.     For example in #4846  the boot failed because a command in the SD card file `etc/extras.txt` was unknown. The mavlink stream was blocked  but no error was reported (except in the system console).    ## Solution  This adds an LED error signal (red slowly blinking) when the system boot takes too long.    ## Implementation  I implemented it in the commander app similarly to the mavlink app: i.e. with a boolean `boot_complete` set to true at the end of the startup script.  Upsides:  - warns user that the boot failed  - does not change the behaviour of the commander app  only the LED pattern    Downsides:  - the startup scripts are modified to add the command `commander boot_complete` after the command `mavlink boot_complete`    ## Potential improvements (not included in this PR):  Let me know if I should add these to the PR:  - Add the boolean `boot_complete` in topic `vehicle_status`.   With this PR  both `commander` and `mavlink` apps need to by notified when the boot is complete. Boot completion could be indicated on the `vehicle_status` topic. This would allow others apps to be notified  and also to remove the command `mavlink boot_complete` from startup scripts.   - Prevent flight while boot is incomplete  The drone can take off even if the boot failed. For safety reason  it would be nice to prevent flight  for example by preventing mode switching.

Title: Make FTP more robust
Body: Make FTP robust against any kind of packet drops. On the vehicle side  this mostly means to keep a copy of the last sent response  most of the logic is in a QGC PR.

Body: This makes sure the simulation with the range finders still works as all estimators now check the orientation.

Title: enable simple posix tests
Body: There are a handful of simple posix tests under platforms not being compiled or run.    This PR also fixes the existing perf test to print to stdout instead of stdin  and decreases the time in the hrt test.

Title: Do Not Merge Work in Progress Nxphlite v3
Body: This has been merged with the important commit from https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/5694    This is a WIP for the NXP flight V3 HW based on the K66. It builds but is incomplete as it is missing key Nuttx support in the Kinetis architecture.    The drivers/kinetis/\* is just stubbed out.  There is SPI  or DMA support    Missing Components  - [x]  FPU support in the OS  - [ ] DMA  - [x] SPI - stubbed kinetis_spibus_initialize(int bus);  - [ ] CAN  - [ ] VBAT - for bootloader app commnincation.  - [x] Timers PIT  LPTM  and FTM  PDB - for pwm  capture  tones  and hrt.  - [x] RESET up_systemreset(void) noreturn_function;        Incomplete Drivers:  - [x] PWM supports only 1 chan per timer.  - [x] USB The K66 has 2 USB USB0 is FS (Nuttx has driver) USB1 is HS (No NuttX driver!)   - [ ] UART lacking DMA kinetis_serial_dma_poll(void)  - [x] TERMIOS for serial  - [ ] RTC - up_rtc_getdatetime  - [ ] SDHC DMA disabled will not work with it yet    OS/System dependant SW  - [x] Cannot use FPU yet on kinetis  - [x] Termios  - [x] tcgetattr  - [x] tcsetattr  - [x] cfsetspeed    PX4 FMUV2 Modules removed from build due to No External SPI  - [ ] drivers/bma180  - [ ] drivers/bmi160        NOT Portable YET  - [ ] /Firmware/src/modules/systemlib/mcu_version.c  - [ ] drivers/pwm_input  - [ ] drivers/test_ppm  - [ ] systemcmds/hardfault_log - needs bsram  - [ ] modules/uavcan  - [ ] uavcan  - [ ] uavcan_stm32_driver - need Kinetis CAN driver    PX4 Drivers Needing porting  - [ ] drivers/kinetis/*  - [ ] drv_hrt.c      - [x] HRT      - [x] PPM  - [ ] drv_input_capture.c  - [x] drv_io_timer.c  - [ ] drv_led_pwm.cpp  - [x] drv_pwm_servo.c  - [x] drivers/kinetis/adc  - [x] drivers/kinetis/tone_alarm

Title: PX4 Rover should have manual reverse
Body: I tried PX4 on a RPI3/Navio2 hardware  running rover configuration. I found myself frequently needed to back off the rover from a corner manually but the current code base does not support manual reverse for rovers.    I first tried to play around with the Mixer settings by changing the output offset for the throttle channel. The manual reverse is possible but this method disrupts many things. E.g. arming/disarming using sticks is possible but not safe  AUTO HOLD throttle level is no long at a neutral position  mission throttle  min and max throttle levels are changed etc.    This pull request implements rover with manual reverse support. It has the following behaviors:  * reverse is only possible in manual mode  the mid position of throttle channel (typically 1500  us) is the neutral or breaking  the lower half is for revere and the higher half is for going forward.  * arming requires throttle channel at neutral position when motor is not spinning.   * auto mission uses only the forward range of the throttle channel. auto hold mode uses neutral/breaking throttle.  * for the users  the behavior of mission cruise settings stay the same. e.g. 50% cruise throttle will be mapped to the correct forward speed  i.e. 50% of full forward speed.  * Other vehicle configurations and behaviors not affected.    Tested using HIL GPS simulated by Vicon motion capture indoors:  (first  I use manual mode to drove the rover backward into position  then I switched to auto mission. There are 3 plain way points (marked on the floor) in the mission.)    ![insta](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14265605/29998233-861972a2-8feb-11e7-9184-d8a069e364e0.gif)        I believe many people would find this implementation useful. Let me know what you think!

Title: sitl add possibility to not run gazebo when running make
Body: Trying to resolve #3961 without changing to much of the scripts  I found that I could just add an environment variable (I called it "DONT_RUN") in `sitl_run.sh` that would disable running for Gazebo (there is already a "HEADLESS" environment variable used there).    I don't know how to edit the cmake target as suggested by @AndreasAntener in #3961  so I'm open to advice.    Of course  that could be extended to other simulators  but for now I wanted to have a feedback on this idea.

Title: NuttX upgrade cmake wrapper
Body: Continuation of https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7397  but for updated NuttX.    This is an experiment for wrapping the NuttX build differently  overall making it much faster and allowing better integration with PX4.     - wraps NuttX per library allowing parallel and incremental builds and tighter integration   - uses NuttX's mechanism for generating builtins which means we don't need sercon/serdis boilerplate in every single config   - moves patches into git commits   - NuttX copy per PX4 build can be done with hard links (where supported) which improves in place editing and debugging   - treats the px4io as a dedicated build  then imports the binary (significantly cleaner and allows us to start using standard cmake for setting compiler flags)   - imports NuttX CONFIG flags into PX4 cmake to better handle multiple architectures   - binaries now placed at top level build dir named ${BUILD}.elf   - all builds moved to a build/ subdirectory   - significant cleanup of the build system for PX4 UAVCAN bootloaders   - split px4fmu-v2 and px4fmu-v3 only handling versioning in v3

Title: cmake minor fixes
Body: - restore output binary naming for s3 (and QGC compatibility) eg nuttx_px4fmu-v2_default.px4 -> px4fmu-v2_default.px4   - nuttx cmake improved dependencies (#7999)   - snapdragon 'upload' dependencies fix (remove hardcoded paths)

Title: Add ocpoc target to CI
Body: Adds ocpoc build target to docker_run.sh - in response to PR #7787 - and updates some board_config items that had broken the build target. Docker file and container were added/built in [containers PR #73](https://github.com/PX4/containers/pull/73).    @dagar It seems like semaphoreci is the appropriate place to add ocpoc  since that's where rpi and bebop run their test builds  but I'll reiterate that I'm brand new to the CI side of things. I haven't added the target yet  as I don't really know how to add the target to semaphoreci.

Title: version add support for vendor version
Body: This adds support for parsing git tags which include a vendor version. E.g. `vX.Y.Z-A.B.Crc1`  whereas `X.Y.Z` are numbers defining the upstream version and `A.B.C` is the vendor version.    A new unittest ensures its functionality: `test_versioning`  run `make tests`

Title: build get rid of annoying CMake warning
Body: Depending on the CMake version when we are configuring it emits a  warning about deprecation of CMAKE_FORCE_CXX_COMPILER. However we  rely on this macro and don't want to do what CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER  is doing. Here is what I get with CMake 3.9.1:     CMake Deprecation Warning at /usr/share/cmake/Modules/CMakeForceCompiler.cmake:83 (message):     The CMAKE_FORCE_CXX_COMPILER macro is deprecated.  Instead just set     CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER and allow CMake to identify the compiler.   Call Stack (most recent call first):     cmake/toolchains/Toolchain-arm-none-eabi.cmake:37 (cmake_force_cxx_compiler)     /usr/share/cmake/Modules/CMakeDetermineSystem.cmake:94 (include)     CMakeLists.txt:263 (project)    Avoid the warning by passing -Wno-deprecated to cmake.

Title: Add include guard in headers files
Body: Add include guard to the headers files in which it is missing.

Title: RTPS and micro CDR build system improvements
Body: This PR fixes some build system issues with RTPS and microCDR.   - serialization moved from each uORB topic header/source to separate files (eg <uORB/topics/sensor_baro.h> -> <uORB_microcdr/topics/sensor_baro.h>)   - cdr serialization only generated for listed topics   - micro-CDR library only included and built if RTPS is detected and topics specified   - micrortps build dependencies fixed    @mcharleb @bkueng any issues with doing this? It improves build times and doesn't burden targets like the px4io with generating and building all this stuff the linker just throws away.    I still don't like the way this quietly depends on fastrtpsgen being found. It creates a situation where users can build and test locally  but break once pushed to CI. If fastrtpsgen isn't yet a hard requirement we should leave it out of the default builds and have rtps configurations where not being able to find fastrtpsgen is a fatal error (nuttx_px4fmu-v4_rtps  posix_sitl_rtps  etc)    This has been split out of https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/8043.

Title: move RTPS to dedicated px4fmu v 3 4 4pro 5 posix sdflight builds
Body: RTPS and micro-cdr now only included and required in the following builds        - nuttx_px4fmu-v3_rtps      - nuttx_px4fmu-v4_rtps      - nuttx_px4fmu-v4pro_rtps      - nuttx_px4fmu-v5_rtps        - posix_sitl_rtps        - posix_eagle_rtps      - posix_excelsior_rtps

Title: orb_exists change semantics from is published or subscribed to is published
Body: Existing users of `orb_exists`:  - logger (dynamic subscribe to multi-instances)  - mavlink (orb subscription)  - sdlog2  - preflightcheck (check for home_position)  - wait_for_topic shell command (it's not used)  - orb_group_count() (used in sensors: dynamic sensor addition)        All use-cases benefit from the changed semantics: they are really only interested if there is a publisher  not another subscriber.    Additional changes:  - logger: do not subscribe to the first instance if the topic is not advertised (but dynamically check if it's published later on)  - logger: remove unused topics commander_state & rc_channels  - avoid dynamic allocations in orb_exists on POSIX  - mavlink_orb_subscription: reduce orb_exists() check from 10Hz to 3Hz    This has deeper impacts on the overall system  hopefully mostly positive!  The following provides some test results.    ### Testing  To get representative results  I tested on a fully assembled quad (pixracer) in armed state with RC and an open QGC connection.    #### Used file descriptors  Number of used file descriptors (mavlink instance is the one that is connected to QGC  without b50b0b7):  ```  Before:  mavlink: 46  logger: 54  This PR: mavlink: 30  logger: 33  ```    #### Memory (Fragmentation)  The additional file operations (open & close) in `orb_exists` do not lead to memory allocations/frees on Nuttx  but did so on POSIX. I changed this in 3b31a03.    My tests showed a considerable **memory reduction of 4.2 KB**. A bit more than half is because of mavlink  the rest is logger. Since pixracer runs more mavlink instances than other boards  it will be slightly less on other boards.    #### CPU usage  Tests showed this is pretty much unchanged (without 191622b). This is the execution time of `orb_exists` before (with locked scheduling):  ```  orb_exists: 23174 events  879696us elapsed  37us avg  min 20us max 196us 24.192us rms  ```  And this PR:  ```  orb_exists: 22182 events  1383130us elapsed  62us avg  min 20us max 274us 47.743us rms  ```  Obviously slower  but I think it's still ok  since it's not called with high frequency or at critical places.    I suggest reviewing each individual commit.

Title: stable AeroFC important backports
Body: We are going to do release of the Aero Linux image changing the baudrate to 921600bps in mavlink-router and PX4  also the 'force bootloader pin' would be nice to have as it is already supported by the current Aero Linux image.

Title: PIXRACER request
Body: Hi I'm Lance from Yuneec:    For racer to consider using pixhawk as a racer  there a couple of things that are missing    1. the Racer Must support the new ESC protocol multishot  Dshot600 and Dshot1200 ( BLheli 32       firmware)     2. 250 size race drone is totally out of date   Most of the Race size are 210 ( full size )   140 ( mini)   100 ( micro)    3. ( Accord to what I see in betaflight ) gyro update in up to 32KHz  depends what esc you can support it 8kHz with blhelis and 32kHz with blheli32    4. If you can support OSD like how beta flight does ( rssi and voltage is very important for us )     5. Able to config through OSD is a very nice feature  and able to connect smartaudio from TBS unify      pro to change channel and output also come really handy.

Title: px4fmu v2_default add sf1xx driver
Body: - closes #8177

Title: df_hmc5883_wrapper set mag device path from input argument
Body: Enables the df_hmc5883_wrapper to accept an I2C device path as an input argument. The default remains the MAG_DEVICE_PATH defined in DriverFramework  but this makes for a far easier method to update or change the device path from the default.

Title: Move gyro calibration from commander to events
Body: This patch moves gyro calibration out of commander to events framework.  Some of the common code shared with other sensor calibration code is moved  to systemlib/calibration    This is one of the part of task mentioned in #8014    Currently the changes are tested on pixhawk using QGC and from commandline and compared the gyro calibration values with and without the changes.

Title: travis ci update
Body: Travis has been unstable and unusably slow lately. I'm removing all extraneous parts of the build. All of these are either informational and can't cause the build to fail  or already moved to jenkins.    Plans for migrating these to the new Jenkins server (http://ci.px4.io:8080/) are in this project board.   https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/projects/16

Title: Use linux_sbus driver on OcPoC
Body: The linux_sbus driver is far cleaner than the ocpoc_sbus_rc_in driver we've been using  so this PR removes the ocpoc specific driver and replaces it with linux_sbus  with a little cleanup in the cmake config files as well.

Title: Fix check_stack target
Body: Fix the Makefile target "check_stack" to match the new build directories (https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7873).    note: as the compile flag "-fstack-usage" was removed  I removed calls to the first script that needs *.su files (which are only generated when -fstack-usage is passed to the compiler)

Title: New Look for jMAVSim
Body: This brings the jMAVSim upgrade from https://github.com/PX4/jMAVSim/pull/62 with better textures and improved rendering settings:    ![jmavsim_new_texture1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/281593/32054547-0397c86c-ba5f-11e7-8c09-ff2d08f0cef8.png)    @hamishwillee fyi

Title: jMAVSim update submodule to include fix for VMware driver
Body: @hamishwillee @MaEtUgR     Fixes #8229

Title: integrationtests fix numpy version problem broken Jenkins
Body: During px4tools installation the latest version of pandas is installed  which requires numpy>=1.9.0. Pandas installs the required version  however  due to the presence of the old numpy in the docker image  the present version 1.8.2 is used  which leads to an error when importing pandas. It's one of the causes of Jenkins SITL fails.    This PR fixes the problem explicitly upgrading numpy with pip before px4tools installation.    @dagar  please review.

Title: Jenkins update docker image
Body: Update the docker image used for Jenkins builds.    I tried to make the same change in #8063  but it was not used during the build.  Apparently Jenkins does not use a Jenkinsfile that was modified by a PR  it falls back to the Jenkinsfile in master. It took me a while to understand that. That makes sense in terms of safety. Interestingly though  we will know if builds pass for this PR only *after* it is merged to master!    @dagar

Title: Add RTPS cmake config for AeroFC
Body: Adding a seperate cmake config to support RTPS messaging on AeroFC. This will  include compiling protocol_splitter and micrortps_client  and starting both  of them at boot time.

Title: submodules track branch and update
Body: This PR sets the submodules branch and updates all to the latest.     With `git submodule update --remote` you can update them to the latest.    Another minor submodule improvement is setting `git config status.submodulesummary 1`.

Title: WIP silent calibration fails
Body: The issue is that calibration fails silently without messages sent out to QGC     Removed [cal] from calibration_log_critical() methods.  Removed [cal] from calibration_messages.h in the QGC_ERROR defs    @dagar

Title: Merge FMUv3 into FMUv2
Body: This is a fix for the pixhawk mini which needs to use the px4fmu-v2_default binary due to lacking bootloader versioning.    FMUv3 was a superset of FMUv2 that used the full 2MB flash and added runtime version detection to handle various board differences in the pixhawk 2 cube and pixhawk mini.     This PR combines FMUv3 into FMUv2 with the only difference being the linker script used by FMUv3 and PX4 module list.

Title: LED refactoring
Body: This brings an LED refatoring: transition from ioctl() to uORB for the external LED's. uORB has several benefits  like thread-safety  and increased flexibility (logging topics  support for heterogenous architectures like Snapdragon).  It includes priority handling and controlling multiple led's individually. A common library implementation makes sure that code is shared among drivers. It comes with a `led_control` command for testing and control on the console.    Note that there are some more drivers that still use the ioctl interface  like blinkm and oreoled (more?)  but they use different device paths  and thus were not controlled from commander.    Tested on a pixhawk with the rgbled driver.

Body: Fixed the Matrix submodule reference. Couldn't push to the old PR because Github considered it merged.    Good to go.

Title: delete old modules in examples
Body: Unless someone feels strongly about it I think we should delete these old modules that were moved to examples.    Some of them are still compiled and need to be updated when uORB messages change  but they aren't tested and can't even be enabled via param. They also confuse the parameter reference. https://dev.px4.io/en/advanced/parameter_reference.html#multicopter-position-control

Title: unify nuttx and posix Device CDev ms5611 linux port
Body: This PR merges the posix and nuttx Device and CDev classes. I also started disentangling Device/CDev  but ultimately maintained the current hierarchy. They're mostly separate now  but the IOCTL usage is so tangled between Device  CDev  I2C  SPI that will likely need to touch every driver.    With this PR the Navio2 Raspberrypi is now using the main ms5611 driver (I2C).    @nicolaerosia FYI

I also added more generic airframes (generic flying wing  generic ground vehicle  generic vtol standard) as the first of each group. These are generally what users need as they usually don't have the exact same setup and this puts them at the top of the list in QGC. Title: uORB pub sub graph
Body: This adds a python script to extract uORB pub/sub information from the source tree and create 2 possible graph outputs: JSON for D3.js or Graphviz.    See it in action: https://logs.px4.io/plot_app/static/graphs_selectable/index.html    Fixes #6189 (See also https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/6189#issuecomment-347507465)    I added the D3.js html file  but it does not need to live in this repo. To test it  create the graph with:  ```  ./Tools/uorb_graph/create.py -e src/examples -f Tools/uorb_graph/graph_full  ```  Then open the html file and select the full graph.    TODO:  - generate from a cmake config target: required is only the list of modules. @dagar any good idea  so that we don't do that on every (local) build?  - handle Subscription & Publication classes (I planned to refactor those first  so this can wait)  - integration into the dev-guide. @hamishwillee I could need your help with that. It's 2 static files: a html and one or more JSON files with the graph (due to same-origin policy  the JSON file needs to come from the same server).  - CI and automatic updates based on master

Title: Max flash size sync between uploader and board
Body: The goal is to force developers to use the correct target with the correct flash size. This prevents criticial functionality missing and is in particular important for FMUv2/FMUv3 boards. It is unmaintainable otherwise for the Pixhawk series.    Reject looks like this:  ```  Loaded firmware for 9 0  size: 1028685 bytes  waiting for the bootloader...  If the board does not respond within 1-2 seconds  unplug and re-plug the USB connector.  Attempting reboot on /dev/tty.usbmodem1 with baudrate=57600...  If the board does not respond  unplug and re-plug the USB connector.  Found board 9 0 bootloader rev 4 on /dev/tty.usbmodem1    ERROR: Board can accept larger flash images (2080768 bytes) than board config (1032192 bytes). Please use the correct board configuration to avoid lacking critical functionality.  ```

Title: Nuttx GCC7 enable Wimplicit fallthrough
Body: Re-enable implicit fallthrough (with default level 3) warning in #8551     I tried various warning levels but they seem ineffective in the docker image.  - -Wimplicit-fallthrough=0 correctly disables the warning  - levels 1  2 and 3 do not correctly accepts fallthrough comments  See here for what the behaviour should be https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc-7.2.0/gcc/Warning-Options.html#Warning-Options.    I replaced the comments `/* FALLTHROUGH */` by attributes `[[fallthrough]]` in C++ files  and by `__attribute__((fallthrough))` in two C files.

Title: Cygwin Enable build of SITL jMAVsim and ARM NuttX under Windows
Body: Most of the incompatitbilities are luckily similar to the darwin build.  - New target OS `__PX4_CYGWIN` added because in other build environments on Windows defines will very likely be completely different  - added all necessary exeptions to the defines  - disabled priorities completely because on Windows they are defined as values 1-32 and with all the arbitrary +40 -40 priority settings for the modules there were a lot of problems    not only did some threads/"virtual tasks" not start because of out of bound priorities but also the resulting scheduling was totally random and inadequate    with default priorities it ran toally fine during my first tests  should be rethought when windows is used onboard in the future    What I'm really wondering is what the define `__CUSTOM_FILE_IO__` is for... I couldn't find any documentation. Any explanation appreciated.    Here is an archive of the portable toolchain setup I tested with: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1y0SvGT6kPxJaB0T-qY2m0ONeR5ppzLGv/view?usp=sharing  If anyone wants to have a try just:  - unzip  - open the console (click script in the root folder)  -   ```  cd Firmware  make posix jmavsim  ```  - connect QGC for testing (which is available for Windows even the daily build https://docs.qgroundcontrol.com/en/releases/daily_builds.html)    I will:  - add more documentation in the dev guide as soon as it's merged (including how to build the entire toolchain manually)  - appreciate any hosting platform/system for the one click toolchain  - maybe create a small PX4 binary package without toolchain for demonstration purposes  - ~try to enable ARM build as well~ **EDIT:** done  - (look into what is possible for Windows CI)

Title: NuttX cmake generate Make defs from PX4
Body: Each nuttx-config's Make.defs is nearly identical except for architecture specific compiler flags which PX4 cmake already has. We can generate this file for each nuttx-config  inheriting the cpu flags from PX4. Additional NuttX flags can be added to `nuttx-configs/Make.defs.in`.    TODO: test on windows

Title: Makefile distclean deinit all submodules
Body: The git submodule dependencies within cmake are actually working surprisingly well. This PR updates `make distclean` to force deinit all submodules  instead of use submodulesclean which reloads all. The next build will initialize only the git submodules actually used by that configuration.

Title: Jenkins rename rostest xml logs to match mission

Title: Feature Precision landing
Body: This is a WIP that adds precision landing for multicopters with the IRLock camera and beacon.    It contains multiple things:    1.  Add orb publishing to the IRLock driver  2. Add a new module  `beacon_position_estimator`  which fuses IRLock reports and range measurements to estimate the beacon's position relative to the vehicle  3. Fuse the beacon measurements in LPE: If the beacon is specified to be stationary (by parameter)  fuse it's measured velocity  similar to optical flow measurements.  4. Add a new flight mode  `PrecLand`  which guides the vehicle down to land on the beacon. Also allow switching to `PrecLand` for land waypoints in missions.  5. Add a Gazebo world  models  and plugin to simulate precision landing.  6. Add noise to the simulated GPS measurements for testing the estimation improvements of beacon measurements    Thanks to @dagar for the help with the simulation and general architecture help.    This has had preliminary testing both in SITL Gazebo and on a PixFalcon with an IRLock camera and a Lidar Lite v3 range sensor. It would be great if others could also test this and provide feedback.    I would also appreciate general feedback on the architecture etc  particularly the interface with the mission controller.    To Do before merging:  - improve experience when switching to precland. I tried using `mc_pos_control`'s prev-current line following to get smooth setpoints  but there are still some setpoint jumps. I might end up just generating smooth setpoints in PrecLand and skipping over all of the logic in `mc_pos_control`.  - check stack usage of `beacon_position_estimator` and reduce to needed amount  - remove debug logging in `beacon.cpp`  - check formatting    Future improvements:  - add beacon measurements to EKF2  - generalize beacon estimator to handle different types of landing targets  e.g. ones that also require estimating target orientation    FYI @dagar @jgoppert @ElMexicant

Title: Proposal organize drivers by type
Body: When soliciting input for https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/7705  #7799  #7806  etc I heard various complaints about the config files. If you add a new module or driver it has to be manually added to every config. Configs get out of sync or are randomly missing modules that slip through until some unfortunate user with the right board and peripheral combination comes along.    One minor improvement I thought of is to group the drivers by type under src/drivers. For example all the differential pressure sensors (airspeed) move to `src/drivers/differential_pressure`.   - `drivers/ets_airspeed`   - `drivers/ms4525_airspeed`   - `drivers/ms5525_airspeed`   - `drivers/sdp3x_airspeed`    becomes     - `drivers/differential_pressure/ets`   - `drivers/differential_pressure/ms4525`   - `drivers/differential_pressure/ms5525`   - `drivers/differential_pressure/sdp3x`    Now in each configuration file you can simply include `drivers/differential_pressure` to get them all  or you can add only the desired drivers for constrained setups.    As new sensors are added they only need a single entry in `src/drivers/differential_pressure/CMakeLists.txt`  and then all configs gain access.    The only potential downside to this I see is that some drivers don't neatly fit into categories.    Thoughts?

Title: Iris set mixer to quad_wide
Body: The geometry was previously `quad_deadcat` in which front motors are closer to the CG and thus more loaded in hover. `quad_wide` is the same geometry as `quad_deadcat` except the CG is centered so all motors are loaded equally.  Flight logs on Iris showed that `quad_deadcat` is not the correct mixer because all motors are equally loaded during hover (actuator_outputs 0 to 3 have similar values)  and a negative pitch offset is building up soon after takeoff (visible in actuator_controls). This is not the case with `quad_wide`.    Logs:  - quad_deadcat  simulation: https://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=b7bdae51-dcb8-4b5d-891a-da06136e7080#Nav-Actuator-Controls-0  - quad_deadcat  real flight: https://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=2575c200-200d-410e-b2af-6a55bfa7818b#Nav-Actuator-Controls-0  - quad_wide  simulation: https://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=47ca349b-8ad9-4f07-aeb3-bee98f35e38a#Nav-Actuator-Controls-0  - quad_wide  real flight: TODO    @PX4/testflights Please do a normal test flight on 3DR Iris  just checking there is no regression. You should see a slightly improved behaviour right after take-off (less pitch up moment).

Title: EKF2 Improvements to use of non GPS aiding sources
Body: Requires https://github.com/PX4/ecl/pull/339 to be merged first.    Adds the following capabilities:    1) When navigation is totally reliant on optical flow data  vehicle ground speed is limited in position control modes to respect flow sensor limits.    2) When navigation is totally reliant on optical flow data and the vehicle is in a manual height control mode  the vertical position and velocity set-point is biased if the vehicle is below the flow sensor minimum focal distance to discourage continuous operation below the sensors minimum effective height.    3) Allows for simultaneous use of  intermittent GPS and optical flow provided one or both are working at the same time.    4) Loss of GPS logic in the EKF has been improved so that provided both sideslip and airspeed fusion are active  the EKF can continue to navigate after total loss of GPS. The navigator failsafe logic prevents FW auto modes taking advantage of this  but an operator can now select altitude mode following total GPS loss and fly back to the recovery area using the GCS map and AHRS displays if required.

Title: Cygwin repair NuttX build
Body: after 1f63d85869b3495f3f66a3300b365c57469f1020    all the NuttX specific WINTOOL define handling was skipped in cmake Make.defs generation (#8573)  The Nuttx build is makfile based and needs its cygwin treatment (https://github.com/PX4-NuttX/nuttx/blob/b18053574bf41712cef93e31bf178518f451a350/configs/stm32f4discovery/scripts/Make.defs#L42-L56)    Additionally the ${PX4_SOURCE_DIR}/src/include which was added through cmake needs path conversion    The two root causes for the special handling are:  - ARM GCC for Windows doesn't support cygwin paths passed as an argument    so they need to be either relative or converted via cypath tool  - Symbolic links are totally different under Windows and because NuttX uses them extensively    it has special handling scripts that need to be fed with the correct defines    ---    @dagar Now it's partly makefile `${shell ...}` path conversion like NuttX did it before and partly  cmake `CYGPATH(...)` conversion because you added  `${PX4_SOURCE_DIR}/src/include` via cmake. What do you think?    How was `${PX4_SOURCE_DIR}/src/include` included before? It always found `visibility.h` so it was included but not in the `CFLAGS`...    I tested `make px4fmu-v4_default` and `make px4fmu-v2_default` and they run through fine with these changes.    **EDIT:** For reference the pull requests that made this necessary/possible: #7873 #8573

Title: move posix nuttx qurt components into platforms
Body: This is another small piece of platform organization working towards what's been discussed in https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/8127  https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/7705  https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7806  and https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/7318.    The idea is to consolidate all OS specific pieces under the relevant directory in `platforms`. The build system already knows the OS for a board  so the entire platform can be automatically included  instead of the various scattered module listings per config.        This is roughly how I've been thinking about the organization of the entire firmware.     - boards      - top level sorted by vendor      - each board contains all required pieces (cmake  nuttx-config  board support package  etc)      - boards can be trivially added or removed from the system in one directory      - easy to extend by a 3rd party in or out of tree   - drivers      - platform independent device drivers      - drivers are just modules that can be started  stopped  etc      - anything that isn't a module should move to libraries or a more appropriate layer   - libraries      - "px4" libraries that have access to parameters  uorb  etc      - also contains generic static libraries  that *don't* have access to the PX4 layer      - libraries are included in the build automatically when added as a dependency to a module (we don't have to list them in each cmake config)   - modules      - platform independent flight code      - modules have access to uORB and parameters      - modules can't directly call into other modules  or drivers      - this is the PX4 "flight control library"   - PX4 platform layer      - uORB      - parameters      - data manager      - messages and logging (PX4_INFO  PX4_WARN  etc)   - OS platform layer     - specific support for posix  nuttx  qurt     - includes entire NuttX OS     - little to no OS specific code should be present outside of this layer          There's more platform organization to do  but the next piece I'd like to tackle is centralizing the boards per vendor (https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/8127).     boards    px4        fmu-v2        fmu-v4        fmu-v4pro        fmu-v5

Title: cmake consolidate px4 executable builds
Body: For some reason we had multiple different paths for building the px4 binary on posix  including special cases for sitl where a per model binary was being built (in addition to the regular binary). This might be a bit obnoxious  but I really don't think it makes sense to do this when we can build a single px4 binary that's configured at runtime. The posix startup configuration is a mess  but that should be fixed by unifying the startup  not by further fragmenting for every platform and configuration.    A lot of this scripting (then wrapped in cmake functions) is making simple things seem way more complicated than they actually are.    @DonLakeFlyer this should fix your issue with the typhoon.

Title: CI allow Gazebo to restart on crash
Body: **What's been done:**  * In https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/8804 gzserver crashed upon loading. Adding the ability for it to restart via launch file arg would've allowed the test to recover  preventing the test failure in this case where the vehicle had yet to spawn and the actual test didn't start.    * Along with the above fix  comes the need to catch the exceptions from the `sleep()` method for the various loops. These bring up a separate thread  which if encounter a problem end up raising an exception (signaling a shutdown) which isn't caught by unittest  and leads to the test falsely passing and no logs being generated in some cases. If gzserver restarts after the vehicle spawns and the test starts an exception is thrown for time moving backwards.    * I found a mistake in the error output in the mission tests that I corrected.    ~~**Because I was already changing launch files  this was done also:**~~ (reverted)    * https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/launch/mavros.launch isn't necessary. The dev guide docs point to the use of mavros's px4.launch. This removes having to maintain this here and simplifies the other launch files (no yaml config arguments -- which are on the mavros side anyway).    * Remove the Gazebo `headless` argument. It doesn't do anything. See https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/issues/491    * Remove launch file namespacing in places that don't make sense (to me at least).    * Formatting of the launch files was very inconsistent  this attempts to make them more uniform.    **Questions:**  * There's a collection of old launch files that haven't been touched since 2015. Do they still serve a purpose?    * HippoCampus launch is odd in that two models are told to spawn - one in the world and the other in the launch  causing an error. A pure underwater world should probably exist for use on the ROS side    and a hippocampus world for the `make` side of things (ref https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7888). Also  the launch file is a complete duplicate of mavros_posix_sitl.launch other than the world and vehicle arguments. mavros_posix_sitl.launch should be used with these arguments supplied. I suggest removing hippocampus.launch (less to maintain). Thoughts?    * I need to do more testing with all these changes if the approach is OK. If you want separate PRs or don't agree with some of this let me know.    * Checking if a WP is reached during a mission based on distance doesn't make complete sense as FW (or VTOL in FW mode) doesn't switch at a set value  but rather the calculated turn distance. What is the actual goal of this portion of the test? Do we have it check the mission's current sequence instead to enforce a WP being reached within a certain amount of time? This would be a separate PR  but I figured I'd just ask this here.    * Is there a reason for the urdf xacro generated model to be converted to sdf before spawning the model in single_vehicle_spawn.launch? Why not use the urdf to spawn the vehicle?    @dagar @TSC21

Title: Parameter Notification Improvements
Body: This PR brings a few fundamental improvements to the param system to update it to today's usage: * Support for async changes: Anything happening on the vehicle will now be reflected to the GCS * Support for volatile parameters which are now not any more forcing a complete list re-transfer * Support for categories which allows to convey an intent to the user about what they should be able to change and what not. I also cleaned up minor things along the way some of which might make UAVCAN params more reliable.

Title: ROS launch file cleanup
Body: Most of this was discussed in https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/8817    I picked xmllint as a formatter to make these look uniform (where `$XMLLINT_INDENT="    "`  4 spaces). I dug through the dev guide and didn't find any references to the launch files I removed. I also grep'ed the Firmware repo directory and didn't see any references there either. Some of this will introduce updates to the dev guide (e.g. the removal of `headless`)  which will be made if this looks good.    Some background  copied from the previous discussion:    - https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/launch/mavros.launch isn't necessary. The dev guide docs point to the use of mavros's px4.launch. This removes having to maintain this here and simplifies the other launch files (no yaml config arguments -- which are on the mavros side anyway).  - Remove the Gazebo headless argument. It doesn't do anything. See ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs#491 and https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/379/rename-headless-parameter-to-recording/diff#chg-ros_roslaunch/tutorial.md  - Vehicle and world specific launch files are not necessary. That's what the arguments are for. The others that I'd like to remove are old and depreciated.

Title: Updates to batt_smbus driver to add functionality and work with TI BQ40Z50 R1 R2 fuel gauge
Body: I have updated the batt_smbus driver to work with the TI BQ40Z50-R1/R2 fuel gauges.     Voltage and current are working correctly and using updateBatteryStatus to update uORB.     There are many more values I want to gather from the fuel gauge and get into a mavlink message. Would it be best to add them to battery_status.msg?    updateBatteryStatus in the battery driver is very geared towards battery measurements coming from the on board ADC's. I think it would be worth updating the battery_status.msg through the batt_smbus driver instead.     BATT_SOURCE also needs to be set to 1 to bypass reading the battery ADC's in the sensors.cpp driver.

Title: CI convert missions to QGC plan format
Body: @dagar Do we want to modify/remove vtol_old_3? It was failing CI because the mission doesn't include landing  preventing the current sequence from resetting to 0. I've fixed how the end of the mission is detected  but now  because there is not another mission item  the vehicle begins to steer away from the WP  to loiter around it  causing a "yaw error mean" failure in the post mission check. What makes this mission different from the others is that it uses MAV_CMD_NAV_WAYPOINT to takeoff and goto the first WP.

Title: px4fmu v2 sensor init again and cleanup
Body: This is similar to the fix @svpcom implemented in https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/8703  except instead of forcing to FMU-v2 in a particular error case this PR defaults to treating the board like a traditional FMU-v2 in all cases where a cube or pixhawk mini aren't detected.    I also dropped the BOARD_HAS_SIMPLE_HW_VERSIONING defines because we don't have a build with that disabled.    Checking sensors status for each board. Pass means all expected onboard sensors found.     | Board        | after flash| reboot cmd | reset button  | cold boot  | notes  | ------------- |:-------------:| -----:| -----:| -----:|-----:|  3DR pixhawk (fmu-v2) |  |  |  |  | 2 x accel  2 x gyro  1 x mag  1 x baro  mRo pixhawk (fmu-v2) |  |  |  |  | same  bad hobbyking pixhawk (R635 issue) (fmu-v2) |  |  |  |  | same  new holybro pixhawk (fmu-v3) |  |  |  |  | same  pixhack v3 (fmu-v2) |  |  |  |   |  2 x accel  2 x gyro  1 x baro  internal mag missing  3DR pixhawk 2 (fmu-v2) |  |  | n/a |  | 3 x accel  3 x gyro  2 x mag  2 x baro  reset button not accessible  proficnc pixhawk 2.1 (fmu-v3) |  |  | n/a |  | 3 x accel  3 x gyro  3 x mag  2 x baro  reset button not accessible  3DR pixhawk mini (fmu-v2) |  |  |  |  | Only single IMU present  no mag  1 x baro

Title: Generate mixers from description of multicopter geometry
Body: closes #7382     - adds script that generates multicopter mixer from the geometry of the multicopter. For reference  see this notebook: https://github.com/jlecoeur/servo_mix_matrix/blob/master/servo_mix_matrix.ipynb  - adds folder containing one config file per multicopter geometry  - auto-generates mixers by listing the *.toml files in this directory    - [x] Add geometries      * [x] quad_x      * [x] quad_h       * [x] quad_plus      * [X] quad_v          * dimensions needed .The angles in multi table (18.8  -18.8  -18.8  18.8) make no sense as all motors would be in front of the CG. In this PR https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/253 it says this is the TBS discovery. Can someone provide motors position rel. to CG?          * edit: dropped      * [x] quad_wide          * because of off-centered CG the previous mixer was wrong  but the new one should be correct          * edit: I used the same geomety as SK450 deadcat but moved the cg backward to load all motors equally.      * [x] quad_s250aq          * dimensions needed. This is the Spedix S250AQ.      * [x] quad_deadcat          * for this one I used dimensions of SK450 deadcat  with CG and autopilot at coordinates 0 0 0. But it came out with completely different mixer from mixer_table.      * [x] hex_x      * [x] hex_plus      * [x] hex_cox      * [x] hex_t           * for this one the doc is missing (https://dev.px4.io/en/airframes/airframe_reference.html). It is very similar to hex_cox except the direction for top&bottom motors is reverted -> *should we modify this mixer?          * Also the CG is off-centered rel. to the motors  so the previous mixer was wrong  the new mixer generated with this PR is correct (i.e. the two rear motors are more loaded than the 4 front ones)      * [x] octa_x      * [x] octa_plus      * [x] octa_cox      * [x] octa_cox_wide          * same off-centered CG as quad_wide so the new mixer is not equal to the previous one  it should be correct though. It does not matter anyway because this mixer was not handled in `mixer_multirotor.cpp`       * [x] twin_engine      * [x] tri_y      * [x] dodeca_top_cox      * [x] dodeca_bottom_cox  - [x] Compare output with previous script (i.e `mixer_multirotor_normalized.generated.h` and `mixer_multirotor_legacy.generated.h`  - [x] Fix CI       * [x] Add python-numpy and python-toml to docker images (see https://github.com/PX4/containers/pull/77)      * [x] Add python-numpy and python-toml to documentation (see https://github.com/PX4/Devguide/pull/304)      * [x] Fix jenkins error while puling docker image `px4io/px4-dev-ros:pr-jlecoeur` (no space left on device)      * [x] Fix semaphoreCI error that is going to sleep while building `make px4fmu_firmware`    - [x] Flight tests       * [x] Tested in simulation with jmavsim      * [ ] Real flights on all available multicopter test platforms    For later  the script is ready for 6dof control. There is an option `--sixdof`. For example see the geometry "quad_x_pusher" (or quadplane if you prefer) that has a 5th rotor to generate forward thrust.    @dagar @bresch     ---  edit: for sake of compatibility  the mixer matrices are normalized so that they match the current mixers (see option `--normalized`). However that voids the advantage of modeling dimensions  mass  intertia  and thrust and moment coefficients.  This PR is a first step that introduces the script and the config files. Next independent steps will be to enable 6dof  and to remove normalization.

Title: Work in Progress Nxphlite v3
Body: From: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/6438    This is a WIP for the NXP flight V3 HW based on the K66. It builds but is incomplete as it is missing key Nuttx support in the Kinetis architecture.    The drivers/kinetis/\* is just stubbed out.  There is SPI  or DMA support    Missing Components  - [x]  FPU support in the OS  - [ ] DMA  - [x] SPI - stubbed kinetis_spibus_initialize(int bus);  - [ ] CAN  - [ ] VBAT - for bootloader app commnincation.  - [x] Timers PIT  LPTM  and FTM  PDB - for pwm  capture  tones  and hrt.  - [x] RESET up_systemreset(void) noreturn_function;        Incomplete Drivers:  - [x] PWM supports only 1 chan per timer.  - [x] USB The K66 has 2 USB USB0 is FS (Nuttx has driver) USB1 is HS (No NuttX driver!)   - [ ] UART lacking DMA kinetis_serial_dma_poll(void)  - [x] TERMIOS for serial  - [ ] RTC - up_rtc_getdatetime  - [ ] SDHC DMA disabled will not work with it yet    OS/System dependant SW  - [x] Cannot use FPU yet on kinetis  - [x] Termios  - [x] tcgetattr  - [x] tcsetattr  - [x] cfsetspeed    PX4 FMUV2 Modules removed from build due to No External SPI  - [ ] drivers/bma180  - [ ] drivers/bmi160        NOT Portable YET  - [ ] /Firmware/src/modules/systemlib/mcu_version.c  - [ ] drivers/pwm_input  - [ ] drivers/test_ppm  - [ ] systemcmds/hardfault_log - needs bsram  - [ ] modules/uavcan  - [ ] uavcan  - [ ] uavcan_stm32_driver - need Kinetis CAN driver    PX4 Drivers Needing porting  - [ ] drivers/kinetis/*  - [ ] drv_hrt.c      - [x] HRT      - [x] PPM  - [ ] drv_input_capture.c  - [x] drv_io_timer.c  - [ ] drv_led_pwm.cpp  - [x] drv_pwm_servo.c  - [x] drivers/kinetis/adc  - [x] drivers/kinetis/tone_alarm

Title: Precision Landing from ndepal
Body: @LorenzMeier @ndepal Rebased version of #8160    In addition  I added EKF2 support to select the measurement delay for the landing target estimate  and set it to a default of 5 ms for the IR-Lock. This is necessary for custom setups where the delay is significant.    We also tested this independently with a custom target tracker (which actually takes Gazebo images and runs an algorithm to estimate target pose from it) and everything works pretty good. See demo below.  ![](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o6nUToAodwMGIU0Ks/giphy.gif)    With respect to documentation  we have fairly complete docs from @ndepal and @hamishwillee here : https://docs.px4.io/en/advanced_features/precland.html. We still need to update the current docs with information about EKF2's auxiliary velocity aiding (added after the docs were created).
