In addition  the definition of `STM32_BKP_BASE` is not correct for stm32f7.  This PR also add a missing definition for stm32f7 boards for `up_systemreset()` which was usually included in stm32.h which is not defined for stm32f7 boards.

Title: FlightTasks incremental introduction
Body: This is the follow up to #8874 and the first increment for the more clear introduction of the flight task architecture as discussed in the dev call. ~~Instead of cherry-picking the intricate history of everything I started to just port over file by file such that it should be clear what the different changes really are.~~  ~~We should also try to preserve the authors at least on a file by file basis.~~  **EDIT:** I figured out a different way which very likely results in the least total work: - All the commits until `PositionControl: comment fix + unused parameter removal` are the entire history of the flight task development but without any changes to the file `mc_pos_control.cpp`. This is the key of the method because it kills all conflicts and the changes to this file can be done afterwards. - `Revert "Subscription remove unused instance class member"` was necessary because @dagar removed two memebrs which @bkueng used for the subscription_array implementation. This will change again anyways but we need these members for compatibility right now. - `FlightTasks: comment out mavlink command processing` disables the mavlink command functionality to control tasks because there is no common mavlink message definition for this yet. Sorry if this is not a nice way to just comment it but otherwise dependencies do not make sense anymore and we want this feature available in the future. - `mc_pos_control: refactor ...` are commits which port necessary refactorings into functions with the only logical change of using the matrix library instead of the math library in one place. - `mc_pos_control: refactor  indent control block` is an extra commit to only indent the else block for legacy functionality such that the diff of the commit just after gets readable - `mc_pos_control: enable flight tasks` is the commit finally enabling all the new functionality but only if the pilot sets the parameter `MPC_FLT_TSK` for beta testing like we discussed in the dev call. This probably needs the most careful review to check if anythong legacy might be broken.

Title: WIP Flighttasks
Body: @MaEtUgR I took the time to push the FlightTask logic upstream to make our future life easier. I squash- merged most of the commits  but kept the original author.   Note: a previous version of FlightTask was pushed [here](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7381)  ## Background `FlightTasks` is a framework  for position  velocity  acceleration or thrust set-point related flight maneuvers independent of vehicle type (main author: @MaEtUgR ). Whereas the input to a task can be anything  the output is defined by the `vehicle_local_position_setpoint` [message](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/px4-flighttask/msg/vehicle_local_position_setpoint.msg). The main purpose of `FlightTasks` is to make it much simpler to implement tasks without making changes to the position controller. It is to note that only one  task of `FlightTasks` can be active at a time. However  the framework is designed such that it can benefit well from inheritance.`FlightTasks` is a lib located [here](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/tree/px4-flighttask/src/lib/FlightTasks).   The current goal of `Flightasks` is to move all positioncontrol related maneuvers such as Auto or Manual into `FlightTasks`. To make the position controller truly compatible with `FlightTasks`  the mc_pos_control_main.cpp and eventually also the position controller for fixedwing have to undergo some major re-factor.  In this PR the mc_pos_control_main.cpp already underwent a large re-factor  which however  is only active if the flag `TEST_FLIGHTTASK` [here](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/px4-flighttask/src/modules/mc_pos_control/mc_pos_control_main.cpp#L90) is set to true  otherwise the legacy position controller is used and ANY `FlightTasks`-related task is ignored.   The goal of the re-factor of the position controller is to make it independent of any mode such that it only consumes position  velocity  acceleration or thrust setpoint and outputs a thrust vector. This logic is done in a new class  `PositionControl` [here](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/px4-flighttask/src/modules/mc_pos_control/PositionControl.cpp). The purpose of the old mc_pos_control_main.cpp is then just to make additional adjustments to setpoints that are received from a task or sent out by the PositionControl.cpp (i.e. in idle any setpoint or during ground contact the thrust setpoint in xy-direction are set to 0). Currently  any mc-manual and auto related maneuvers are supported by `FlightTasks`. Offboard and any fixedwing related modes are still missing. In addition  certain corner cases such as estimator related updates need to be considered.   For now it makes sense if anyone who is working on a position related task also considers `FlightTasks`. This framework is not set in stone and most likely will change for reasons such as obstacle avoidance. But it is an intermediate step towards control pipeline that benefits greatly from maintainability

Title: WIP PX4 development environment setup scripts
Body: The idea is to store the development environment setup scripts/instructions in PX4 itself. The documentation can refer to them directly  the PX4 dev docker containers can directly use them  and all aspects will stay in sync and tested.  Which platforms should we cover?  - ubuntu lts  - OSX  - fedora or centos (@davids5)  - arch? (@julianoes @jlecoeur)  - anything for windows? The ubuntu versions should also work within Bash on Windows.  The scripts themselves should be idempotent and be suitable for most developers to run directly and stay in sync. Whenever possible we should make an effort for multiple versions to coexist in parallel. Then developers can jump between branches where official toolchain versions have changed  but still have both compilers.  The installation should be somewhat granular (more or less following the container layout).  - nuttx optional  - raspi and generic armhf?  - fastrtps optional  - gazebo  - ROS (ubuntu only)

Title: BlockParam classes refactoring
Body: The existing BlockParam classes have some issues  which IMO prevent the use of them by default.  * The biggest issues is the memory overhead: each instance has a linked list pointer  a pointer to the vtable (because it contains virtual methods)  and a `param_t` handle (16 bits on NuttX  but because of the memory layout in that specific case  it will still use 32 bits). While the actual data we care about is only 32 bits.  Since we have >1000 params by now and tendency increasing  this will account for several kb's of (wasted) RAM  if those classes are used everywhere. * if the parent naming prefix is used  grepping the src tree for a param name will not find all usages. I already ran into problems because of this. * the parent naming prefix is optional  which makes the API confusing * the namespace name `control` is not appropriate (it's not only used for controllers anymore  so we should rename it). Any ideas?  Otherwise  the existing API is ok  which is why I largely tried to keep it  and only change the deficiencies.  ### Proposed solution Since in the majority of the cases  we know which param we want already at compile-time  I decided to use an enum instead of a string to specify the parameter. This has benefits in terms of runtime (no `param_find()` required)  and memory (no need to store the handle). In addition it's a template parameter  so that the type can be checked at compile-time.  This is how it's used: `BlockParamFloat<px4::params::MPC_MANTHR_MAX> _manual_thr_max`  #### Automatic Parameter updates One thing missing from that is the automatic parameter update calls. As it turns out this is more difficult to achieve without overhead  and minimal boilerplate. What I wanted to do is to iterate over all fields of a struct. This requires a language-feature called Reflection  but C++ does not support that. The closest I found is [this](https://github.com/apolukhin/magic_get)  which aliases a struct as a `tuple` (using lots of template magic so it's quite involved). A [different solution](http://pfultz2.com/blog/2012/07/31/reflection-in-under-100-lines/) uses macros  and I decided to do something similar: the block param definitions are wrapped in a macro  which automatically generates a (virtual) method that calls `.update()` for all params. This is then called as usual from the `Block` base class on a param update notification.  Final usage example (see 4c7d623 ):  ``` DEFINE_BLOCK_PARAMETERS( (BlockParamFloat<px4::params::MPC_MANTHR_MIN>) _manual_thr_min  /**< minimal throttle output when flying in manual mode */ (BlockParamFloat<px4::params::MPC_MANTHR_MAX>) _manual_thr_max ) ```  #### Potential programming/user errors The use of a macro can lead to some usage errors:  * forget to use the macro or use the block param classes outside of the macro.  Avoided by placing the class definitions into a special namespace  that makes it clear that it should not be used explicitly. In addition  we can add a class definition outside the namespace  that leads to a clear compile error message (using a `static_assert`)  that the macro should be used instead. * In a custom class hierarchy  the child class must call the `updateParams` method of the parent. But C++ does not have a way to generically find the parent class'es name  so the macro cannot do that automatically. Instead  the macro marks the method as `final`  so that a wrong usage will lead to a compile error  forcing the user to use the extended macro  with explicit parent class (however this use-case is rather atypical  and I don't think we have it currently in our code-base).  #### Benefits   * param type statically checked (type-safety w/o runtime overhead) * no invalid param handles anymore: A used param is guaranteed to be included in the build * reduced memory usage. The new interface is even better than the typical uses of the C API  since no param handle is stored. A block param really only requires the storage of the param (float or int32) * reduced runtime overhead: no `param_find()` & linked list operations -> faster bootup * the default constructor can be used (no additional code in the constructor's initializer list of the SuperBlock required) * src tree can still be grepped for parameter names  #### Drawbacks   * no dynamic parameter names (the templated enum requires the param name to be known at compile-time). But we only use dynamic strings at a few places  and we can still use the C API for those. * no arrays possible (BlockParamFloat _mag_params[3]). Currently only used once in ekf2 * the need for a macro  which is not so nice  Note that this only shows the basic working example  and will require additional cleanup.  Sorry  this description got way longer than expected.  Thoughts?

Title: commander add parameters for eph eph evh thresholds

Title: CI mavros restart
Body: This adds the `respawn_mavros` arg introduced in mavros 0.23.2. Now that we've updated CI containers with 04ecc81a70232d89bea5d3284b6c878e388fc895 we can make use of it. Before and with `respawn_mavros=false`  all nodes in the launch file will be killed if mavros dies. Setting this to `true` restarts mavros and lets the other nodes continue to live. This will harden CI against potential issues with mavros. The only negative here  which I feel is not an issue  is if users try to use `mavros_posix_sitl.launch` or any of the `.test` files with a version of mavros<0.23.2  they will see an error from roslaunch and it will fail to launch.

Title: Improve the Crazyflie MAVLink tunnel to increase efficiency
Body: This change fragments MAVLink packets more efficiently and therefore increases the net throughput. This in turn makes the connection significantly more stable and the Crazyflie experience overall more usable.  Replaces https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/9232

Body: This makes it trivial to keep everything updated and pointed at the right thing (valid commit  correct branch  etc).      git submodule update --init --force --remote .

Title: Filled CRTP messages with mavlink packets to save space
Body: Instead of packing header  payload and checksum of a mavlink message in separate CRTP messages  I packed them into one to save space in buffers and send less bytes/second to the crazyradio. This helps decrease data traffic and hence data loss.

Title: Pr wind est work queue
Body: This is a replacement of #9041 and implements the standalone wind and airspeed scale factor estimator as a work queue. Previously  the estimator was living in the sensors module which did not really make sense.  Advantages:  - the estimator is now a separate module and can be run only for VTOL and fixed wing configs - we can extend this module to take data of multiple airspeed sensors and run multiple estimators and then use this information for airspeed failure detection  Disadvantages: - we have some overhead in terms of memory due to the work queue and the fact that we need to subscribe to three topics  one of them is local_position which is rather large  @dagar @priseborough FYI

Title: Breakout rc mavlink from rcS create MAVLINK_DEVICE_X variables and restructure
Body: Hi   This PR attempts to create a more generic framework for configuring mavlink streams/devices and reduce the complexity of the rcS script.  Relevant sections of the rcS script have been moved to rc.mavlink and board specific logic has been simplified/condensed to allow future migration toward a simpler  generic method for configuring multiple mavlink streams/devices.  The implementation framework accommodates the legacy SYS_COMPANION parameter specific logic while allowing future users to configure mavlink device settings within their configuration specific scripts without creating additional SYS_COMPANION values and new logic in the rc.mavlink file.   Currently  script variables are in place for setting up 2 unique MAVLINK devices  baud rates  and command line arguments  but this model can easily be extended to accommodate additional stream configurations.  Last  I've relocated all rcS script variable set statements at the beginning of the file  and all unset statements at the end of the file so that accounting for unsetting all script variables is more easily achieved.  This is to avoid the condition of a subscript setting a variable after it has been unset higher up in the rcS script  then not being unset again before the script has finished executing.  (I have only been able to test this PR on one board configuration  so some assistance is kindly requested for testing additional board configurations.)  Thanks for your review  and please let me know what questions you have on the PR!  -Mark

Title: Fix astyle Display Language Dependency Makefile Colored Output
Body: This PR solves two problems which I found during Cygwin Toolchain usage:  - **astyle check passes in any case** The shell script which checks the style relies on greping for the keyword "Formatted" in the output of astyle. But the program has localization support and will output in other languages e.g. german. This leads to all style checks always succeeding. I only tested this on Windows in Cygwin but I can imagine the problem also exists on non-english Ubuntu installations. **Solution:** is the parameter --formatted of astyle which only produces any output if there was something to fix. This allows for a display language independent condition for an empty string inside the shell script.  - **Makefile colors do not work** e.g. `\033[0;34mFormatting with astyle \033[m` Certain terminal combinations like cygwin - mintty - xterm - bash do not escape colors by default. **Solution:** Force interpretation of backslash escapes with the parameter -e of echo.  I also switched the colored messages to a lighter blue (94 instead of 34) because in certain terminals default blue is hard to read on black background while on linux both blues were easy to read (see pictures).  ![terminal1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4668506/39757751-146deae2-52ce-11e8-8d97-4d014704a878.JPG) ![terminal2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4668506/39757750-1453e606-52ce-11e8-82be-f0f1a8bac104.JPG)

Title: Cygwin Enable ARM NuttX Upload within Cygwin Environment
Body: In the Cygwin environment the native Windows serial COM# ports get mapped to /dev/ttyS# for POSIX compatibility. While # is one number lower inside the environment than the COM port number because it's 0 indexed instead of 1.  I added the necessary handling to all the dependent parts I found which allows uploading to /dev/ttyS# when the cygwin platform is detected. Now the usual `make px4fmu-v4 upload` and `./Tools/upload.sh build/px4fmu-v4_default/px4fmu-v4_default.px4` work.

This PR partially reverts #9372 and creates a second optional MPU device for the px4fmu-v4.  Note: this is still horrible  we need to find a better way to split the drivers and board configurations.

Title: cmake remove circular linking and reorganize
Body: PX4 is supposed to be modular  but because of the current cmake build system everything is built and linked together as a large pile of code. The lines between different modules and different layers of the system have become blurred in many cases.  This PR changes the PX4 cmake build slightly to allow us to actually enforce and maintain modularity. We can then tease apart some of these interconnected components and work towards more well defined layers (https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/8784#issue-166153775).   First instead of calling everything a module (px4_add_module) and linking it all together (with multiple passes to resolve circular dependencies) I changed px4_add_module to require a MAIN. Any modules included in a configuration (eg nuttx_px4fmu-v2_default.cmake) are included in the final PX4 binary. Modules without a main are now simply libraries (px4_add_module -> px4_add_library). Some libraries are part of PX4 and need access to uORB  the parameter system  logging system  etc (PX4 libraries: px4_add_library)  but many don't (regular cmake: add_library).   Libraries aren't automatically included (linked) in your final PX4 binary  they must be added as a module dependency. As a result we don't need to list them per configuration. Including a particular module pulls in a library only if it's needed as a dependency. With that dependency comes additional include directories and build flags if specified by the library.  ## PX4 CMake Changes  **px4_add_module (PX4 Modules)**  - now requires MAIN  - access to uORB  params  and other libraries  - name is defined for the logging system (PX4_INFO  PX4_WARN  PX4_ERR)  - no access to other modules by default  **px4_add_library (PX4 libraries)**  - access to PX4 uORB  params  etc  - not linked to final binary by default  must be a dependency (DEPENDS) of a module  - name is defined for the logging system (PX4_INFO  PX4_WARN  PX4_ERR)  - use INTERFACE to specify include directories  build flags  etc that should be used by the module  - can use other libraries (PX4 or not)  **add_library**  - use for regular libraries that shouldn't have access to anything PX4 specific (uORB  params  etc)  - can't use logging system (PX4_INFO  PX4_WARN  PX4_ERR)  - not linked to final binary by default  must be a dependency (DEPENDS) of a module  **cmake configurations**  - all libraries (src/lib) are automatically included in every build  - only the ones that are dependencies of PX4 modules (px4_add_module DEPENDS) are actually built  - other common pieces (eg src/drivers/boards/${BOARD}) are also included automatically now  - this removes the need for every cmake configurations to exhaustively list every component and core system piece. Modules are specified directly  and then the libraries are pulled in as dependencies.   - example  here's how the px4fmu-v2 configuration (nuttx_px4fmu-v2_default.cmake) is simplified.     - ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84712/38652047-370359b8-3dd2-11e8-88d7-a0e1d63b7cf8.png)  This also removes the need to link with `--start-group/--end-group` to resolve the circular dependencies.       ## Notes  * A few ideas taken from [CppCon 2017: Mathieu Ropert Using Modern CMake Patterns to Enforce a Good Modular Design](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eC9-iRN2b04).    - declare all properties per target (PRIVATE  PUBLIC  or INTERFACE)      - target_link_libraries for dependencies (somewhat poorly named  but very useful)      - target_compile_defintions      - target_compile_options      - target_include_directories    - forbid/report circular and hidden dependencies    - build interfaces are transitive    - help developer reason at module level   * Related issues and PRs https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/8784#issue-166153775  https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/8127  https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/7705  https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7806  and https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/7318

Title: Pr fmuv5 i2c fixes
Body: This PR is related to the board config of fmu-v5. It removes PX4_i2C_BUS_EXPANSION2 because describes same bus as PX4_I2C_BUS_ONBOARD and it is never used because it only connects to the onboard mag and is not exposed on the external connectors.   What used to be PX4_i2C_BUS_EXPANSION3 now because PX4_i2C_BUS_EXPANSION2.  Moreover in all drivers in that there is the bus_option[] I added PX4_i2C_BUS_EXPANSION1 and PX4_i2C_BUS_EXPANSION2 in order to support all i2c busses on fmu-v5.

Title: Use Nuttx defconfig defines to determine arch
Body: These hard coded paths assume all Nuttx targets are ARMv7-M targets. Updating them to use ${CONFIG_ARCH} and ${CONFIG_ARCH_FAMILY} instead allows for the architecture defined by the incoming Nuttx defconfig to be correctly targeted.

Title: Fix broken links to pixhawk org
Body: This fixes broken links to pixhawk.org (either never existed or removed in latest update).   There remain some open issues: 1. In \Firmware\README.md we have link to https://pixhawk.org/modules/stm32f4discovery - is the discovery kit still available  used  or useful? If not will delete that line. 2. There are links in \Tools\px_uploader.py and \Firmware\src\systemcmds\ver\ver.c to silicon errata doc (which says). ``` FMUv2 / Pixhawk Silicon Errata STM32F427VIT6 (errata) Flash Bank 2 and full speed USB device exclusive Silicon revisions up to rev 1 (revision 3 is the first not affected) can produce errors / data corruption when accessing the 2nd flash bank while there is activity on PA12  which is one of the USB data lines. There is no workaround / software fix for this  except to not use the flash bank #2. Since USB is needed to program the device  Pixhawk revisions built with silicon revisions < rev 3 can only use up to 1MB of the 2MB flash of the microprocessor. ``` Should that section just go in the Pixhawk 1 doc  or do we need a whole specific topic for silicon errata? If we need a unique topic can that go in the user guide  or would it need to go in pixhawk.org?  3.  `\src\modules\systemlib\circuit_breaker.h` Line 47:  ``` * SAFETY WARNING  --  SAFETY WARNING  --  SAFETY WARNING  *  * OBEY THE DOCUMENTATION FOR ALL CIRCUIT BREAKERS HERE   * ENSURE TO READ CAREFULLY ALL SAFETY WARNINGS.  * http://pixhawk.org/dev/circuit_breakers  *  * CIRCUIT BREAKERS ARE NOT PART OF THE STANDARD OPERATION PROCEDURE  * AND MAY DISABLE CHECKS THAT ARE VITAL FOR SAFE FLIGHT.  */ ``` But the line "http://pixhawk.org/dev/circuit_breakers" just points generically to the devguide. Perhaps point it to the devguide parameter reference?

Title: launch fix for px4 shutdown
Body: The problem mentioned here https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/9667 was masked with a failure message that wasn't the actual issue. If we make the PX4 node required in the launch  we can see that the shutdown is what caused the test to stop. Setting the required arg means "If node dies  kill entire roslaunch." This makes sense to have because you can't do anything if the firmware dies anyway. In the case of our failure  PX4 died and the test continued to run  eventually failing because there were no messages being received  due to MAVROS having no connection to the FCU.  The fix for the problem has been merged in already https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/9672. This only helps to correctly identify future issues of the same nature.  Here is what the error message looks like with this PR (note that it says "ROS shutdown request"): ![screenshot from 2018-06-14 12-19-43](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10533707/41440637-490c0e54-6ffd-11e8-8998-7fc9e75057fe.png)

Title: Obstacle avoidance interface
Body: This PR is a first iteration of the interfaces to receive a collision free path from a obstacle avoidance system and to send a path a planned path  e.g. mission  to the obstacle avoidance. It follow the proposal: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1BQp1a6yszl9f6LDrxrkKUDDGyXxBs5C86BzvJwVbRrU/edit?usp=sharing The interface could also be use by a trajectory generator.   Needs: https://github.com/mavlink/mavlink/pull/856   <del> I have defined a parameter `ENABLE_OBSTACLE_AVOIDANCE` to disable by default the execution of obstacle avoidance waypoints. It needs a proper implementation  possibly a parameter that can be changed in QGC. </del> To enable obstacle avoidance set parameter `MPC_OBS_AVOID` to `TRUE`  Tests: - tested position waypoints in simulation with local planner - tested velocity waypoints on hardware  FYI: @Stifael  @ChristophTobler @dagar @thomasgubler   @LorenzMeier

E.g. Title: ecl ekf tools set exit code to 1 if the log analysis fails CI check fails for failing SITL log analyis
Body: This pull request sets the exit code of the log analysis script to -1 if the analysis detects a failure in the flight log. The CI check will therefore fail  if the log analysis of a SITL flight fails. The pr adds two additional small changes (see details below).  - `process_logdata_ekf`: exit with code -1 if whole system analysis fails - `batch_process_logdata` and `process_logdata_ekf`: add arguments for analyzing without a sensor safety margin to forward  the default mode will still stay as it used to - reduce the minimum necessary log length for the analysis to 50 samples (at the moment the analysis is not performed for logs that have less than 100 innovation samples)

Title: px4_base switch visibility h back to relative include path
Body: The include path of `visibility.h` was recently changed back to absolute here: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/commit/83fd5a5fd1e5d35f8c705b43cb61e81f825136bd    The Cygwin toolcahin does not find the file with this absolute path generation and hence master does not build anymore.    Can we merge this pr and change it back to relative? It was changed to realtive before: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/commit/3f0653e824949f5e991bc279d9f1f4749a7914c0#diff-5f4402a03edacf409e7501a9039d3392R582    **What's the advantage of the absolute path here?**    Alternatively I could add an extra absolute path generation dealing with cygpath conversion that does not break under Cygwin but I'd like to avoid that.

Title: FlightTask Introduction Replace Legacy Multicopter Position Controller
Body: It's a follow up to #9253 and #9368.  I rebased all changes to any FlightTasks and the PositionControl logic and left out all the changes to the `mc_pos_control_main.cpp` file because of nasty rebase conflicts. Then in the last commit "mc_pos_control: replace legacy functionality" I switched the mc_pos_control file to the new refactored version that does not contain any unwanted  replaced legacy code anymore. Note: The original changes are mostly by @Stifael as correctly represented in the metadata.  We know what's missing right now is:  - [x] Porting changes that happened to the position controller in the meantime to FlightTasks       See any of these sources:       - [History in June](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/commits/master/src/modules/mc_pos_control/mc_pos_control_main.cpp)       - The file `src/modules/mc_pos_control/mc_pos_control_main.cpp` in this diff: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/compare/Legacy-Auto-Manual-replacement...master       - The only prs that did changes: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/9613 and https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/9630  closes #9368

Title: Minimal HW manifest support need for FMUv5
Body: Platforms that provide HW versioning tend to have more FLASH and can have a PX4IO as an option.     (E.G.) FMUv5. This change provides run time  decision to control the safety switch on     platforms that have BOARD_HAS_VERSIONING and support a manifest. (FMUv5)       On platforms with no versioning and have BOARD_HAS_STATIC_MANIFEST defined as a 1     The decision is compile time only. When a PX4IO is present the fmu control of the safety is     not built.

Title: Core rearchitecture for modularity
Body: Layout was modified to be consistent and enable platform support to be separated into git repos and to add vendor collections of build targets.    The New vendor layout allows external git repos to be mapped in under vendor/ and will be automatically integrated into the PX4 build platform.  ```  vendor/   ATLFlight       cmake       CMakeLists.txt       multi.conf       posix        cmake         posix_sdflight_default.cmake         posix_sdflight_legacy.cmake        eagle         board_config.h         config_default.cmake Title: Bash scripting for posix
Body: ## tl;dr  This adds bash scripting for POSIX. The startup file is now evaluated by bash. Additionally  PX4 commands can be sent from other terminals  allowing commands such as `px4-commander status` or `px4-listener sensor_combined` from anywhere on the machine. ## Description  This PR adds the possibility to spawn PX4 modules out of bash. Basically  the main executable can now be started as a server/daemon or as a client. The server replaces the existing functionality of the main exe with the pxh shell  however  it also opens a pipe that clients can talk to.  Clients can run or spawn PX4 modules or commands by connecting to the server over the pipe. They clients will get the stdout and return value of their commands via a client specific pipe back.  The main exe starts as a server and runs a startup script using bash. Each command in the startup script such as 'commander start' gets aliased with a prefix as 'px4-commander start' and symlinked to the px4 main executable. If the main executable is called with the prefix 'px4-' which is passed in `argv[0]`  it will act as a client and therefore send the command 'commander start' to the server. Once this command has been run in the server  the client will receive the return value and the bash script will continue with the next command.  Additionally  this allows commands to be sent from outside pxh  so from other terminals (on the same computer). All that is needed is to have the px4 exe and the symlinks in the PATH.  Thanks to @bkueng for the big help.  Let me know what you think: @jgoppert  @LorenzMeier  @dagar  @mcharleb   Adresses: #4800 ## Progress to get this PR in - [x] Main SITL startup transferred to unified rcS startup script - [ ] Additional SITL startups into rcS - [ ] Check CI on jenkins - [x] Script Snapdragon startup - [ ] Script Bebop startup - [ ] Script Raspberry Pi startup - [ ] Upload mixers - [ ] Stress test whole system with some scripts - [x] Allow listener to keep looping - [ ] Add Devguide documentation ## Future work after this PR - Unify NuttX and Posix startup ## How to test ### SITL  The normal SITL startup already uses the new unified SITL startup script rcS  it can get started with:  ``` make posix gazebo ```  ``` make posix jmavsim ```  To send a command in another terminal window  adapt the PATH:  ``` export PATH=$PATH:~/src/Firmware/build_posix_sitl_default/bin ```  and send a command:  ``` px4-commander status ```  Or listen to a uORB message:  ``` px4-listener vehicle_attitude ```  Press Ctrl+C to exit. ### Snapdragon  To test this on Snappy  just build and upload normally:  ``` make eagle_default upload ```  Open adb shell  and start it with:  ``` cd /home/linaro/bin export PATH=$PATH:/home/linaro/bin ./px4 rcS ```  Then choose  the airframe config using the param SYS_AUTOSTART and restart. The current options are:  ``` SYS_AUTOSTART 4100: generic (flight) Quad SYS_AUTOSTART 4200: Microheli 200QX ```

Title: Posix shell switch from bash to bin sh
Body: This switches to use the system's default shell  as not all systems have bash available (and we should not depend on bashism in our scripts).  - improves portability  - on ubuntu /bin/sh is mapped to `dash`  which is a minimalistic POSIX-compliant shell. This makes it a good testing candidate  so that we don't start to depend on shell-specific features.  - when bash is invoked as /bin/sh  it operates in POSIX mode (changes are [here](https://tiswww.case.edu/php/chet/bash/POSIX)).  - [[ is bashism -> use [  - NuttX shell scripts: replace operator == with = (POSIX only defines = and NuttX supports both)  -  module_schema: enforce serial config param names to end in _CONFIG or _CFG (unrelated change)    @bartslinger fyi    EDIT: tested on NuttX and SITL Linux (bash & dash)

Title: Fix catkin build of PX4 Firmware
Body: Replaces #10573.    Ended up being simpler than first thought  after @dagar suggested to play with `BUILD_SHARED_LIBS` CMake variable.    The problem with catkin is that it explicitly sets `BUILD_SHARED_LIBS` if not explicitly overridden by the user (https://github.com/ros/catkin/blob/kinetic-devel/cmake/tools/libraries.cmake#L12). This means that  by default  catkin tries to build all libraries added by `add_library()` as shared libraries  which ends up breaking the build system were some targets expect static libraries.    This also avoids adding explicit includes on the top CMake module of PX4.    Adds also CI based on #9679 (@dagar I tried to cherry-pick but didn't work as I expected).

Title: Bebop 2 improved control gains and force failsafe
Body: I've done some tuning on the PID settings on Bebop 2. It flies much better now  see video https://youtu.be/SsnzYhiuWiE. Still a little bit of overshoot in yaw  but not excessive. Also the frame is not very rigid  so you literally see it twisting when yawing. More agressive yaw control is tricky with such a flexible frame.    I also disabled the rangefinder for now  because it has real-time problems. When it is enabled  the compass notifies me sometimes that a frame was skipped. The compass runs at 100Hz and is polled at 200Hz. It looks like something within the rangefinder driver occupies the driver framework thread for more than 10ms.    Another minor addition: shut down motors on `armed.force_failsafe`. I added this to be able to kill the motors on a geofence violation (terminate).

Title: WIP cmake minimize module list
Body: As a very small part of an ongoing effort to improve the extensibility and modularity of PX4 this PR updates the build system to reduce the per config module list. Components needed for a particular platform are automatically included. Libraries aren't listed at all anymore  but instead are automatically included and only built + linked if added by a PX4 module's DEPENDS.     - all libraries included automatically   - only the ones listed by a module's DEPENDS are built and linked    Initially started here. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/8139

Title: WIP High rate IMU sampling
Body: Continuing https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7446. @dagar @priseborough @jgoppert . I needed a better idea about vibration in a system and this is a good start. This is also one step towards https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7446#issuecomment-354678120  This still suffers from missing DMA/FIFO access. But I was able to log unfiltered data from 2 IMUs at 2kHz  which is already pretty nice. And you can publish gyro control messages at 2kHz as well  but in that case the MC attitude controller uses 22% CPU ;)  This is NOT test flown  I'm really just bench testing at the moment.  Tasks / open questions - [x] really disable DLPF - [x] separation done for MPU6000 and MPU9250 - [x] separate gyro message for control and estimation - [x] add message to log unfiltered (but NOT raw) data for spectral analysis - [ ] clip detector (should that be done in the driver?) - [ ] do everything for the rest of gyro/accel drivers - [ ] optimize message used for estimation: do we need RAW data there? (do we need to publish raw data at all?) - [ ] add interface for new driver options (e.g. to enable unfiltered publishing) - [ ] check ISR load  probably the cause for increased CPU load in every task when increasing the publishing rates - [ ] read data with DMA/FIFO  Is that going into the right direction? @dagar you mentioned you could help with DMA?

Title: VTOL standard transition improvements
Body: This PR allows TECS to run during vtol standard transition to FW if altitude control is enabled. During the transition TECS is configured with a speed weight of 0 (100% height rate priority) and underspeed disabled. This gives it control of throttle and pitch to maintain altitude  while the MC controller is still responsible for throttle. Once FW transition completes there's no abrupt transfer.    Additionally we can disable the blending entirely (airspeed or time based) as the MC motors will automatically fade out. The airspeed and time based blending are still preserved for transitions without altitude control enabled.    Opening now for early review and discussion. There's a lot more that can be done from here  including significant back transition improvements.

Title: Do Not Merge Yet Better bss alignment can saves up to 250ish bytes
Body: Changing the alignment of the .bss section to 4. As it appears the default was 256.    This is a proper fix for running out of [memory on the PX4IO](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/commit/6ef2ae29993c02f926c8719d29d84202b1fe3142)    The issue there was not adding the ALIGN() in the correct place in the linker script. This set of commits does that.

Title: Fix dataman and allow more waypoints
Body: The dataman started overwriting contents after 256 items because the  item index were only uint8_t. This fix allows for more than 256  waypoints.    Since using more than 256 mission items has been tested and fixed  the  limit can now be raised to more than 256 (but smaller than UINT16_MAX).    Since the whole file is allocated in advance on NuttX  the limit there  is (arbitrarily) set to 2000. For POSIX archs such as SITL  we don't  really need to constrain ourselves any longer.    Found together with @bkueng.  You might be interested to review @AndreasAntener  I think  you asked in the past what the state was.    Tested with up to 65000 mission items using SITL and 400 on a Pixracer.    @LorenzMeier am I missing any architecture setup to test?

Title: WIP Param backend replace utarray with HashMap
Body: Utarray uses the struct memory address as a key in a hashtable. This means we have to pass around the object instances to reference things like params and topics. This switches the backend to HashMap that does string based hashing. It will allow us to directly implement a ROS like api for param management.    I plan to keep everything 100% backwards compatible  but change the param handles to be strings internally and for new code to just uses the strings directly.    @stephanbro FYI    ### TODO    * [x] Add HashMap submodule  * [x] Move param.c to param.cpp  * [x] Create HashMap for params  * [ ] Change backend to use HashMap

Title: WIP mc_pos_control triplet handling for mc
Body: currently the handling of the triplet setpoint in mc_pos_control_main is rather confusing. In addition  the coupling of vtol to mc makes it also hard to distinguish what is important for vtol and what not. Following the discussion from here #6681  the triplet handling for simple point to point motions are implemented too complicated. Setting the desired current setpoint as the desired position is enough. There should not be any additional slewrate applied to the position. It is completely fine to have a position setpoint step. The velocity limit is applied  already at the output of the position controller.   For the handling of waypoints  I can see the benefit of incorporating the previous and next setpoint  but I would completely split the implementation depending on vtol and normal mc (maybe that is already the case  but it is not obvious to me). Also  instead of having this position setpoint adjustment  I suggest to apply normal position control perpendicular to the line between previous and current setpoint and velocity feedforward in the velocity controller. the velocity feedforward vector can be computed from bezier curve which also incorporates max acceleration. I know how to do trajectory based on bezier curve for mc  but not for vtol and that is another reason why I would split the implementation entirely. obviously with vtol I mean when in fixedwing mode.

Title: Do Not Merge pwm experiment on v2
Body: The first commit - will ensure a transition from PWM to another mode will not extend a PWM pulse when the drive from the FMU pin is stopped.    The second commit holds the FMU_CHn lines Low for 40 Ms prior to a rest from a reboot command or shutdown API call. There is no delay on a board reset from Power on.    When the HW has the TXs0108 the Async reset can terminate a PWM pulse early or shortly after the end of the last PWM pulse as seen below: Note the little spikes on Trace 02 & 03 are for debug.    At the Spike on Trace 02 the Async reset is pulling the FMU_CHn lines Low. But it will only stay low for 58uS. Then be followed by a 3.12 ms high pulse caused by the GPIO input float time from reset until GPIO is initialized on the CPU's slow clock.    ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1945821/25681410/ed3ffbb0-2fef-11e7-8230-96d91184191d.png)    This PR has a fix for this. We sleep the CPU once the lines are low for 40Ms.   A1 is the Async reset.  There is a 40+ ms Low and a 3.12 MS high at A2      ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1945821/25681397/dde7ee84-2fef-11e7-926e-6c9a2713713d.png)

Title: Pr flt task arch
Body: @Stifael @MaEtUgR @bkueng  I want to propose some slight changes to the flight task library:  The output of flight task is now a private struct of the base class and contains the setpoints The derived classes each implement one setter function which gets a reference to the struct from the base class and fill in the values. The advantage is that it's very clear where in the code the setpoint is changed as to before where each instance could alter the setpoint anywhere since it was a protected member.  Instead of using generic functions like updateSetpoints or scaleSticks I increased the granularity of the method set and gave them names which precisely tell you what they do  e.g. calculateYawSetpoint(float&yaw_setpoint) or calculateThrustXY(Vector2f& thrust_sp). This also avoids doing calculations in base classes and then overriding half of the calculations in the derived classes. One example was the altitude control flight task which used the stabilized flight task to calculate the thrust vector only to override it again (it only needed the yaw).  I've test flown all flight tasks in SITL except  Orbit and Sport which I have not ported yet.  I'm not yet sure if this is the best way to go so let me know what you think.

Title: Trajectory generator fixes
Body: ### Context: The trajectory generator (called VelocitySmoothing here) is basically an optimizer that tries to find an optimal jerk signal of fixed amplitude to control each output of a chain of two integrators (i.e.: control acceleration and velocity) while minimizing the time to reach the desired state and satisfying maximum acceleration.  ### Problem: When the defined jerk is large and the velocity/acceleration targets are small  the problem cannot be solved given the fixed time interval (this is a discrete-time problem). The drone sometimes keeps drifting while the stick is centered because the velocity is non-zero.  ### Proposed solution: When the velocity and acceleration are small  decrease the jerk (set it to 1) such that the optimizer can find a new solution and move closer to zero. Once the outputs are small enough  force them to 0.  ### Other changes: - Some division by 0 and sqrt of negative number protections. - A simple script that uses the VelocitySmoothing library. This is used to debug the code  verify the outputs and compare them to the original python script. The next step is to run a true unit test to compare the outputs automatically.

Title: Port PX4 to BeagleBone Blue Board using library librobotcontrol instead of a submodule
Body: James Strawson  the creator of https://github.com/StrawsonDesign/librobotcontrol  helped to make some changes to facilitate the change of package usage in this porting from a submodule to a library.  Corresponding DriverFramework pull request (https://github.com/PX4/DriverFramework/pull/228) was also updated to use librobotcontrol in form of a library instead of a submodule.   The porting code is constructed in the way that it won't break builds of other configuration targets while allow build of BeagleBone Blue target with some manual setup which is not complicated.  It seems that currently librobotcontrol debian package is only available on BeagleBoard products. Here are the ways to obtain the librobotcontrol on BeagleBone Blue (and Black): 1) use the one pre-installed in  BeagleBoard images 2) install from debian package or repository (sudo apt update && sudo apt install librobotcontrol) 3) install from source     git clone https://github.com/StrawsonDesign/librobotcontrol.git     cd librobotcontrol     sudo make install  After acquiring the pre-built library         a) select and define LIBROBOTCONTROL_INSTALL_DIR environment variable so that other unwanted headers will not be included       b) install robotcontrol.h and rc/* into $LIBROBOTCONTROL_INSTALL_DIR/include       c) install pre-built native (ARM) version of librobotcontrol.* into $LIBROBOTCONTROL_INSTALL_DIR/lib  then the BeagleBone Blue target can be built on both cross compile host system and native build system  e.g.  make posix_bbblue_cross [upload | upload_px4].

Title: Windows CI on Appveyor
Body: This PR is based on my initiative to support PX4 developent under Windows and @dagar 's request to have CI to inform everyone automatically when a change breaks that support. Reference: #10002   **Solution:** I created an `appveyor.yml` CI script that when enabling the [Appveyor CI service](https://www.appveyor.com/) for the PX4 Firmware repository automatically builds it under Windows. Appveyor in particular is used because it's a convenient cloud service host supporting Windows builds and it offers a free service usage with a certain amount of resources to open source projects.  **Details:** - It downloads and uses the latest Cygwin Toolchain installer which is described in the Devguide here: http://dev.px4.io/en/setup/dev_env_windows_cygwin.html Hence it exactly reproduces the recommended way to build natively under Windows. - It caches the MSI installer file (496MB) on the Appveyor server to prevent huge amounts of duplicate downloading from AWS S3. - It sets up the environmental variables exactly as the scripts do for your local usage without using any Appveyor specific feature other than the bare metal Windows 10 machine. - It builds the `posix` (SITL) and `px4fmu-v4` (to test NuttX build) targets with a complete execution time of ~13 min. Other tests can be added in the future. - The installer itself uses ~3.5 min but has to be executed everytime because the free build cache is 1GB which the complete toolchain folder exceeds. Also I'm not if the Appveyor cache extracting of that many files would be actually any faster.  **Conclusion:** I suggest to enable this CI even if we might find any better solution. As stated the process itself is not dependend on Appveyor and the gained experience setting this up could be used on any CI automated Windows machine e.g. a jenkins slave. I'm happy to look into that later on if I get some support to integrate it with [ci.px4.io](http://ci.px4.io/).  The output of the successful build of this pr (and hence currently latest master) is available here: https://ci.appveyor.com/project/MaEtUgR/firmware-b5mk6/build/25  closes #10002

Title: PX4FMU V4 IMU Heater Driver
Body: Hello   This PR introduces a driver for heating the IMU in PX4FMU-V4  (and presumably can be utilized in the future with other boards as well).  The driver has been used for the past 6 months for hundreds of flight hours at environmental temperatures between -20C and +40C and typically maintains +/-0.05C in our application.  It is likely that this PR may generate additional useful insight into the construction of the driver and we welcome your feedback.  Let me know your comments and suggestions on this PR.  Thanks!  -Mark

Title: adis16477 probe and reset
Body: The ADIS16477 seems to require more time than specified in the datasheet to initialize after a reset. This PR moves the RESET (via RST pin) to the board initialization (to maximize the time before probe) and cleans up the probe and reset logic in the ADIS16477 driver. The ADIS16477 debug output has also been left on for now until there's a more definitive answer.

Title: Firmware is not able to compile due to conflicting optimization flags
Body: **Describe problem solved by the proposed pull request**  Firmware is not able to compile without this change with recent gcc. The flags are redundant at least with gcc  so I just removed them. If there's a better way of handling this let me know.  Eg:  ``` msg/topics_sources/uORBTopics.cpp:1:0: error: switch -mcpu=cortex-m7 conflicts with -march=armv7e-m switch [-Werror]  /****************************************************************************  compilation terminated due to -Wfatal-errors. ```  **Describe your preferred solution**  Removed conflicting optimization flags (they're redundant anyway).   **Describe possible alternatives**  alternative 1: ignore the issue     side effects: project will not be compilable using recent gccs.  alternative 2: silence the warning     side effects: gross  **Additional context** Add any other context or screenshots for the feature request here.

Title: cmake toolchain don t specify both mcpu and march
Body: Specifying both `-march` and `-mcpu` is redundant and makes certain versions of GCC unhappy. The `-march` switch selects a "generic" CPU  and `-mcpu` specifically sets a cortex-m3/m4/m7 CPU.  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84712/43686603-a8228cda-9896-11e8-89a5-ea790fb3aab3.png)  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84712/43686606-ae3148aa-9896-11e8-88a8-b5d8b5f719f3.png)  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84712/43686611-b550140e-9896-11e8-8b78-a3451ba377c6.png)  I've verified this PR produces identical binaries before and after (px4io-v2  px4fmu-v2  px4fmu-v5).   - closes https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/10165

Title: Posix shell rebased ready
Body: This brings back the great work from @julianoes which was never finished in #5162. I rebased (sorry Julian I had to squash it  there were many conflicts)  and finished it to a point where everything is in a good state (meaning mergeable but not everything is converted or finished yet).  ### Features - all posix scripts run through bash now - there is already a unified script for `iris` and the `typhoon_h480`. The rest are still using the existing scripts  but already run through bash. - Running through bash (or a shell) allows to use full scripting power like on NuttX and thus unification of first all posix scripts and then also with the NuttX scripts (at least partly). This reduces duplication and allows the same functionality on posix targets as on NuttX. - support for multi-instances: it will simplify multi-vehicle simulations - supports an arbitrary amount of px4 shells: this makes PX4 modules 'feel' like individual executables and can be run as such when added to the `PATH` (e.g. `px4-listener sensor_accel`).  ### Try it out To see the magic in action  start the simulation  then in a new shell: ``` cd <firmware>/build/posix_sitl_default ./bin/px4-commander takeoff ./bin/px4-uorb top ```  ### Testing Done I did extensive testing: - SITL with jMAVSim and gazebo for different vehicles - replay works - RPi works - stress-test: I ran variations of `while true; do ./bin/px4-ekf2 status; done` in about 5 shells in parallel  and it works as expected. Memory usage stays stable. - not tested: snapdragon  bepob & ocpoc  ### TODO Left todo before merging: - make sure MAVROS still works (tested via CI). - rebase and make required changes for the BeagleBone board if the PR is merged before  ### Future work - continue unification of SITL scripts - make sure MAVROS uses the new unified rcS script - merge scripts with NuttX - avoid printf for status output and use PX4_INFO_RAW instead

Title: SITL unify all init scripts
Body: This combines all SITL startup scripts into a common rcS file with separate autostart files for each model using the same structure as we have on NuttX. The `rc.vehicle_setup` from NuttX is now also used in SITL  which starts all vehicle type-specific apps and loads the mixer. So a considerable portion of the scripts is now shared.  Bash does not allow empty 'if then else' clauses  so I added 'if ! <cmd>' support for NuttX and changed all existing occurrences.  I tested all the models with gazebo (rover doesn't seem to work  but it does not on master either). Mutli-vehicle simulation works now generically.  This depends on https://github.com/PX4-NuttX/apps/pull/2.  It's probably best to review commit by commit.  Note that LPE needs to be selected with `export PX4_ESTIMATOR=lpe` now.  @hamishwillee docs will follow.  ### Script testing I found [ShellCheck](https://www.shellcheck.net/)  a static analyzer for (bash) scripts. I added a script to run it  and we should add it to CI via: ``` ./Tools/run-shellcheck.sh ROMFS/px4fmu_common/ ``` It will test the NuttX scripts as well.

Title: px4fmuv2 Add detection for Pixhack V3
Body: The Simple HW detection was detecting the   Pixhack V3 as a mini.    This commit adds further discrimination  based on   the fact the Pixhack V3 left VDD_5V_PERIPH_EN   floating. Where a mini  V2  V3 HW has it connected   to the active low enable of the VDD_5V_PERIPH and   VDD_5V_HIGHPOWER via a 10K pull down.    The detection enables the 40K pull up and samples   the pin. This reads back as a logical one on the   Pixhack V3  and a logical zero on the Mini.    Since the float is applied some 3.3 Ms post pin setting   at reset the 10 us should leave the 5 Volt supplies in   the on state because of the 10K pull down.   This is assuming typical 40K pullup 10K pull down   This results in typical 0.66V (.875V max) on the /EN pin   which should not be detected as a high on the TPS2041.  @dagar Detection wize this is safe  it would only affect a Mini and I reviewed that schematic in detail. Please do check the rotations ar commensurate with the V3 Cube.

Title: Add remote power off switch
Body: After flight controller board is installed on the vehicle  power button is often inaccessible. Unplugging power directly has risk of file system corruption resulting in read-only file system. Here is an example on BeagleBone Blue:  sudo: unable to open /var/lib/sudo/ts/debian: Read-only file system  More info can be found here: https://electronics.stackexchange.com/questions/234970/protection-of-beaglebone-black-from-emmc-corruption-on-power-loss  At field  logging into system to issue shutdown command is inconvenient.

Title: WIP Camera capture driver
Body: This PR adds the camera capture driver. This can be used to receive a feedback from a camera after it is triggered (eg. sony hot shoe feedback). In this case we don't publish the camera_trigger message in the camera_trigger driver when we trigger the camera  but we publish when we receive the feedback from the camera. When geotagging images this will increase the presision in the geotag.  This can be also used to sync CV cameras with the IMU data for VIO or similar applications.  Currently only channel 5 on the FMU PWM outputs can be used for this driver. I still need to check on which outputs we can actually run this.   Some more tests will be done in the next days.  Params for testing: CAM_CAP_FBACK = 1 (enable camera capture)  CAM_CAP_MODE =  0 (get edge timestamp) 1 (get pulse midpoint timestamp for active high triggers) 2 (get pulse midpoint timestamp for active low triggers)  CAM_CAP_EDGE =  0 (trigger on falling edge) 1 (trigger on rising edge)  CAM_CAP_DELAY --> delay between image integration start and strobe firing (default to 0)

Title: RM3100 continued
Body: This is a continuation of #9818 for the RM3100 magnetometer driver. A few items to discuss :  - as there is no WHO_AM_I register  driver initialization depends on REVID  so far only tested on 1 breakout board - the RM3100 sensor provides raw magnetic data as signed 24-bit values  those are stored in 32-bit variables and "artificially" converted to int32_t  is there a cleaner way to do that? - the ORB struct `sensor_mag_s` only stores raw values as 16-bit integers  is it worth enlarging definition to 32 bits? - `check_calibration()`  `check_offset()` and `check_scale()` functions have been removed as they will be replaced by an ORB-based mechanism (as of #10126) - the driver has been succesfully tested on SPI (external SPI on Pixhawk 3 Pro)  no I2C available on the breakout board

Title: Move platforms into src platforms

Title: Batt smbus rename to bq40z50 ceate battery driver folder and update bq40z50 driver
Body: This PR is to rename the batt_smbus driver to bq40z50 in order to reflect accurately what it is for. This also creates a battery folder in drivers for it to reside. This brings it in line with the rest of the drivers.   It also adds two fields to battery_status.msg. A voltage array for individual cell voltages  and a cell voltage delta value. This is to communicate the max difference between the highest and lowest voltage cell in a pack. This can help diagnose bad batteries with imbalanced cells.   mavlink_messages.cpp is also updated to populate the voltage array  and add time_remaining.    ``` INFO  [bq40z50] starting /dev/bq40z50_ext BQ40Z50_I2C on I2C bus 1 at 0x0b (bus: 100 KHz  max: 100 KHz) INFO  [bq40z50] Smart battery found at 0xb INFO  [bq40z50] Smart battery connected INFO  [bq40z50] bad PEC from block_read INFO  [bq40z50] Max Cell Delta: 0.12  WARN  [bq40z50] Please enter an appropriate command. Title: Configurable serial ports v2
Body: Rebased and reworked version of #9615. Differences: - per-module serial config parameters instead of per-port as asked for by Daniel   - added the required port deconfliction in the startup scripts (eventually the user should be notified about the conflict in some way  or prevent a conflicting config in the first place). - Added module config files based on YAML  ### per-module vs. per-port config params Personally I don't see strong arguments for either way  both have their drawbacks: #### per-port (previous PR) - more centralized approach (in terms of how modules register a serial command) - QGC metadata contains all modules even if not enabled #### per-module (this PR) - explicit port deconfliction required - More parameters (one per service instead of one per port) - QGC metadata contains all ports  In any case we have now both versions.  ### Module Config Files Modules now need a config file to register a startup command  and configure the parameters. I decided to go for YAML  because: - generally wide-spread tooling support - benefits over JSON:   - simpler to read and edit   - YAML is a superset of JSON   - we can have comments   - JSON is targeted more for serialization instead of configuration  Here's an example to register a serial command (see the mavlink config for an example of using multiple instances): ``` module_name: LeddarOne Rangefinder serial_config:     - command: leddar_one start -d ${SERIAL_DEV}       port_config_param:         name: SENS_LEDDAR1_CFG         group: Sensors ```  These config files can also be used for parameter definitions. MAVLink already uses them to generate multiple instances. These are then translated into the existing C-style parameter definitions. This allows us to transition all files step by step and eventually remove the translation layer.  In addition it allows us to do schema validation  to ensure that the configs will conform to the expectations. I added a script that uses [cerberus](http://docs.python-cerberus.org/en/stable/) (see commit 1b42c63). The schema is also a good place to document all possible options.  Once there's consensus  I'll continue here  there's still quite a bit left to do.

Title: RTPS msg generation generalize scripts
Body: This PR generalizes the scripts fro generating the RTPS related headers and source files. 1. Allows passing the templates as arguments  so to allow the scripts to use different templates; 2. Allows passing the pkg name  which is useful when setting field types which depends on other msg types that belong to a certain package - it also allows using the scripts out of the PX4 Firmware repo; 3. Sets the RTPS msg ID's to the templates by loading these from a JSON file - this allows setting other JSON files with other IDs or message naming (which for the ROS side is required  since the msg naming is different).

Title: Bootloader updates for fmu v2
Body: Since we don't seem to have enough bandwidth on the QGC side for https://github.com/mavlink/qgroundcontrol/issues/6488  this proposes an alternative way to update the Bootloader on v2 boards that does not rely on QGC changes.  ### How does it work? The BL binary is included in the Firmware binary  and the user can then activate the update through a parameter that gets checked on the next boot.  ### Steps for a user - Insert an SD card (for the bootlog) - Flash master of fmu-v2 target (e.g. through QGC) - Enable `SYS_BL_UPDATE` - Reboot & Wait - Flash fmu-v3 target  I tested it around 10 times  works w/o problems  and the actual BL update takes only about a second.  Drawback: increased Flash usage due to the inclusion of the BL binary.  Fixes: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/9562

Title: Port Deconflicts for Multi UAV Gazebo Simulations
Body: **Test data / coverage** Output of diagnostics for a test with 3 UAVs [3quad_dia.txt](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/files/2389949/3quad_dia.txt)  **Describe problem solved by the proposed pull request** Resolves an issue within https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/ROMFS/px4fmu_common/init.d-posix/rcS#L84-L88 that caused a UDP bind error when spawning multiple UAVs in Gazebo. As a result the UAVs were not able to be armed.    fixes issue  #10430    **Describe your preferred solution** Shifting the UDP port assignments to not have any overlap. The set of ports needed to establish a connection between the simulator and mavros are now a function of the UAV's id and are shifted incrementally for each new UAV. The associated launch file will also reflect these changes. Also fixes an off-by-one mismatch between quad ID's   **Additional context** With this fix there's a notable difference between how a single UAV is spawned (hard coded ports within a SDF file) and how the multi_uav launch file works. It might be useful to further consolidate this.

Title: GPS updates reduce delay support for u blox protocol version 27
Body: Reduces message delay by reducing the sleep time (around 20ms less). This uses now the same sleep time logic as mavlink  depending on the baudrate.  CPU usage on a Pixracer for different sleep times: ``` #num reads/sec    sleep time         CPU usage 17-18             2.8ms              0.233-0.31% (this PR) 12                5ms                0.155-0.3% 9-10              10ms               0.155-0.233% 6                 20ms               0.155-0.233% (previous) ```   ~~Requires https://github.com/PX4/GpsDrivers/pull/32~~ EDIT: submodule updated. (all testing there was done with this change as well)  @priseborough I did some replay testing with different `EKF2_GPS_DELAY`  but changing it by +-20 ms did not show significant changes of the innovation. Maybe you want to cross-check?

Title: DO NOT MERGE Test ccache for Windows CI
Body: This pr is setup as a test bench to allow cooperation for making the NuttX build work with ccache for CI. It was requested by @dagar in a private discussion.  It uses a beta installer to with ccache present in Windows CI which currently makes the NuttX builds fail. As soon as the problem is found I can do a new official installer release and we can just leave the resulting fix in this pr.

Title: WIP Omnibus MC only
Body: Needed to unblock https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/10355  but this is also a good excuse to fix these bogus dependencies.  Navigator is currently dependant on the VTOL parameters **VT_B_DEC_MSS** and **VT_B_REV_DEL**. Let's either handle this with the VTOL controller publishing a status message  or falling back to the old param API.  I'd vote for an orb based solution if @RomanBapst could assist. I'll be mostly unavailable until next week.  Similar to the way the FW position controller publishes `position_controller_status` for the L1 distance that's used by navigator as the acceptance radius  we could have the vtol controller publish an appropriate acceptance distance for back transition (how VT_B_DEC_MSS and VT_B_REV_DEL are used). https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/navigator/mission_block.cpp#L291-L305  Going forward I think we should strictly enforce parameter module boundaries with only a few global exceptions (SYS and CAL?).

Title: omnibus temporarily disable the topic listener

Title: Toward a centralized flexible PWM resource coordination subsystem
Body: **Note** This PR is a workable branch  little bit behind latest px4/master (so all checks may fail)  but as i imagine it will not be merged in short time so i need to rebase it anyway till then. You are welcome to comments on the new model and design  to see any improvements needed  and co-work if you are also interested.  If anyone would like to have a test flight you can find it here:  https://github.com/airmind/OpenMindPX as its updated from time to time.  So far it is only tested on [MindPX](https://docs.px4.io/en/flight_controller/mindpx.html) and [MindRacer](https://docs.px4.io/en/flight_controller/mindracer.html). Please let me know if you found any problem on other hardware (TAP-V1 probably broke on LED drivers  but it was not a correct implementation and needs to be fixed later anyway).  **Describe problem solved by the proposed pull request** This PR starts the step towards a centralized while flexible PWM resource management system which introduce many interesting features.   Existing PWM subsystem majorly hand-wire pwm resource allocation like timers  channels  pin numbers  scattered in many different locations such as board configs  airframe config files  mixer files  or source codes  many of them hard-coded. This makes attempts to expand supported PWM devices quite difficult as one needs to manually settle all potential conflicts on resource usage.  This PR wants to build a centralized while flexible way to support as many kind of PWM devices as possible with only few simple runtime configurations needed through some kind of Human-Machine Interface(like from GUI of GCS).  **Describe your preferred solution** A new model of PWM devices and a centralized resource management group of classes are defined to  achieve this goal. A detailed description of the model and design can be found here: [Design document](https://github.com/airmind/OpenMindPX/pull/3) ![https://camo.githubusercontent.com/ad036a5b6d6f1ba7475997bf432512c056e0f6f9/687474703a2f2f7777772e636c75622e6d696e6470782e6e65742f7075626c69632f75706c6f61642f37383863366666316466663532326263323065346633373933613031376432342e706e67]( https://camo.githubusercontent.com/ad036a5b6d6f1ba7475997bf432512c056e0f6f9/687474703a2f2f7777772e636c75622e6d696e6470782e6e65742f7075626c69632f75706c6f61642f37383863366666316466663532326263323065346633373933613031376432342e706e67)  Some interesting features can be brought in by the new design. For example   1. Camera trigger will not be limited on the first 6pins of main output. Pilot can use any free pins on Main/Aux port  if the first 6 pins all occupied  through few configuration of parameters. 1. A pilot that flys a hexa airframe  now can use the remaining 2 channels on Main port to drive an external PWM heater to heat any other components(not only the flight controller) on his vehicle  simply by selecting the pin number from GUI of GCS(needs further work).  1. in the meanwhile  he can still connect a set of external PWM LEDs to AUX channels  still through configuration of the pin numbers from GUI of GCS(needs further work). He will not need to change the codes and compile to upload everytime he wants to change the task modules layout for different missions.  **Additional context** @davids5 It will be very interesting to see the possibility of it to be combined with the hardware manifest work you initiated. I am expecting your co-work on it. @dagar This PR is somewhat independent of the original PR #7208  and #8142 that separating the FMU from other 'flight management' tasks. I prefer that we pursuing that target in an other PR. @DonLakeFlyer Ultimately all these configurations has to be done through GCS. I think this will need your help on QGC side  if you like it and are interested on helping it out. **@testflights** I will be appreciate if you can help to test the PR. And i strongly recommend you have MindPX/MindRacer hardwares added into your testing package :-)  @mzahana I think you can have all 16 (8 main + 8 aux) channels on MindPX fully funtional and all VTOL frames available now. Pls let me know on any issue. @TSC21   @LorenzMeier

Title: Master logical led
Body: This PR is the groundwork to fix the power LED blinking on V5     Background:    ----------    Early boards only had an AMBER LED that was used to    indicate a High Load condition.     This change defines the new logical interface    the LED_<color> should not be used in application    code moving forward  only the manipulator macros    should be used.         Logical usage             Legacy default       ------------------------+-------------        BOARD_OVERLOAD_LED     | LED_RED     Later boards defined BOARD_HAS_CONTROL_STATUS_LEDS    and added the use of a BLUE and GREEN LED that were    used as follows:     Logical usage             Legacy default       ------------------------+-------------        BOARD_ARMED_LED        | LED_BLUE        BOARD_ARMED_STATE_LED  | LED_GREEN     With this PR a board may now define _only_ a subset    the leds and map them at the board level to the    color LED it wants to use.         Logical usage             Legacy default       ------------------------+-------------        BOARD_OVERLOAD_LED     | LED_RED     when BOARD_HAS_CONTROL_STATUS_LEDS is defined        BOARD_ARMED_LED        | LED_BLUE        BOARD_ARMED_STATE_LED  | LED_GREEN     If any of the BOARD_{OVERLOAD|ARMED|ARMED_STATE}_LED are not defined. The code output generates a null action for that  LED.

Title: RTPS classify msgs as send receive or ignore
Body: This is an ongoing work in order to classify the uORB topics depending on if we want them to be published to the RTPS stream  subscribed (or both) and ignored ("unclassified").  This replaces the CMake set of the topics to send and receive and reads the yaml description file and gets which topics are classified in which category.  TODO: - [x] Verify why the spec global is not being set: ```bash Traceback (most recent call last):   File "/home/nuno/PX4/Firmware/msg/tools/generate_microRTPS_bridge.py"  line 333  in <module>     generate_agent(agent_out_dir)   File "/home/nuno/PX4/Firmware/msg/tools/generate_microRTPS_bridge.py"  line 247  in generate_agent     package  px_generate_uorb_topic_files.INCL_DEFAULT  classifier.msg_id_map  uRTPS_AGENT_TEMPL_FILE)   File "/home/nuno/PX4/Firmware/msg/tools/px_generate_uorb_topic_files.py"  line 215  in generate_uRTPS_general     return generate_by_template(output_file  template_file  merged_em_globals)   File "/home/nuno/PX4/Firmware/msg/tools/px_generate_uorb_topic_files.py"  line 300  in generate_by_template     interpreter.file(open(template_file))   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/em.py"  line 2359  in file     self.safe(scanner  done  locals)   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/em.py"  line 2401  in safe     self.parse(scanner  locals)   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/em.py"  line 2421  in parse     token.run(self  locals)   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/em.py"  line 1425  in run     interpreter.execute(self.code  locals)   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/em.py"  line 2595  in execute     _exec(statements  self.globals  locals)   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/em.py"  line 42  in _exec     exec("""exec code in globals""")   File "<string>"  line 1  in <module>   File "<string>"  line 7  in <module> NameError: name 'spec' is not defined ``` - [X] Check how to handle the multi-topics/aliases  since they do not exist as files  so when we set an ID to them on the yaml file  it looks for the file on the msg dir  which doesn't exist. An approach to take can be setting a new field on the yaml file which says from which topic does that aliased topic derives from. **NOTE:** to be added in a further PR.  - [x] Fix uint8_t serialization and deserialization.

Instead the output is only being saved when the check passes  which isn't helpful.   **Describe your preferred solution** Archive the EKF log processer artifacts only when a failure occurs.  **Describe possible alternatives** Archive the EKF log processer artifacts always. This can be changed easily if desired.  **Additional context** Example of the problem: http://ci.px4.io:8080/blue/organizations/jenkins/PX4_misc%2FFirmware-SITL_tests/detail/master/248/pipeline  - [x] Needs testing to demonstrate a failure.  EDIT: Adding some images for reference of the issue: ![screenshot from 2018-10-03 15-00-07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10533707/46475551-cf8d0880-c7b3-11e8-958c-d9dfaf8f2c70.png) ![screenshot from 2018-10-03 15-00-31](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10533707/46475559-d74cad00-c7b3-11e8-93a9-223d419a5c4e.png)  Before you can see that the job exits before it has a chance to archive the artifacts and that the artifact we'd want to see isn't there: 08_49_06.ulg.pdf  EDIT: For now  we'll swallow up the exception for the ecl script failing but keep the output.

Title: Make SITL tests faster than real time
Body: This is work ~in progress~ to address #5026.   Edit/Update:  This is now closer to lockstep but not complete/correct yet. The way it works is that the simulator sets the time using the `HIL_SENSOR` message.  **Things to try:**  1. Set simulation speed using env variable `PX4_SIM_SPEED_FACTOR`: ``` PX4_SIM_SPEED_FACTOR=10 make posix jmavsim ``` or: ``` PX4_SIM_SPEED_FACTOR=10 make posix gazebo ```  2. Pause the simulation: During the simulation  just press **P** in jMAVSim to toggle pause/resume. For Gazebo you can hit the pause button in the the Gazebo viewer.  **Issues  what is missing?**  - Once we start running it very fast (e.g. 10x)  we see that `sensors` misses samples while the mc_att_ctrl keeps up and keeps working and generating actuator outputs and therefore drives the lockstep. To debug this  enable the debug output in `simulator_mavlink.cpp` (https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/10648/files#diff-23c67e906b712051714dd61b12fce367R297) Or you can also check this [logfile](https://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=f96607c1-4a32-4d02-96b7-b9f289f22488) where you see that the estimator is missing quite a few samples over time. **-> Future work** - ~Integration with Gazebo is not started. I would get to this once jMAVSim is done.~ - We get datalink lost/regained often unless you increase the timeout via param: e.g. `COM_DL_LOSS_T = 30`  **-> Future work** - The mavlink rates sent to QGC get quite high  e.g. 10x  and QGC stalls because of it. A workaround is to reduce the rates in `mavlink start -r`. **-> Future work** - `perf` is also fake when it probably should be using the "real" time. **-> Future work** - ~It doesn't seem to work on macOS yet. With TCP it doesn't connect  and with UDP it does connect but then show: `sim_send: px4_poll() sem error`.~ - ~The unit tests stall or segfault (or both?).~ - ~We need to check if this works with ROS.~ - ~The unit tests and jMAVSim SITL don't work properly on Windows yet.~

Title: Individual cell voltages and batt_smbus
Body: Hello all  This is my first pull request ever. I am still very new to development in general  so please forgive me. I know there are errors  But I would love some feedback while I fix them.  Changes to files are for two reasons: - Try to fix an issue where the batt_smbus driver does not include I2C bus options for Pixhawk hardware with buses other than `PX4_I2C_BUS_ONBOARD` and `PX4_I2C_BUS_EXPANSION`  (Example: I am using a Pixhawk 4  so px4fmu-v5 defines the external I2C A port as `PX4_I2C_BUS_EXPANSION2`  which the driver cannot start on currently) - Implement real individual voltage checking and reporting to the ground station via the existing individual voltage array in MAVlink `BATTERY_STATUS` messages. The existing code divides total pack voltage by number of cells (up to 10 cells) to calculate individual cell voltages  but I want to populate that array with measured cell voltages.   The registers beyond 0x3f are specific to the custom voltage and temperature measuring board I am working on  but because they are not defined for most TI fuel gauge chips (the BQ40Z50 does not define any registers in the range of 0x40 - 0x49)  I don't think I am breaking compatibility by adding this behavior. However  I do not have a BQ40Z50 to test this on.  Possible alternatives: - Write custom driver for up to 10 cell voltages and up to three temperature values that works with my hardware to publish `battery_status` messages  - Separate core SMbus functionality (`read_word  write_word  block_read  etc.`) from device specific functionality to prevent bloating of `batt_smbus` and make development easier as @dakejahl suggested   Example: Test bench setup for custom board connected to Pixhawk 4 I2C A port ![img_20181005_200912](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35938826/46565296-bda68500-c8db-11e8-80da-4ff188e52c15.jpg)  Starting the driver manually ![screenshot from 2018-10-05 20-12-58](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35938826/46565273-9059d700-c8db-11e8-84ab-dcfeb4439a84.png)  Result of sweeping benchtop through voltage range  ![screenshot from 2018-10-05 20-15-06](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35938826/46565257-7a4c1680-c8db-11e8-9678-207aee60306d.png)  Thanks  Zack Selgrath
