Title: ICM20602 and ICM20608g new standalone driver 8 kHz gyro 4 kHz accel
Body: This is a new driver for the Invensense ICM20602 that uses the sensor's FIFO and SPI DMA (on px4_fmu-v4) to transfer raw gyro data at 8 kHz and accel at 4 kHz. It can also do gyro at 32 kHz  but at that point the bus utilization is a bit too high to peacefully coexist with other sensors.    The intent is to keep these opinionated drivers simple and optimized to the point where it'll likely be easier to carry separate drivers for each sensor with minor differences rather than trying to support everything in one place (see current mpu6000 mess). We'll see how this actually pans out for the ICM20608  ICM20689  etc.    Originally I was going to do a pass and enable SPI DMA everywhere first (https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/12436)  but given various problems and delays in that area I think we can move forward incrementally like this.    Features   - 8 kHz gyro (32 kHz possible)   - 4 kHz accel   - FIFO emptied at 1 kHz (we can consider doing this faster or slower as appropriate)   - clip counters   - new low pass filter that operates on an array of data (LowPassFilter2pArray)   - new sensor messages for better visibility      - sensor_{accel  gyro}_fifo: full raw data for optional logging and analysis      - sensor_{accel  gyro}_status: metadata  clipping  etc      - sensor_{accel  gyro}_integrated: delta angles and delta velocities       - eventually these will replace the existing sensor_{accel  gyro} monolith      ### Background (notes from @priseborough)    #### IMU Signal Processing  Failure to detect vibration induced inertial navigation failures early enough during system integration or operation has contributed to a number of vehicle loss incidents. In the majority of cases this has been caused by structural resonances excited by motor and propeller blade bassage frequency vibration.  The current practice of using the IMUs internal DLPF is  a major blocker for the following reasons:   1. IMU internal sampling is then limited to 1kHz which makes the ADC step susceptible to aliasing on airframes with high RPM/geared motors and high blade count propellers   2. The use of the IMUs internal DLPF means that high frequency vibration clipping of the ADC cannot be detected externally until it has affected the INS   3. Data cannot be logged at the ADC sampling frequency so it is not possible to use a data driven approach to resolving vibration induced navigation failures.    Experience working with companies using PX4 has shown that the majority do not understand how propulsion system forcing  structural dynamics  IMU sampling and vibration isolation mount design interact to affect navigation system performance and for those that do  the inability to log the required data prevents the use of normal analytical methods.    The signal chain for autopilot feedback and navigation needs to be split for the following reasons:   1. Logging of raw unfiltered data from the sensors ADC is required if an analytical approach to resolving vibration induced navigation failures is to be adopted.   2. Angular rate control feedback requires data with minimum phase low/group delay with a maximum acceptable level of high frequency content that is application specific.    3. The best general purpose filter in terms of high frequency noise rejection for a given phase delay measured at the rate controller gain cross-over frequency of 5-15Hz is an IIR second order bi-quad filter with a Q of 1/sqrt(2).   4. The angular rate controller should be synchronised to the imu to reduce inter-sampling delay.   5. The angular rate controller should run at a higher rate than the attitude and position/height controllers and therefore needs to run at a faster rate than the INS/EKF.    6. The angular rate controller may be required to run at 1kHz or higher for some applications.   7. The INS/EKF uses delta angles and delta velocities that are obtained by integrating high rate gyro and accel measurements in body frame across the INS/EKF update interval.   8. The INS/EKF is very sensitive to errors caused by clipping and aliasing.    9. Correction for coning errors introduced when downsampling needs to applied as part of the downsampling integration algorithm.  10. It is unlikely that INS data would be required faster than 250Hz.    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84712/66319962-f19bf800-e8eb-11e9-9b84-7ef6c19d4877.png)

Title: Create publish_status method in the heater driver and add a status field to indicate if the temperature setpoint has been met within 2 5C
Body: Hello     **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  This PR performs a minor bit of refactoring and adds a status field to the heater_status message to indicate if the temperature setpoint has been achieved within 2.5C.  It also decreases the default heater temperature setpoint to be valid for a wider range of hardware and increases the driver scheduling frequency to reduce potential influence on magnetometers.     **Test data / coverage**  Flight tested on a CubeBlack after resetting the setpoint on the bench from 55C to 35C.  I will post another log from cold shortly.  https://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=3b68e434-421c-4072-8d5d-5385f524fee9    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2497951/114605641-84db8980-9c57-11eb-8b62-928611f01f06.png)      Let me know if you have any questions or would like more information regarding this PR. Thanks!    -Mark

Title: parameter runtime defaults and other small improvements
Body: Continuation of the core configurable parameters defaults idea from @RomanBapst's https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/pull/14363.    This is intended to be a replacement for the current airframe  vehicle type  and board specific parameter defaults currently scattered throughout init.    ### Example    Setting multi-EKF parameter defaults on fmu-v5.   ```Console  nsh> param set-default EKF2_MULTI_IMU 3  nsh> param set-default SENS_IMU_MODE 0  ```  The defaults are baked into the firmware and applied early at boot before anything is started. The parameter system's non-volatile storage (typically FRAM) doesn't need to store anything. If the default value changes in a future release the user automatically gets the new value  unless they made a change from default.    In the future I'd like the defaults to actually be a declarative format that's loaded automatically per board/vehicle type/airframe  but for now extending the param systemcmd seemed like an easy way to get started.    ### Notes   - saves several kilobytes of flash on fmu-v2 by splitting out volatile parameters    ### Next steps   - param file format       - QGC compatible .param? or simple key value?

Title: WIP Pr uavcan v1 node client
Body: Next step for integrating uavcan_v1    Todo:  - add options to start/connect with more than one CAN bus [@Igor-Misic ]    Know issues:  - socketcan driver will hang if the node is not properly connected to the CAN bus (reproducible if CAN wires are not connected or there is no active CAN device on the bus)  - uavcan node client can't be properly reconnected if it is rebooted.   The problem is on the server-side because canard remembers inside `_rx_subscriptions` different `rxs->transfer_id` from the previous session.

Title: check_code_style_all sh remove ignored xargs parameter
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  For quite some time now I get this annoying warning message:  `xargs: warning: options --max-args and --replace/-I/-i are mutually exclusive  ignoring previous --max-args value`  when each time when running `make format`.    **Describe your solution**  Looked up the man page: https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/xargs.1.html  > -I replace-str  .... Implies -x and -L 1.  > -L max-lines  Use at most max-lines nonblank input lines per command line. ...  > -n max-args  --max-args=max-args  Use at most max-args arguments per command line. ...    So my interpretation is that `-n 1` is superfluous because `-I string` implies that `-n` cannot be used separately but is implicitly set to one.    **Test data / coverage**  I tested and the executed commands of `make format` are exactly the same.    I'm using `xargs (GNU findutils) 4.8.0` but am assuming it doesn't make any difference.

Title: Makefile clean use git clean to delete all gitignore files recursively
Body: This is helpful for submodule dependencies that get into a dirty build state and will otherwise need to be completely reinitialized before the build will succeed again.

Title: cmake set MAX_CUSTOM_OPT_LEVEL to O3 if Release
Body: In release builds (-O3) modules that set `MAX_CUSTOM_OPT_LEVEL` were actually being limited to `-O2`.

Title: Add support for UCANS32K146B board revision
Body: The UCANS32K146B is a board revision that uses a different CAN phy.  However the behavior of the STB pin on this CAN phy is inverted.  This patch adds a runtime detector to see which revision it's and correctly set the CAN phy STB pin.

Title: Makefile keep git clean for submodules to resolve incomplete dependency problems
Body: This might solve the issue with a partial libuavcan build being interrupted  but not yet verified.    **EDIT:** seems to work  broken incomplete builds are now recoverable with `make clean`.

Title: FMUK66 V3 free up some RAM
Body: Reduces RAM usage on the FMUK66-V3 and FMUK66-E by 3KB    And on SocketCAN target it reduces it even more by ~ 5KB

Title: PWM Fixes
Body: None of the test worked. Now they do....some what - There is still an order of operation issue.     Testing with the commands listed below.     (1)  `pwm_out mode_pwm14` only starts instance 0  ```  pwm_out0 set_pwm_rate 0 0 50  group:0  mask f  group:1  mask f0  group:0  mask f  group:1  mask f0  ```  (2)  `pwm rate` Only sets first instance until both are armed  ```  nsh> pwm rate  -d /dev/pwm_output0  -r 400 -a  pwm_out0 set_pwm_rate 0 0 400  group:0  mask f  group:1  mask f0  group:0  mask f  group:1  mask f0  pwm_out0 set_pwm_rate ffff 0 400  group:0  mask f  group:1  mask f0  group:0  mask f  group:1  mask f0  nsh> pwm rate  -d /dev/pwm_output1  -r 400 -a  pwm_out1 set_pwm_rate 0 50 400  pwm_out1 set_pwm_rate ffff 50 400  nsh> INFO  [pwm_out] instance: 0  max rate: 2000  default: 0  alt: 400  INFO  [pwm_out] instance: 1  max rate: 800  default: 50  alt: 400  ```    3) now sets mode and alow rates to be set  ```  nsh> pwm -d /dev/pwm_output0 arm  nsh> pwm -d /dev/pwm_output1 arm  pwm_out1 set_pwm_rate ffff 0 400  group:2  mask f00  group:3  mask 3000  group:2  mask f00  group:3  mask 3000  nsh> INFO  [pwm_out] instance: 1  max rate: 2000  default: 0  alt: 400  ```    4)  ```  pwm rate  -d /dev/pwm_output0  -r 400 -a  pwm_out0 set_pwm_rate ffff 0 400  group:0  mask f  group:1  mask f0  group:0  mask f  group:1  mask f0  pwm_out0 set_pwm_rate ffff 0 400  group:0  mask f  group:1  mask f0  group:0  mask f  group:1  mask f0  nsh> pwm rate  -d /dev/pwm_output1  -r 400 -a  pwm_out1 set_pwm_rate ffff 0 400  group:2  mask f00  group:3  mask 3000  group:2  mask f00  group:3  mask 3000  pwm_out1 set_pwm_rate ffff 0 400  group:2  mask f00  group:3  mask 3000  group:2  mask f00  group:3  mask 3000  nsh> INFO  [pwm_out] instance: 0  max rate: 2000  default: 0  alt: 400  INFO  [pwm_out] instance: 1  max rate: 2000  default: 0  alt: 400  ```      First commit:  Found and fixed DSHOT broke io timers. (This may need so be rippled to other arches)    Found and fixed AFU IOCLT values. It coun not have been any more broken. (Channel number like 0xffffffffa Nikes!!    added _output_mask logic to keep the restored `set_pwm_rate(pwm_alt_rate_channels_new  default_rate_min  alt_rate_max);`  from missing with groups not in it's intance.      ```  pwm_out start  pwm_out mode_pwm14      pwm status -d /dev/pwm_output0  pwm status -d /dev/pwm_output1      pwm -d /dev/pwm_output0 arm  pwm -d /dev/pwm_output1 arm    pwm rate  -d /dev/pwm_output0  -r 400 -a  pwm rate  -d /dev/pwm_output1  -r 400 -a         pwm rate  -d /dev/pwm_output0  -r 50 -a  pwm rate  -d /dev/pwm_output1  -r 50 -a      pwm test  -d /dev/pwm_output0  -p 1000 -a    pwm test  -d /dev/pwm_output0  -p 1234 -a    pwm test  -d /dev/pwm_output1  -p 1234 -a      pwm_out -d /dev/px4fmu test  pwm_out -d /dev/px4fmu1 test        pwm rate  -d /dev/pwm_output0  -r 0 -a    ```    ```  diff --git a/src/drivers/pwm_out/PWMOut.cpp b/src/drivers/pwm_out/PWMOut.cpp  index 5f513553f6..1e61e29bb0 100644  --- a/src/drivers/pwm_out/PWMOut.cpp  +++ b/src/drivers/pwm_out/PWMOut.cpp  @@ -375 7 +375 7 @@ int PWMOut::set_mode(Mode mode)    */   int PWMOut::set_pwm_rate(uint32_t rate_map  unsigned default_rate  unsigned alt_rate)   {  -       PX4_DEBUG("pwm_out%u set_pwm_rate %x %u %u"  _instance  rate_map  default_rate  alt_rate);  +       printf("pwm_out%u set_pwm_rate %x %u %u\n"  _instance  rate_map  default_rate  alt_rate);             for (unsigned pass = 0; pass < 2; pass++) {     @@ -402 6 +402 7 @@ int PWMOut::set_pwm_rate(uint32_t rate_map  unsigned default_rate  unsigned alt_                                  continue;                          }     +                       printf("group:%d  mask %x\n"  group  mask);                          // all channels in the group must be either default or alt-rate                          uint32_t alt = rate_map & mask;  ```

Title: Support multi vehicle simulation for fixed wing in gazebo SITL
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Since the plane model is defined as a sdf format  it was not possible to launch multivehicle simulation  as it relies on xacro macros to generate sdf files.    **Describe your solution**  This enables https://github.com/PX4/sitl_gazebo/pull/385 and spawns the vehicles from the sdf file rather than froma urdf file as done previously. This is more consistent on what was being done for the iris in PX4/sitl_gazebo    **Test data / coverage**  Video:   [![Video](https://img.youtube.com/vi/aEzFKPMEfjc/0.jpg)](https://youtu.be/aEzFKPMEfjc "Hovering done")

Title: Makefile clean and distclean updates
Body: - update `clean` to iterate all build directories and use build system clean   - git clean is used to remove submodule generated build artifacts that are left in the source tree   - `distclean` now discards all build directories and any gitignored files that were generated in source directories (but not top level)    @julianoes @bkueng can you give this a try?    Background https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/pull/17522#issuecomment-832358757

Title: UAVCANv1 cleanup and uORB over UAVCANV1 move to own subclass
Body: Just another UAVCANv1 iteration  this PR adds/fixes the following    - Receive/transmit scheduling is solved by adding while loop in the receive function thanks @JacobCrabill   - Move uORB over UAVCAN sensor_gps to it's own subclass (now Uavcan.cpp is almost clean of all manual subscription implementations)  - Integrated uORB over UAVCAN sensor_gps into parameter system  - NodeManager integration with parameter system which does automatically remotely set Node portID if the node exposes that.    - However we've to figure out how to make this a bit more clean and compact  because technically our subscription is the same as the publication register of a node and thus I don't want to store a copy of that string twice.    `{"uavcan.sub.uorb.sensor_gps.0.id"     "UCAN1_UORB_GPS"} ` could also be     `{"uorb.sensor_gps.0.id"     "UCAN1_UORB_GPS"  SUB} `

Title: Add ARK CAN GPS Board Config
Body: This PR adds support for the ARK CAN GPS.   https://arkelectron.com/product/ark-gps/    ![SAM_0852 (Large)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2019539/118344200-59fc8380-b4ea-11eb-8315-32b7298f7246.JPG)    This also rolls back the GPS submodule to commit https://github.com/PX4/PX4-GPSDrivers/commit/f82313f082f6a9e63f83040996172906622f01a7 to fix https://github.com/PX4/PX4-GPSDrivers/issues/82    Further improvements to the safety button  buzzer  and safety LED over UAVCAN will be made.        UAVCAN GPS  Magnetometer  Barometer  IMU  Buzzer  and Safety Switch Module      Runs PX4 Open Source Firmware      Supports UAVCAN Firmware Updating      Sensors          Ublox M9N GPS              Ultra-robust meter-level GNSS positioning              Maximum position availability with concurrent reception of 4 GNSS              Advanced spoofing and jamming detection              Excellent RF interference mitigation          Bosch BMM150 Magnetometer          Bosch BMP388 Barometer          Invensense ICM-42688-P 6-Axis IMU      STM32F412CEU6 MCU      Safety Button      Buzzer      Two Pixhawk Standard CAN Connectors          4 Pin JST GH      Pixhawk Standard Debug Connector          6 Pin JST SH      Small Form Factor          5cm x 5cm x 1cm      LED Indicators          Safety LED          GPS Fix          RGB System Status      USA Built    Flight Logs on 1.12beta5.  https://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=04a5ca3e-91af-4a25-939d-0f61700a226b  https://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=d1e17f9a-1805-49c3-81b3-08f150506ac3    Shell on boot.  ```  ERROR [PX4_MTD] failed to locate spi bus  ERROR [PX4_MTD] mtd failure: -6 bus 2 address 0 class 1  nsh: sercon: command not found  nsh: ver: command not found  nsh: mft: command not found  nsh: mft: command not found  Board architecture defaults: /etc/init.d/rc.board_arch_defaults  ERROR [param] Parameter EKF2_MULTI_IMU not found.  ERROR [param] Parameter SENS_IMU_MODE not found.  ERROR [param] Parameter EKF2_MULTI_MAG not found.  ERROR [param] Parameter SENS_MAG_MODE not found.  Board defaults: /etc/init.d/rc.board_defaults  nsh: rgbled: command not found  nsh: rgbled_ncp5623c: command not found  Board sensors: /etc/init.d/rc.board_sensors  ERROR [parameters] get: param 65535 invalid  ERROR [parameters] get: param 65535 invalid  icm42688p #0 on SPI bus 1 (devid=0x26)  bmp388 #0 on I2C bus 2  bmm150 #0 on I2C bus 1  ERROR [param] Parameter SENS_EN_PX4FLOW not found  INFO  [uavcannode] Node ID 125  bitrate 1000000    NuttShell (NSH) NuttX-10.0.0  nsh>  ```

Title: fake_imu updates for testing gyro filtering
Body: This is a crude way to directly test/inspect the gyro filtering pipeline with data rates that are more representative of real vehicles (eg 8 kHz gyro instead of 250 Hz we have in SITL).    The `fake_imu` publishes fake FIFO gyro data with sine sweeps ramping up to different frequencies on x  y  z over 10 seconds. For convenience the fake accel is populated with the frequency.    You can run this directly in the test build directory.    ``` Console  ~/git/PX4-Autopilot/build/px4_sitl_test$ ctest -VV -R sitl-imu_filtering  ```    #### Example: angular velocity (gyro through low pass with 40 Hz cutoff) 0 - 100 Hz    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84712/118529479-8e05bd80-b711-11eb-8b65-86fc29b2d8ba.png)      To test different values you can modify the parameters in `posix-configs/SITL/init/test/test_imu_filtering`.

Title: Add Publishers and Subscribers for UAVCAN v1
Body: I was motivated to start developing in UAVCAN v1  but it's missing a few pieces first  including a parameter system and a Publisher / Subscriber classes to simplify development.    This is just a first stab at putting some of these pieces in place - by no means a final solution; I don't have the time to do this all myself.  So  just putting this here so that others can take a look and hopefully dive in to continue development.    ~Note: In its current state it won't compile due to too large stack frames... I'm not immediately sure how to easily resolve this.~  Stack size for the module was increased from the default up to 4096 bytes to enable the use of the large dsdl serialization buffers on the stack  vs. needing to use the heap.    **Update:**  Largely Complete:  - [X] Existing code from `run()` refactored into smaller functions  - [X] Generic Subscriber class added; Gnss and Bms placeholders added  - [X] Generic Publisher class added; Gnss publisher in place  - [X] Client-side ESC service added; uses MixingOutput + actuator_armed    Still TODO:  - [ ] Use newer BatteryStatus message (v0.2)  - [ ] Use timestamped GNSS topic (PointStateTs)  - [x] Replace default/unset port ID from 0 --> 65535  - [x] Change the Subscription / Publisher classes to take in SUBJECT_NAME rather than full register name  - [x] Rename Publication --> Publisher  - [ ] Server-side ESC service implementation (comments / outline in place)  - [ ] Make use of actuator Readiness / arming  and listen to returned Status  - [ ] Additional Publisher/Subscriber work -- allow one class to be both a Publisher and a Subscriber (i.e. the EscClient)  - [ ] SubscriptionMulti class (or similar)  - [ ] Clean up the BMS and GPS code that predates this PR  - [ ] Clean up and fully test the Register List/Access system    I've been testing with a Pixhawk 4 + a Babel board  using the Yakut command-line tool as I go along.    **As of 23 Feb**: Have a setup with a CAN-->PWM node configured (in combination with https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/pull/16808).

Title: Revert Pull downs bad levels cause motor spins
Body: It has been reported that the some ESC have spun with  the change to PX4_MAKE_GPIO_INPUT_PULL_DOWN.    If the input to the ESC is puled up in the SoC and the FMU pulls it down  the voltage can sit at 1.56V.     Unfortunately we can be wrong 50% of the time if an ESC uses the pull down against the FMU pull up.     Prior to the series of commits introducing PX4_MAKE_GPIO_INPUT_PULL_DOWN there were no reports. So this seems like a better choice.

Title: Adding BatMon smart battery as a module and refactoring SMBUS based SBS 1 1 spec to a library
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Supporting BatMon(rotoye.com) smart battery units on PX4.    **Describe your solution**  A library drivers__smbus_sbs is created with core SBS 1.1 spec.   BatMon module is built using this library. Other chips such as bq40z80  bq40z50 etc may be added using the underlying library @amikhalev     **Describe possible alternatives**  A PR for adding BatMon support (https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/pull/16723) through the batt_smbus module was attempted. A separate batmon module was requested by dev-team (@dagar) to prevent regression on batt_smbus module.     **Test data / coverage**  BatMon was connected to Pixhawk 4 and tested. Flight test has not been conducted.   - Starting  stopping  resume  suspending the module was tested using `batmon start -X -b 4 -a 11`  `batmon stop` etc.   ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/518314/108641818-633bfe00-746f-11eb-8584-3b4248ce75cc.png)      **Additional context**  Issues identified:   1. `batt_smbus start -X` is able to start an SMBUS capable device on bus 4 and address 0x0b. But `batmon start -X` does not automatically connect to BatMon. It seems to be a problem with not identifying the default bus as 4. Module can start with `batmon start -X -b 4`.

Title: Broadcom AFBR S50LV85D Distance Sensor Driver
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  This PR adds a basic driver for the [Broadcom AFBR-S50LV85D](https://www.broadcom.com/products/optical-sensors/time-of-flight-3d-sensors/afbr-s50lv85d) Distance Sensor that is present on the [ARK Flow](https://arkelectron.com/product/ark-flow/).    **Describe your solution**  The challenge incorporating this driver was needing to use the [pre-compiled library provided by Broadcom](https://github.com/Broadcom/AFBR-S50-API). Through collaboration with Broadcom  the library and API were released with the BSD-3 license to match PX4. The necessary files were copied from the [AFBR-S50-API](https://github.com/Broadcom/AFBR-S50-API) instead of adding it as a submodule to keep the size on disc lower.  Further updates to this driver will need to be made to support more targets.     **Test data / coverage**  The driver was tested on an ARK Flow running as a uavcannode with a Pixhawk 4 Mini on 1.12 beta 5. The system was also running an [ARK GPS](https://arkelectron.com/product/ark-gps/) and [ARK BMS](https://arkelectron.com/ark-bms-smart-battery/) on UAVCAN.     ARK Flow  ARK GPS  and ARK BMS with GPS Fusion on 1.12 beta5. https://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=9f810404-bb1c-4fa2-b05a-be5b970cecc7  ARK Flow  ARK GPS  and ARK BMS without GPS Fusion on 1.12 beta5. https://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=fbe22921-ae3f-4b07-8eee-35efeae3f70e  ARK Flow and ARK BMS No GPS Connected on 1.12 beta5. https://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=01862fc5-cd71-4d1c-a663-d0512b0382ce    https://youtu.be/wu6Hlg_wIcs    **Look Mom  No GPS!**  ![PXL_20210604_222025534 MP](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2019539/120872124-f5699d00-c55a-11eb-9b8b-5d80039336a3.jpg)

Title: Non Version Specific changes for Future NuttX upgades
Body: In the 10.1.0 Of Nuttx this changes will be needed. This PR preps the current PX4 code base for theses structural changes.     Using inttypes - will be enforced in 10.1.0 as will type checking.    getops interface will be Thread safe and accesors will be macros that collide the cli.getops interface. The change here in uses mixed case to avoid the collisions      STM32 Timers will be based on the Basic timer defines and advanced    Includes for debug/syslog/assert/schedule  will only be public API and not layerd.

Title: nora fixed syntax error
Body: I am very sorry for the extra work caused by my mistake. This commit is correct.

Title: microRTPS bridge improvements
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Brings a major list of improvements. Listed bellow.    **Describe your solution**    Major changes/features:  * **Communications and data exchange in the localhost network only** are now possible with ROS2 Foxy when `ROS_LOCALHOST_ONLY` env variable is set to 1. This will also by default enable the **Shared Memory Transport** feature  which is also the default in ROS2. Known limitation: This will not work with ROS2 Galactic though when the middleware is set to CycloneDDS  so this was limited to when the `rmw` implementation is set to FastRTPS  or unset but defaulted to FastRTPS (which is the case of Foxy);  * The microRTPS client (FMU side) now has **statistics** of the link TX/RX when using `micrortps_client status` and provides also a max bandwidth usage of the link using the `-m` argument;  * Fixes the fact that the `micrortps_agent` would SEGFAULT with memory corruption. This was being caused because the program was attempting to delete the `Timesync` object instance twice. This is now solved and the agent exits correctly;  * There's no need now to create specific `rtps` models (like `iris_rtps`)  as now  by default  the `micrortps_client` will be started in `rcS` when one builds the PX4 SITL target using the `make px4_sitl_rtps`. This will require an update on the docs  as the `iris_rtps` was removed from the `make` target options.    Minor changes:  * Apply on the microRTPS agent Pubs and Subs the default QoS policies for memory management and publish mode found in ROS pubs/subs.  * Increase the stack size on the microRTPS client to avoid warnings regarding low stack;  * Add fix to `PRIu32` and `PRIu16` macros usage in the microRTPS agent when building the transport code;  * Building now the microRTPS agent in CI to avoid changes that break it here and on the `px4_ros_com` side. This also adds the `BUILD_MICRORTPS_AGENT` option to `make` to allow building the microRTPS agent during the PX4 `_rtps` build (e.g. `make BUILD_MICRORTPS_AGENT=1 px4_sitl_rtps`);  * Others.    **Describe possible alternatives**  None that I can think of but open to suggestions.    **Test data / coverage**  In PX4 SITL and with a Pixhawk 4. Currently already in usage in the Auterion Skynode.

Title: Add 3D DShot capability
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Fixes #17364     **Describe your solution**  Added 3 DShot parameters to enable 3D DShot.  If DSHOT_3D_ENABLE is selected  the bottom actuator_output range is reversed to comply with DShot specification.  DSHOT_3D_DEAD_H and DSHOT_3D_DEAD_L set the range where output is 0    **Describe possible alternatives**  - Use generic deadband parameters that apply to both DShot and pwm  - Fix actuator output value of 0 not being usable by DShot [see here](https://github.com/benjinne/PX4-Autopilot/blob/4f52c0b6daa93f01b3c02e9457265be107af74be/src/drivers/dshot/DShot.h#L58).     **Test data / coverage**  Tested using a custom rover mixer and both directions worked and deadband/min and max values worked correctly.

Title: Enable crsf and ghst telemetry on supported boards
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  See issue https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/issues/17232    **Describe your solution**  I added BOARD_SUPPORTS_RC_SERIAL_PORT_OUTPUT define to the supported board configs and changed the check for CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_OMNIBUS_F4SD to BOARD_SUPPORTS_RC_SERIAL_PORT_OUTPUT in RCInput.cpp.    **Test data / coverage**  Tested on modalaiFC-V1 board with a crossfire receiver sending telemetry to my radiomaster TX16s transmitter

Title: add esc_battery module to modalai fc v1 build
Body: **problem solved by this pull request**  To get current and voltage readings from escs when no power module is included    **solution**  Add the new esc_battery module to the fc-v1 build    **Test data / coverage**  With the esc_battery module included in a custom build  my voxl-flight now reads out the voltage and current readings from the escs. This was done by using the daily build of QGC and selecting Source as ESCs  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9113272/103309625-9324d300-49e3-11eb-92d6-acd7039ccaa5.png)

Title: boards modalai fc v1 add rtps cmake
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Adds rtps support for modalai/fc-v1    **Describe your solution**  Copied modalai/fc-v1/default.cmake to modalai/fc-v1/rtps.cmake and changed the LABEL to rtps and un-commented the micrortps_bridge module  then added "modalai_fc-v1_rtps" to Jenkinsfile-compile    **Test data / coverage**  I started the module on Telem1 and connected to voxl's microhard usb port with an FTDI adapter. Running the micrortps_agent  I'm able to echo ros topics

Body: This is a new STM32H7 board with 3 IMUs and 8 PWM outputs from mRo (https://store.mrobotics.io/mRo-PixRacer-Pro-p/m10064c.htm) that's a successor the Pixracer.    ![Screenshot from 2020-10-10 20-48-38](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84712/95667873-fe27e180-0b39-11eb-8af3-59868f76375f.png)  ![Screenshot from 2020-10-10 20-49-01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84712/95667883-10098480-0b3a-11eb-9e36-b2777820dda9.png)

Title: microRTPS increase base message ID space and update protocol_splitter header
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  - Preventing and actively adding a bit more room to base messages RTPS IDs  - Follow the update and fix to the agent_protocol_splitter in https://github.com/Auterion/agent_protocol_splitter/pull/14.    **Describe your solution**  - Increase the base ID space to 179  and update the alias messages IDs accordingly;  - On the protocol_splitter  now we include the magic number on XOR for checksum.    **Describe possible alternatives**  N.A.    **Test data / coverage**  Tested with SITL and the Auterion Skynode.

Title: ARK CAN Flow Add ICM 42688 P
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  This PR adds support for the ARK CAN Flow Rev 2 that swaps out the BMI088 for the ICM-42688-P due to lack of availability of the BMI088.    **Describe your solution**  Add the ICM-42688-P in the build. Check if the ICM-42688-P driver doesn't start  then start the BMI088 driver.    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2019539/123330434-3ec66000-d4fb-11eb-8f5c-c5e3fe74d433.png)  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2019539/123331435-8699b700-d4fc-11eb-97e9-f99c15f484bd.png)

Title: Update board h
Body: SPI 2 had the wrong SCK PIN -> PB10 instead of PB13 -> accidentally the kill pin  FRAM wasnt starting  could be probably wrong on other mro boards as well

Title: Enabled uavcan flags in holybro durandal board description
Body: **Problem:** The Holybro Durandal v1 board boasts two can ports for interfacing uavcan devices  but the px4 board file does not reflect this.     **Progress:** I added uavcan to the durandal px4_add_board-call  under both DRIVERS and MODULES. This after @dagar had indicated an old comment "_No H7 or FD can support in UAVCAN yet_" was no longer true. He suggested me to create a draft PR to collaborate on updating the code.    As of the creation of this PR  the code does not build  i.e. make holybro_durandal-v1 fails.

Title: Battery class Refactor
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  The structure of the battery class annoys me for a long time now. This pr is a first stab at simplifying the structure. The final goal is to be able to reuse everything useful also for smart battery drivers but I'm trying to not change everything at once here.    **Describe your solution**  Refactoring:  - It looks like every battery field is stored in stored in the battery_status message and in a separate member field  - Reset logic is complicated ofr that  - Certain fields are set multiple times  - Publish measured values even if the battery is not connected. The connected field gives information and should be checked.  - Remove outdated comment: https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/commit/e360dd34f91628d8d090df10d08250241dcfea7d#diff-3a5252ca9358f1005158928f25483d87347e4c7550a62eeda333baf8c66f90b0R212    **Describe possible alternatives**  Follow-ups should:  - add unit testing  - clarify connected vs too low voltage vs initialized  - enable a smart battery to fill quantities it knows and have the rest estimated    **Test data / coverage**  I did not test this yet. It pure refactoring based on the code. I think a thorough review and might be able to do some basic tests.

Title: gyro_fft decrease default length 1024 512
Body: The `gyro_fft` module is generally working by default but the latency is still a bit high. - change default FFT length (1024 -> 512) - this doubles the update rate because half the number of samples are required for each - decrease number of peaks (4 -> 3) - so far 3 seems to be sufficient - increase median filter window (3 -> 5) - decrease SNR requirement For example this throttle change is detected about 150 milliseconds after commanded. https://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=332c609f-55b2-421d-96f2-0075b6f1bc82

Title: UAVCANv1 Collection of fixes
Body: Collection of fixes for the UAVCANv1 module:  - Remove timed-out CAN frames from canard's Tx queue  - Add support to SubscriptionManager for dynamic port ID updates (instantiate and/or update the port IDs of all DynamicSubscriber objects)  - Fix the port ID update for Publishers    What has been tested (Using a Pixhawk 4):  - Updating the PX4 `UCAN1_*` parameters for all pubs/subs at run-time  with expected results  - Use `yakut monitor` to verify the expected port ID's being published    What has not yet been tested (and is being worked on separately):  - Verify that high-rate messages can be sent (O(100Hz) and larger)

Title: Events interface 1
Body: Now that the mavlink messages got merged  we can continue.    Changes from #16293:  - preflight or calibration not added here yet  - some API simplifications  - converted some of the existing messages to events  - compatibility & transition support (backward + forward):    - PX4 sends out STATUSTEXT + events in parallel for a while    - to each STATUSTEXT sent as event as well  a tab is appended to the message. This message is then ignored on newer QGC  while older QGC's ignore the event and the tab    - this allows to convert incrementally    This should not go into the release yet.

Title: uavcan fw server will place a properly named uavcan file uavcan bin in the fw tree
Body: uavcan:fw server will place a uavcan.bin in the fw tree.       This is a helper to allow a user to install a properly named  uavcan file into the fw tree. Thay simply place the file in the  root directory of the SD card. The file will be deleted.    Naming is:    ${HWNAME}-${HW_MAJOR}.${HW_MINOR}-${SW_MAJOR}.${SW_MINOR}.${uavcanbl_git_desc}.uavcan.bin    I.E: org.cuav.can-gps-v1-1.0-0.1.1c0ed74d.uavcan.bin    The helper will create the directory hierarchy if needed and  move the file from the root dir fw directory as    `+-org.cuav.can-gps-v1`  `+--1.0`  ` +----- can-gps-v1-1.0-0.1.c4af2319.uavcan.bin`    N.B. The file names can be quite long and this change requires a file name length (CONFIG_NAME_MAX and CONFIG_FAT_MAXFNAME) of 60

Title: EKF add baro bias estimator using GNSS altitude
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Barometers develop a bias over time  mainly due to a temperature or a weather change. This can be compensated by estimating the change in offset between another height source that is not affected by the same noise.    **Describe your solution**  In this PR  the GNSS altitude is used to estimate the bias of the magnetometer using a simple single-state KF.    Additional benefit: this is a requirement for multiple height source fusion (e.g.: GNSS alt + baro)    **Test data / coverage**  Used for ~1 year on many different drones without issues.    Example SITL test with drifting baro:  EKF2 is using baro as the primary height source but the drift is compensated by the bias estimator introduced in this PR.  ![DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20210719155037](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14822839/126170643-84823ca3-4ccc-4172-899c-304f9966862e.png)  https://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=6a4b836d-6bb8-420d-aceb-ccee324f3f4d

Title: Add ignition gazebo support for PX4 Software In The Loop simulations
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  This commit adds SITL support for [ignition gazebo](https://ignitionrobotics.org/home). Ignition gazebo is a replacement for the "classic" gazebo for future applications.    Since PX4 uses gazebo for a lot of integration testing and simulated environments  it makes a lot of sense to integrate into the new ignition gazebo.    **Describe your solution**  This implementation is a first iteration supporting SITL in the ignition environment.  - a `mavlink_interface_plugin` was implemented as an interface for `HIL_*` mavlink messages between px4 and `ignition gazebo`  - Only a quadrotor is supported in the current implementation    A demonstration of the package is shown in the video below:  [![ignition gazebo sitl](https://img.youtube.com/vi/38UJqrNQChg/0.jpg)](https://youtu.be/38UJqrNQChg "Circular trajectory tracking")      **Test data / coverage**  The dependency that is only needed in the regular environment is ignition edifice. This is the latest LTS release of ignition gazebo. Supported environments include Ubuntu Focal / Ubuntu Bionic  ```  sh -c 'echo "deb http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo/ubuntu-stable `lsb_release -cs` main" > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/gazebo-stable.list'  wget http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo.key -O - | sudo apt-key add -  apt update  apt install ignition-edifice  ```  The simulation can be run as the following  ```  make px4_sitl ignition  ```    **Additional context**  - The submodule that was added can be found in https://github.com/Auterion/px4-simulation-ignition  - Added ignition gazebo to px4 container: https://github.com/PX4/PX4-containers/pull/303

Title: Heater added support of inverted IMU heat controller output
Body: Depending on the hardware implementation of the IMU heater it can be controlled with either normal (active high) or inverted (active low) pin output.     Current implementation supports only active high IMU heat controller output.     This pull request allows to control both active high and active low IMU heat controller hardware implementation. This can be configured with the SENS_TEMP_INVERT parameter. By default  it's set to 0 which is normal non-inverted control output (active high). When set to 1 the control output will be inverted.

Title: sensors create vehicle_angular_velocity module
Body: This is a new part of the sensors module that creates the system wide angular velocity message needed by the rate controllers and several other modules. Because this message is needed at a relatively high rate (250 Hz now  >= 1 kHz shortly) with absolute minimum latency it runs out of the WQ rate_ctrl.     ``` Code C  vehicle_angular_velocity    uint64 timestamp  # time since system start (microseconds)  uint64 timestamp_sample  # the timestamp of the raw data (microseconds)  float32[3] xyz   # Bias corrected angular velocity about X  Y  Z body axis in rad/s  ```      - broken out of https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/12225

Title: Add ice status uavcan bridge and mavlink stream
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  The problem is described here #17861. It is related at least to possibility of monitoring internal combustion engine state from QGC  but also could be a first step of ICE control implementation.    **Describe your solution and possible alternatives**  Here I added uorb msg  simple uavcan bridge and mavlink stream ice_status -> EFI_STATUS.  Uorb message is based on UAVCAN msg [ice_status](https://legacy.uavcan.org/Specification/7._List_of_standard_data_types/#status-4). Here I suggested that CylinderStatus size = 16 is to much for uorb msg  so I keep fields only for a single CylinderStatus.  Also I made an assumption that 10 Hz will be enough. Higher frequency of this UAVCAN msg could significantly load the bus.    **Test data / coverage**  I made only a simple test by sending fake UAVCAN message to cuav V5.    Here what I send to UAVCAN:  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36133264/125469380-ffee2873-3bd9-4188-80cd-677e54588c24.png)    Here what I have on uorb:  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36133264/125468690-2183f86e-d055-45d6-88ec-eab123be7716.png)    Here what I have on QGC:   ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36133264/125468547-b055f1a2-802a-4de0-bf99-697eb2aac580.png)    So  it is exactly what I expected.

Title: Add No help Option to CONSTRAINED_FLASH

Title: mavlink use dynamic camera comp id instead of hardcoded value
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  When the camera is disconnected/connected to a companion computer it gets a new ID. Before this PR  PX4 was always sending mavlink feedback to hardcoded camera `MAV_COMP_ID_CAMERA`.     **Describe your solution**  This solution will store the camera and system ID that is received from the companion computer  and it will send feedback with exact stored values.   This is not a solution for multiple cameras. For multiple cameras  this will need more logic and more work.

This provides the same behavior as [free(1)](https://gitlab.com/procps-ng/procps/-/blob/master/proc/sysinfo.c). The module measures system-wide memory usage  without swap included.  Enabled in SITL as well.

Title: VL53L1X Region of Interest Distance Mode Setting
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Distance sensor driver for the VL53L1X has region of interest (ROI) that can be programmed  but the set of functions were not implemented in the VL53L1X ul driver integrated into PX4. The ROI settings allow better resolution when changing the ranging area within the field of view. Distance is decreased but resolution is increased allowing the sensor to pick up smaller objects at sub-1 meter ranges.    **Describe your solution**  Utilized the ST vl53l1x ultra lite driver manual to implement two functions that allow a programmable region of interest  also created a distance mode class data member that allows easier setting  this defaults to a short distance mode for better resolution. These two settings lay the ground work for using multiple simultaneous zone detection with multiple distance sensors (2d lidar)    **Describe possible alternatives**  Utilize code from a larger driver that allows Lidar sensing with multiple sensors. However  this has larger code footprint.    **Test data / coverage**  Tested on bench setting with real hardware ITL. Plot from flight review:  ![bokeh_plot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35986980/106339749-25c3c680-625d-11eb-8151-f1c434430617.png)   attached

Title: Sih fw
Body: Hi everyone     I'm excited to release a fixed wing model for the simulator in hardware. The aerodynamic model is based on the Thesis by     > Waqas Khan  supervised by Meyer Nahon "Dynamics modeling of agile fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicles." McGill University  PhD thesis  2016. Sections 3.1  3.2  and 3.3    I implemented it in the class AeroSeg  which is capable of  - full 360 deg angle of attack lift  drag  and pitching moment.  - wings with aspect ratio from 0.1666 up to 6  (gliders would perform poorly for instance).  - control surface (flap) deflection up to 70 degrees.  - unlimited flap chord  (the elevator could take the entire tailplane).  - stall angle function of the flap deflection.  - effect of the flap deflection on lift  drag  and pitching moment.  - any dihedral angle  the fin is modeled as a wing with dihedral angle of 90 deg.  - slipstream velocity (velocity from the propeller) using momentum theory.    This class is meant to model different vehicle easily by specifying the geometry of their wings and tail surfaces.    Notes:  - I need to takeoff in Manual mode with full throttle.  - The floor is a simple model where the vehicle slides on it  it is also automatically replaced flat for the next takeoff which throws off the EKF when landing.    Here are the full 360 deg aerodynamic coefficient for a wing with span 6m  chord 1m and flap chord 0.25m.  ![aoa_full_smooth_AR6](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17630348/127492137-fde4b127-2af3-4c23-9424-78c40f4e9ae6.png)      https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17630348/127492813-4e1efe62-4bbe-44fd-9a95-3f498079bdb9.mp4

Title: Pr nuttx 10 1 0 upstream
Body: For Build testing Upstream NuttX

Title: microRTPS more fixes and improvements
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**    This a a large set of improvements and fixes that address the bellow:    1. The need for a more efficient protocol splitter read operation  while providing relevant statistics to the messages/packets being parsed  2. The need for use ROS time and simulation time when doing timesync  3. The need for allowing to setup a custom RTPS link in SITL (similar to what we do when we override the MAVLink streams)  4. Follow the appropriate format for ROS topic naming for the topics in the microRTPS agent  5. A more efficient way of handling RTPS IDs without having to set them manually  which currently is a burden to the developers adding new uORB messages and a source of error  6. An improved transport layer implementation to reject packets that come from the same entity  i.e. the entity parsing them is the same entity that sent the packets  7. The flow control for UART being set incorrectly  8. A better overall UX for developers doing updates in uORB and wanting to deploy their changes to `px4_ros_com` and `px4_msgs` without having to manually copy everything    And other minor cleanups here and there.    **Describe your solution**  Per topic above:  1. @julianoes implemented a quite more efficient approach to how we read from the UART to a read buffer and from there provide the data to the respective fds for MAVLink and RTPS  2. Added a ROS2 node to the timesync implementation that fetches both ROS time or sim time  depending if the user passes the `use_sim_time` arg set to the node. This is allows the usage of the simulation time when using Gazebo with SITL. Possible when using the following command: `micrortps_agent -t UDP --ros-args -p use_sim_time:=true`  3. Added a `px4-rc.rtps` with the default microRTPS client args  while still allowing to use another file setup in PATH  4. Changed the topic naming to the format `<robot_namespace>/fmu/<uorb_topic_name>/in` and `<robot_namespace>/fmu/<uorb_topic_name>/out`  depending if the data is going to the FMU (agent subscribers) or coming from the FMU (agent publishers) respectively. E.g  `/SensorCombined_PubSubTopic` now becomes `/fmu/sensor_combined/out`. *  5. Remove the need to manually set the IDs in the yaml file and made the attribution automatic and only to the topics added to the yaml file. *  6. The `sys_id` field was removed from the `timesync` message and not it's embedded as part of the RTPS header that gets serialized in the link. Not only this reduces the size of the message  but also allows to reject data coming from the exact same entity for all the topics. This is applicable when  or one is using the same UDP port to send and receive data  or one is using the same topic for pub/sub (either them quite improbable now with the default setup and updated topic naming).  7. Well now it is set correctly in https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/commit/667a9364b5b55e4c30e672d127fb04fa67ca8891.  8. New handy `make` targets were added in order to facilitate the generation and update of `px4_msgs` and `px4_ros_com` when uORB messages and/or microRTPS agent templates are updated. This makes it easier for developers to update their PX4-ROS2 bridge code on the ROS2 side  by simply issuing a `make` command and passing the `ROS2_WS_DIR` as an env var input. E.g:    ```sh  ROS2_WS_DIR=~/Auterion/colcon_ws/ make update_ros2_bridge  ```    The output looks something like:    ```bash  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  ----------------------          microRTPS bridge yaml PX4 to ROS topics          ----------------------  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  -- - '/home/nuno/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/msg/tools/urtps_bridge_topics.yaml' file loaded  -- - 26 ROS message file names updated  -- - '/home/nuno/PX4/colcon_ws/src/px4_ros_com/templates/urtps_bridge_topics.yaml' created  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  ---------------          microRTPS agent code generation and templates update          ----------------  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  -- - '/home/nuno/PX4/colcon_ws/src/px4_ros_com/templates/microRTPS_timesync.cpp.em' updated  -- - '/home/nuno/PX4/colcon_ws/src/px4_ros_com/templates/Publisher.h.em' updated  -- - '/home/nuno/PX4/colcon_ws/src/px4_ros_com/templates/RtpsTopics.cpp.em' updated  --    - 3 template files updated  -- - '/home/nuno/PX4/colcon_ws/src/px4_ros_com/scripts/uorb_rtps_classifier.py' updated  --    - 1 code generator / helper file updated  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  -----------------------          microRTPS bridge uORB to ROS messages          -----------------------  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  -- - Generated 201 ROS message files in '/home/nuno/PX4/colcon_ws/src/px4_msgs/msg'  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  --------------------------------          Update successful!          ---------------------------------  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  ```    **Describe possible alternatives**  Well it's a big set of changes  and maybe there might be some alternatives here and there  but these were the approaches that were thought and looked more reasonable when they were taken. Note the above is already being used and proved internally.    **Test data / coverage**  No data coverage at this point  but this can easily be tested with the current supported platforms and interfaces for the bridge.    **Additional context**  N.A.      *  THIS IS A BREAKING CHANGE  i.e.  the user/developer should be aware that it might need to update some part of it's workflow or application to fit the changes.    1. For the RTPS IDs  just make sure you follow the recommended convention documented on the new yaml file and update both PX4-Autopilot  px4_msgs and px4_ros_com so they are in sync;  2. For the topic name update  just make sure you update your nodes or remap them to the new topics.    @markusachtelik FYI.

Title: RP2040 MCU Support
Body: Submitting a pull as asked by the dev-team during [PX4 dev call](https://discuss.px4.io/t/px4-dev-call-july-21-2021/23297).    **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Add PX4 base layer support for RP2040 MCU    **Describe your solution**  Currently  this branch is created from @davids5's  [pr-nuttx-10.1.0+-upstream](https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/tree/pr-nuttx-10.1.0+-upstream) branch because the nuttx in current master doesn't have support for RP2040. Let me know if I should do thing differently in this matter.  So far  files with absolute necessity are added so that PX4 compiles. Other base layer functions for adc  spi  etc. will be added eventually.    **Test data / coverage**  Working on it.    **Additional context**  Creating this pull request as a draft because many more changes will happen before the PX4 base layer is ready for RP2040. The main goal of creating this PR is to get some feedback from dev-team.    Please take a look at commits made since July 14th.

Title: dshot improve performance by removing extra motor_buffer array
Body: Reduces CPU load by almost 1.5% @ 2khz on F4 and F7.    This changes the motor ordering on boards where the timer ordering does  not match the order of the timer usage in the channels defintion.  Only omnibus f4sd is affected.

Title: Jenkins remove modalai_fc v1 temporarily
Body: - board test harness needs to be repaired

Title: platforms nuttx px4_init initialize and reset all I2C buses
Body: This adds a full I2C bus reset in board init  both using the low level I2C driver reset (if enabled)  followed by a general call software reset. With a centralized bus reset now handled by the board on all buses we can reduce the retries scattered across most drivers. The current external I2C device probing results in a huge number of I2C reset attempts.      - fixes init for stubborn I2C devices like the Sensirion sdp3x or the QMC588L magnetometer    - minimize the retry count for most I2C drivers as the board now does a reset on each bus

Title: Improve Ignition Gazebo Startup scripts
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Previously  the ignition startup script was not using the model name  effectively limiting it to start only one world (`ignition.world`)      **Describe your solution**  This PR extends the script so that multiple models can be added to ignition gazebo    As an addition  this PR  also enables verbose from the `VERBOSE_SIM=1` for ignition gazebo (also available for classical gazebo)    **Test data / coverage**  ```  VERBOSE_SIM=1 make px4_sitl ignition  ```    **Additional context**  - Includes submodule update of https://github.com/Auterion/px4-simulation-ignition/pull/14

Title: Support headless mode for ignition gazebo
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  While `HEADLESS=1` supports other simulators such as `jsbsim`  `gazebo` this flag doesn't work for ignition gazebo    **Describe your solution**  This adds support for `HEADLESS=1` when starting ignition gazebo with headless mode    **Test data / coverage**  Headless mode can be tested with the following command  ```  HEADLESS=1 make px4_sitl ignition  ```    **Additional context**  - This is a follow up PR of https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/pull/18187

avg  min 429us max 430us 0.421us rms  int32 div (10k ops): 10 events  4888us elapsed  488.80us avg  min 488us max 489us 0.422us rms  INFO  [microbench] TEST PASSED: time_32bit_integers    INFO  [microbench] RUNNING TEST: time_64bit_integers  int64 add (1k ops): 10 events  1199us elapsed  119.90us avg  min 119us max 120us 0.316us rms  int64 sub (1k ops): 10 events  1273us elapsed  127.30us avg  min 127us max 128us 0.482us rms  int64 mul (1k ops): 10 events  1008us elapsed  100.80us avg  min 100us max 101us 0.421us rms  int64 div (1k ops): 10 events  6864us elapsed  686.40us avg  min 686us max 687us 0.516us rms  INFO  [microbench] TEST PASSED: time_64bit_integers  ```  However there's a remaining issue: loading and storing from/to memory uses additional runtime  distorting the results (this could be fixed by using inline assembly). So I'm inclined to just remove the tests to avoid incorrect interpretation.    Out of interest I also checked cos/sin from cmsis:  ```  sinf() (1k ops): 10 events  8714us elapsed  871.40us avg  min 871us max 872us 0.515us rms  cosf() (1k ops): 10 events  8357us elapsed  835.70us avg  min 835us max 836us 0.480us rms  arm_sin() (1k ops): 10 events  2933us elapsed  293.30us avg  min 293us max 294us 0.483us rms  arm_cos() (1k ops): 10 events  3110us elapsed  311.00us avg  min 311us max 311us   nanus rms  ```  So we would gain something there  but the result is also less accurate.

Title: Flexible FMU pins and timer config
Body: This changes the FMU timer + pin reservation to a first-come-first-serve pattern: on startup camera drivers and others reserve the pins (and timers) they want  and later the pwm/dshot driver uses the remaining timers + pins.  As a result  all the mode_* handling is removed  and camera trigger/capture can use any pins.    Tested:  - pixracer  pixhawk 4  - various combinations of camera trigger (pwm and gpio)  capture  pwm input with pwm output and dshot.  - oneshot  - concurrently run dshot + pwm output  - pwm_out instance splitting on cuav x7pro

Title: ina238 Support for ina238 power monitors
Body: Implements a driver for the INA237  INA238 and INA239 power modules    **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  For newer 12S power modules  different chip choices are available. PX4 already contains a driver for the INA228 chip. The INA23X chips differ in that they have less resolution and are cheaper.    **Describe your solution**  INA23X are very similar to INA228  so this driver is based on the INA228 driver. Constants and the math are different  and the results registers are a different bit-width  so different readout. I implemented this as a standalone driver rather than making the existing INA228 driver too complicated. This way  people can just integrate the driver for the hardware they have.     **Describe possible alternatives**  Make the INA228 into a general purpose TI-power module driver  with either params to choose the right registers and math or even autodetect.     **Test data / coverage**  Tested on Skynode    **Additional context**  Like the INA228 driver  this needs param `SENS_EN_INA23X` do be set to 1 to be launched.

Title: Add bootloader crypto
Body: This PR adds architecture/HW specific crypto interface in platforms/common/include/arch_crypto.h  This interface is WIP  and to be specified in more detail in Security SIG  In addition this adds:  - Two libraries to implement the security IF:s  arch_crypto and arch_keystore  - Example implementations for those libraries under platforms/common  utilizing monocypher as the backend library  - Way to configure which crypto implementation to use in target's cmake file  - Use the px4 crypto interface in nuttx based bootloaders  having the same implementation as with the old bl.    The way to take px4 crypto interface into use is to:  - select the implementation for CRYPTO and KEYSTORE in target's cmake file. For example "sw_crypto" and "stub_keystore" for the ones implemented in this PR.  - if the bootloader security is wanted  select the same in the bootloader's cmake file  and in addition define macros in hw_config.h:  #define BOOTLOADER_USE_SECURITY  #define BOOTLOADER_SIGNING_ALGORITHM CRYPTO_ED25519  These defines will switch on the ed25519 signature checking in bl.c    The functionality with the bootloader has been tested on a custom HW

Title: Add risc v compiler
Body: This brings in support for compiling RISC-V based targets. We are building a flight controller / flight computer based on Microchip PolarFire MPFS250T chip.    Please comment if this kind of stuff is wanted in before there is not any targets using it? Or would it make sense to discuss about this kind of additions later on  at the same time if/when new full chip support for some RISC-V would be brought in?    I was thinking that this might be useful for others as well  if someone else is working on RISC-V targets for PX4.    If this is not wanted in at this time  just ignore and close this PR :)

Title: Signed boot master
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  This *draft* PR continues the work by @dinomani to add signature to the px4 binary. This is very much a framework  even though a working sample is implemented on fmuv5 target.    This PR fulfills the following requirements/properties:    - The generated images are compatible with existing px4 (i.e. the signed images boot normally if the device has got a bootloader that doesn't support image signing check)  - The signing tool can be switched without code modifications (environment variable SIGNING_TOOL for makefiles)  - The signing algorithm can be freely selected (related to above)  - There is a way to add certificates (e.g. R&D certificate unlocking specific functionality for a single device)    The provided signing script is a working example  interesting parts are the structures (toc  certficates...)    When building the software with SIGNING_TOOL environment variable pointing to the signing script  this creates a signed image. For example:  SIGNING_TOOL=Tools/cryptotools.py make px4_fmuv5_default    This is compatible with bootloader implementation in https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Bootloader/pull/179

Title: Move px4io mixing to FMU
Body: This moves the mixing out of the px4_io-v2 (stm32f103) and into the px4io driver FMU side. By handling all the mixing directly in PX4 we'll be in a better position to iterate on system configurability  control allocation  and really anything related to mixing. This also saves a relatively large amount of flash (~ 23 kilobytes).    The downside is we lose full manual control RC passthrough  but that's useless for multicopters  and even for VTOLs where the convention has been to have MC on MAIN and FW on AUX. The px4io can still handle fixed failsafe output values and a manual kill switch  but otherwise all actual work is done on the FMU.    Not yet fully functional  but getting closer.    ### TODO:   - [x] ~~kill switch~~   - [x] failsafe positions   - [x] move px4io entirely to WQ   - [x] review in air restart   - [x] test test test   - [x] watchdog? (we'll bring this in separately https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/pull/18086)

For this use case I ran into...    **Describe your solution**  A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.    **Describe possible alternatives**  A clear and concise description of alternative solutions or features you've considered.    **Test data / coverage**  How was it tested? Title: Auto tuning of angular rates and attitude controllers MC version
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Trial and error manual tuning requires good piloting skills and tuning experience. The new module`mc_autotune_attitude_control` introduced in this PR is an attempt to address these issues by automating this tuning process.    More than this  the result of the system identification algorithm included in this module will be helpful to the control systems engineer to obtain a simple discrete-time model of the system that can be later used for offline controller design of more sophisticated controllers.    **Describe your solution**  The auto-tuning introduced in this PR is based on indirect (online closed-loop system identification + controller design) adaptive control theory. Running at relatively high speed in real time on a microcontroller  only recursive filters and estimators have been used. For the same reason  the PID designer (based on General Minimum Variance Control) uses a pre-computed closed-form solution to obtain the result of the optimization problem.    ![DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20210905105049](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14822839/135276353-8fddb106-a61d-423d-97fa-177a9aabc618.png)    For more details  see:   [MathieuBresciani_Controllers_auto-tuning_for_multirotors_and_fixed-wing_vehicles.pdf](https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/files/7252179/MathieuBresciani_Controllers_auto-tuning_for_multirotors_and_fixed-wing_vehicles.pdf)  and the recorded presentation (PX4 Dev Summit 2021):  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yzhjlo5FnCU&t=2s&ab_channel=PX4Autopilot-OpenSourceFlightControl.    **How to use it?**  IMPORTANT: moving the roll/pitch stick of the remote during identification will immediately abort the process. It can be started again using the `MC_AT_START` parameter.    It will soon be a single click on a button in the "Tuning" tab of QGC (but it isn't upsreamed at the moment) but for now  it can be triggered manually via the parameter `MC_AT_START` (set to 1  it'll automatically go back to 0 when done). For the rest  follow the documentation in the Skynode manual:  https://docs.auterion.com/skynode/advanced-configuration/controllers-auto-tuning    **Test data / coverage**  SITL jMavSim on this branch:  https://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=d305531b-5462-4b1c-949f-7f89c2beefab    Result in `autotune_attitude_control_status.msg`  From top to bottom:  - current state of the state machine  - value of the estimated coefficients (discrete-time transfer function)  - signal injected to the input of the rate controller (for system identification)  - PID gain generated using the current model and desired meta-parameters  ![DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20210929151049](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14822839/135275612-dc17414e-1166-42b4-91b9-1a9ee21838fa.png)    Replayed on offline Python tool (soon available):  ![DeepinScreenshot_urxvt_20210929151343](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14822839/135275768-b72185d3-ff77-470f-94b8-fe01612dd6a7.png)    Test on a X500 (same algorithm but different branch):  https://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=7a2a60fd-dfba-4356-b92b-5dfd687bd579    TODO:  - [x] add module to all targets  - [x] find a way to send back the current status to QGC through mavlink (@dagar we used to have a `progress` field in the ACK message but it's apparently not there anymore)

Title: mavlink USB auto start
Body: Opening this early to discuss as it may be somewhat controversial. Currently on most boards with USB we always start `sercon` (CDC/ACM serial device)  then attempt to start Mavlink USB (/dev/ttyACM0). This pull request instead uses GPIO_OTGFS_VBUS to automatically create the CDC/ACM serial device  then launch mavlink.    ### Connect USB  ``` Console  nsh> sercon: Registering CDC/ACM serial driver  sercon: Successfully registered the CDC/ACM serial driver  INFO  [mavlink] mode: Config  data rate: 800000 B/s on /dev/ttyACM0 @ 57600B  nsh> mavlink status    instance #0:          mavlink chan: #0          type:           USB CDC          flow control: OFF          rates:            tx: 0.000 kB/s            txerr: 0.826 kB/s            tx rate mult: 0.050            tx rate max: 800000 B/s            rx: 0.000 kB/s          FTP enabled: YES  TX enabled: YES          mode: Config          MAVLink version: 1          transport protocol: serial (/dev/ttyACM0 @2000000)    instance #1:          mavlink chan: #1          type:           RADIO Link            rssi:         28            remote rssi:  0            txbuf:        91            noise:        26            remote noise: 0            rx errors:    0            fixed:        0          flow control: ON          rates:            tx: 0.883 kB/s            txerr: 0.000 kB/s            tx rate mult: 1.000            tx rate max: 1200 B/s            rx: 0.017 kB/s          FTP enabled: YES  TX enabled: YES          mode: Normal          MAVLink version: 1          transport protocol: serial (/dev/ttyS1 @57600)  ```    ### Disconnect USB  ``` Console  nsh> INFO  [mavlink] exiting channel 0  serdis: Disconnected  nsh> mavlink status    instance #0:          mavlink chan: #1          type:           RADIO Link            rssi:         34            remote rssi:  0            txbuf:        95            noise:        26            remote noise: 0            rx errors:    0            fixed:        0          flow control: ON          rates:            tx: 1.030 kB/s            txerr: 0.000 kB/s            tx rate mult: 1.000            tx rate max: 1200 B/s            rx: 0.016 kB/s          FTP enabled: YES  TX enabled: YES          mode: Normal          MAVLink version: 1          transport protocol: serial (/dev/ttyS1 @57600)  ```

Title: Quick magnetometer bias calibration
Body: The smartphone-like magnetometer calibration  ![DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20211001160112](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14822839/135633004-ab782e64-60e9-4a34-a231-45610dae448d.png)  Image source: https://www.howtogeek.com/519142/how-to-calibrate-the-compass-on-android-to-improve-device-location-accuracy/    **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Once the soft iron effects and scale factors are known from the factory calibration  the magnetometers are usually only disturbed by hard iron effects  mostly due to (non-)permanent magnetization of components  payload change  batteries  ...    **Describe your solution**  Calibrating the bias does not require a full 6-axis calibration and can be easily estimated using gyro data in a simple estimator as described in http://www.roboticsproceedings.org/rss09/p50.pdf as long as some rotation of the drone is performed before flight.    This should completely remove the need of a complete in-field "mag dance" and a rotation of +/-30 degrees in all direction is usually more than enough to estimate the biases.    The new biases are directly used co correct the mag readings in `VehicleMagnetometer` and are used on disarm to update the `CAL_MAGx_xOFF` parameters.    **Test data / coverage**  Used on many vehicles on a daily basis.  Example of a bench test (using this branch) with an artificial bias created by a magnet attached to the external GNSS+mag module:  https://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=dfaeada6-24a2-4948-ad00-ea9fbe8b64be  ![DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20211001152706](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14822839/135631146-9eebb6d2-446e-47cc-b5f0-1bab61f25d20.png)

Title: gyro_fft require higher SNR for initially tracking a peak
Body: On real vehicles the tracked FFT peaks can be a bit erratic. This PR updates the detection in `gyro_fft` to first require a much stronger peak (SNR 10 -> 15db) before initially tracking  but then to continue tracking that threshold is reduced (SNR 5 db).      #### Example from a real quadcopter flying master  ![Screenshot from 2021-09-19 13-44-42](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84712/133937474-b71306b8-a720-4c38-b8c0-1c44bb2942b2.png)     - prior to takeoff (first half of log) there are false positives   - during flight real frequency peaks (that correspond to motor RPM) are detected  but intermittently lost which increases the number of necessary resets in the bank of notch filters

Title: Enablement of PX4 SPI driver for nxp_ucans32k146 board
Body: UCANS32K146 is currently broken in master due to broken SPI/I2C bindings. This PR affects only the UCANS32K146 board and fixes these bindings so I2C/SPI sensors like vl53l0x work. This was done by porting SPI driver code from the FMUK66 to the UCANS32K146  as both chips have the same SPI module.    This PR also includes a "distancesensor" cmake file for testing I2C/SPI distance sensors with the UCANS32K146.     Tested by building firmware with nxp_ucans32k146_distancesensor as a target  connecting a vl53l0x  and testing the driver to see if it works.

Title: PX4 board configuration using Kconfig
Body: A Request for Comments (RFC) Replaces #17052 by providing boardconfig for the whole board. Current testing target is fmuk66-v3 configuration using Kconfig ~Almost~ **All** CMake options in [default.cmake](https://github.com/PetervdPerk-NXP/Firmware/blob/px4_kconfig/boards/nxp/fmuk66-v3/default.cmake) have been removed and been replaced by [default.px4board](https://github.com/PetervdPerk-NXP/Firmware/blob/px4_kconfig/boards/nxp/fmuk66-v3/default.px4board) Seperate labels from the same board always inherit the default.px4board and provide a delta file of features which are enabled/disabled e.g. [rtps.px4board](https://github.com/PetervdPerk-NXP/Firmware/blob/px4_kconfig/boards/nxp/fmuk66-v3/rtps.px4board) ~To facilitate a seamless transition process both the default.cmake option and boardconfig still work. Only when you start using them at the same time you will get CMake errors that modules have been added twice.~ Dependencies this PR pulls in the Python [kconfiglib ](https://pypi.org/project/kconfiglib/) package which provides a ncurses based a GUI based Kconfig GUI tool to configure your build. **How to use this?** - Install kconfiglib using pip3 install kconfiglib - Type `make nxp_fmuk66-v3 boardconfig` or `make nxp_fmuk66-v3 boardguiconfig` - Select your required modules. **Cross-platform support** | OS | boardconfig | boardguiconfig | |---------|-------------|-------------------------------| | Linux | Working | Working | | Windows (PX4 Toolchain / Cygwin) | Working | Working requires https://github.com/PX4/PX4-windows-toolchain/pull/25 | | Windows (Python for Windows) | Working requires pip3 install windows-ncurses | Working | | macOS Big Sur M1 (homebrew) | Working | Working | | macOS Big Sur x86 (pyenv) | Working requires install of curses | Working | **Open tasks** - [x] ~Boardconfig changes don't have immediate effect workaround for is using make clean -> have to automatically reset CMakeCache or other caches after boardconfig.~ Solved by using CMAKE_CONFIGURE_DEPENDS - [x] Verify we aren't breaking anything -> compare cmake build and Kconfig build and look for differences - [x] Check if the current Kconfig cmake rules actually work on Windows and Mac - [x] ~Implement Kconfig rules for UART configuration~ ->~Doesn't work that nice with Kconfig rather keep it in default.cmake for now~ -> All combinations have been written out GPS1-5 / TEL1-5 - [x] Implement Kconfig rules for UAVCANv0 interface count - [x] Verify with other targets -> Compiles for FMUK66 & FMUv5 not tested on real HW - [x] Update CI to include kconfiglib pypi package - [x] Convert all boards & labels from cmake to px4board **Nice things for in the future** - Default profiles e.g. FMU minimal profile & Cannode minimal profile - Kconfig depedencies e.g. SYSTEMCMDS_LED_CONTROL depends on DRIVERS_LIGHTS_RGBLED - Full naming of Kconfig modules currently based on folder name e.g. "pca9685" -> "PCA9685 PWM/Servo driver" - More in-line documentation in Kconfig using the help parameter - Conversion of more targets from cmake to boardconfig

Title: ControlAllocation normalize control allocation matrix
Body: - [x] requires https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Matrix/pull/167    **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  Switching from a static "mixer" to dynamic control allocation including changing to a non-normalized new rate controller is a too large step for most people and it is difficult for us to handle all those changes at the same time.    **Describe your solution**  Add control allocation matrix normalization to be able to use the current "normalized" rate controller. That way  the change will be invisible to the user as the resulting CA matrix is the same as before (i.e.: no need to re-tune the rate controller).    Normalization done as in: https://github.com/PX4/PX4-Autopilot/blob/6b8840a01b87dce6958cd7907b913eb88f5ddb61/src/lib/mixer/MultirotorMixer/geometries/tools/px_generate_mixers.py#L197-L224    **Test data / coverage**  Tested using `make px4_sitl_ctrlalloc gazebo_typhoon_h480_ctrlalloc`  The hexacopter is able to fly with 5 and even 4 propellers (when loosing two opposite rotors  e.g.: 0 and 1)  ![DeepinScreenshot_select-area_20211006141556](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14822839/136200325-6014238a-0e14-4a00-be5d-c71cec80faf0.png)

Title: Add sitl glider model
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  While gliding has been added to offboard  there were no vehicles that actually were unpowered.    This model can be useful for not only developing gliders  but also observing behaviors in TECS.    The model is a modified version of the `standard plane` model. The rotors are removed from the vehicle.    In order to takeoff  the simulation is equipped with a `catapult_plugin`  which throws the vehicle to up to around 30m altitude.     **Describe your solution**  This commit adds a SITL target for a unpowered glider model    **Test data / coverage**  ```  make px4_sitl gazebo_glider  ```  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5248102/126079600-94ba381b-8570-4605-9085-4f404debf135.png)    The vehicle takeoff can be triggered by typing  ```  commander takeoff  ```  in the mavlink shell    **Additional context**  - model files are added in the submodule https://github.com/PX4/PX4-SITL_gazebo/pull/785

Title: PilotPi fix upload command
Body: **Describe problem solved by this pull request**  `make scumaker_pilotpi_default upload` now fails somehow... A quick fix for that.
